translation: And who are more unjust than those who prevent the name of Allah from being mentioned in His mosques and strive toward their destruction. It is not for them to enter them except in fear. For them in this world is disgrace, and they will have in the Hereafter a great punishment.
interpretation: This verse highlights the severe injustice of those who prevent the remembrance of Allah in His mosques and work towards their destruction. Such individuals, driven by arrogance and ignorance, are denied the blessings of entering the mosques except in fear and humiliation. Their actions lead to disgrace and a severe punishment in this world and the Hereafter. It serves as a warning against disrespecting places of worship and obstructing the remembrance of Allah.
orig: ومن أظلم ممن منع مساجد الله أن يذكر فيها اسمه وسعى في خرابها أولئك ما كان لهم أن يدخلوها إلا خائفين لهم في الدنيا خزي ولهم في الآخرة عذاب عظيم

translation: And to Allah belongs the east and the west. So wherever you turn, there is the Face of Allah. Indeed, Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the omnipresence and omniscience of Allah. It conveys the idea that Allah is everywhere, and His knowledge encompasses everything. It also highlights the unity of worship towards Allah, as no matter where individuals turn, they are ultimately facing Allah. Therefore, believers should submit to Allah in all aspects of their lives, knowing that Allah is fully aware of everything.
orig: ولله المشرق والمغرب فأينما تولوا فثم وجه الله إن الله واسع عليم

translation: And they say, "The Most Merciful has taken a son." Exalted is He! Rather, they are [but] honored servants. They cannot precede Him in word, and they act by His command.
interpretation: This verse highlights the falsehood of those who claim that God has taken a son. It emphasizes that God transcends such human qualities and relationships, and that everything in the heavens and the earth belongs to Him. Furthermore, it emphasizes that all beings, including angels and humans, are subservient to God's will and cannot act independently of His command.
orig: وقالوا اتخذ الله ولدا سبحانه بل له ما في السماوات والأرض كل له قانتون

translation: Originator of the heavens and the earth. When He decrees a matter, He only says to it, 'Be,' and it is.
interpretation: This verse highlights the power and authority of Allah, emphasizing His ability to create and bring things into existence simply by commanding them to 'be.' It signifies the divine power of Allah as the ultimate Creator and the one who controls all matters. It demonstrates the unmatched ability of Allah to manifest His will and bring about instant transformation, showcasing His supreme authority over all creation.
orig: بديع السماوات والأرض وإذا قضى أمرا فإنما يقول له كن فيكون

translation: And those who do not know say, 'Why does Allah not speak to us or there come to us a sign?' Thus spoke those before them like their words. Their hearts resemble each other. We have shown clearly the signs to a people who are certain.
interpretation: This verse teaches that throughout history, there have been people who questioned why Allah does not communicate directly with them or show them clear signs of His existence. Allah is addressing the doubters and skeptics, reminding them that He has indeed provided clear signs to those who have faith and certainty. The verse highlights the importance of having firm belief and certainty in Allah's signs and messages, even if they are not always in the form that people expect or desire.
orig: وقال الذين لا يعلمون لولا يكلمنا الله أو تأتينا آية كذلك قال الذين من قبلهم مثل قولهم تشابهت قلوبهم قد بينا الآيات لقوم يوقنون

translation: Indeed, We have sent you with the truth as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. And you will not be asked about the companions of Hellfire.
interpretation: This verse is indicating that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was sent by Allah with the truth to deliver glad tidings to the believers and to warn the disbelievers of the consequences of their actions. It also emphasizes that he will not be held accountable for what happens to the people who are destined for Hellfire, as ultimately it is up to Allah to judge and decide on matters of the Hereafter.
orig: إنا أرسلناك بالحق بشيرا ونذيرا ولا تسأل عن أصحاب الجحيم

translation: And the Jews will never be pleased with you, nor the Christians until you follow their religion. Say, "Indeed, the guidance of Allah is the [only] guidance." If you were to follow their desires after what has come to you of knowledge, you would have against Allah no protector or helper.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the idea that believers should remain steadfast in their faith and not be swayed by the desires or opinions of others, even if those others are influential groups such as Jews or Christians. It highlights the importance of following the guidance provided by Allah, rather than following the whims and beliefs of others. It also serves as a reminder that true guidance comes from Allah alone, and straying from that path can leave a person without divine protection or support.
orig: ولن ترضى عنك اليهود ولا النصارى حتى تتبع ملتهم قل إن هدى الله هو الهدى ولئن اتبعت أهواءهم بعد الذي جاءك من العلم ما لك من الله من ولي ولا نصير

translation: Those to whom We gave the Scripture recite it with its true recital. It is they who believe in it. And whoever disbelieves in it - it is they who are the losers.
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the importance of reciting the scripture (the Qur'an in this context) with a true and sincere recital. Those who believe in the scripture and recite it with understanding and faith will benefit from it and be rewarded. Conversely, those who reject it or fail to recite it with respect and faith are the ones who suffer loss.
orig: الذين آتيناهم الكتاب يتلونه حق تلاوته أولئك يؤمنون به ومن يكفر به فأولئك هم الخاسرون

translation: O Children of Israel, remember My favor that I have bestowed upon you and that I preferred you over the worlds.
interpretation: This verse is a reminder to the Children of Israel to reflect on the blessings and favors that Allah has bestowed upon them. It serves as a call to gratitude and appreciation for the special position they have been granted among all nations and communities. It highlights the importance of recognizing and acknowledging Allah's favor and responding with obedience and gratitude.
orig: يا بني إسرائيل اذكروا نعمتي التي أنعمت عليكم وأني فضلتكم على العالمين

translation: And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, and no compensation will be accepted from it, nor will any intercession benefit it, nor will they be aided.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of individual accountability on the Day of Judgment. It highlights that on that day, no one will be able to intercede or take the burden of another person's sins. Each individual will be responsible for their own actions, and there will be no escape from facing the consequences of one's deeds. It serves as a reminder to each person to be conscious of their actions and strive to do good, as no one else can bear their burdens on the Day of Judgment.
orig: واتقوا يوما لا تجزي نفس عن نفس شيئا ولا يقبل منها عدل ولا تنفعها شفاعة ولا هم ينصرون

translation: And [mention] when Ibrahim was tried by his Lord with commands and he fulfilled them. [Allah] said, "Indeed, I will make you a leader for the people." [Ibrahim] said, "And of my descendants?" [Allah] said, "My covenant does not include the wrongdoers."
interpretation: This verse highlights the story of the Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) being tested by Allah and passing the test successfully. Ibrahim's request to include his descendants in Allah's covenant emphasizes the importance and value of righteousness and morality within the lineage of prophets. The verse teaches us that the covenant of Allah is not inherited by those who continue in wrongdoing and injustice, emphasizing the principle of accountability and individual responsibility in following the path of righteousness.
orig: وإذ ابتلى إبراهيم ربه بكلمات فأتمهن قال إني جاعلك للناس إماما قال ومن ذريتي قال لا ينال عهدي الظالمين

translation: And [mention] when We made the House a place of return for the people and [a place of] security. And take, [O believers], from the standing place of Abraham a place of prayer. And We charged Abraham and Ishmael, [saying], 'Purify My House for those who perform Tawaf and those who are staying [there] for worship and those who bow and prostrate [in prayer].'
interpretation: This verse highlights the significance of the Kaaba as a central place for humanity, ordained as a sanctuary and a symbol of security. It also emphasizes the importance of the act of worship and purification in Islam, illustrating the duty given to Abraham and Ishmael to maintain the sanctity and cleanliness of the Kaaba for the benefit of those who worship, perform Tawaf (circumambulation), and engage in prayer within its vicinity.
orig: وإذ جعلنا البيت مثابة للناس وأمنا واتخذوا من مقام إبراهيم مصلى وعهدنا إلى إبراهيم وإسماعيل أن طهرا بيتي للطائفين والعاكفين والركع السجود

translation: And [mention] when Abraham said, 'My Lord, make this city [Makkah] secure and provide its people with fruits - whoever of them believes in Allah and the Last Day.' [Allah] said, 'And whoever disbelieves - I will grant him enjoyment for a little; then I will force him to the punishment of the Fire, and wretched is the destination.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the supplication of the Prophet Abraham (peace be upon him) for the safety and sustenance of the people of Makkah who believe in Allah and the Last Day. It also mentions that non-believers will be given enjoyment in this world for a limited time, but they will ultimately face the punishment of the Fire in the Hereafter. The verse serves as a reminder of the consequences of belief and disbelief, emphasizing the importance of faith in Allah and the Day of Judgment.
orig: وإذ قال إبراهيم رب اجعل هذا بلدا آمنا وارزق أهله من الثمرات من آمن منهم بالله واليوم الآخر قال ومن كفر فأمتعه قليلا ثم أضطره إلى عذاب النار وبئس المصير

translation: And [mention] when Abraham was raising the foundations of the House and [with him] Ishmael, [saying], 'Our Lord, accept [this] from us. Indeed, You are the Hearing, the Knowing.'
interpretation: This verse describes Prophet Ibrahim and Prophet Isma'il building the Kaaba, the sacred structure in Makkah. Through their actions and supplication to Allah, they demonstrate submission and worship to Allah, acknowledging His ability to accept their efforts and prayers. It teaches us the importance of sincerity and devoutness in our worship, as well as the significance of seeking acceptance from Allah in our deeds.
orig: وإذ يرفع إبراهيم القواعد من البيت وإسماعيل ربنا تقبل منا إنك أنت السميع العليم

translation: Our Lord, make us Muslims [in submission] to You and from our descendants a Muslim [in submission] nation to You. And show us our rites and accept our repentance. Indeed, You are the Accepting of Repentance, the Merciful.
interpretation: This verse is a supplication to Allah asking to be supported in submitting completely to Him, to have future generations that will also be obedient to Him, to be guided in performing the rituals of worship correctly, and for His acceptance of repentance as He is the Most Merciful and Forgiving.
orig: ربنا واجعلنا مسلمين لك ومن ذريتنا أمة مسلمة لك وأرنا مناسكنا وتب علينا إنك أنت التواب الرحيم

translation: Our Lord, and send among them a messenger from themselves who will recite to them Your verses and teach them the Book and wisdom and purify them. Indeed, You are the Exalted in Might, the Wise."
interpretation: This verse is a supplication to Allah asking for the sending of a messenger from among the people to recite the verses of Allah, teach them the Book and wisdom, and purify them spiritually and morally. It acknowledges the power and wisdom of Allah in fulfilling this request.
orig: ربنا وابعث فيهم رسولا منهم يتلو عليهم آياتك ويعلمهم الكتاب والحكمة ويزكيهم إنك أنت العزيز الحكيم

translation: And who would be averse to the religion of Abraham except one who makes a fool of himself? Indeed, We chose him in this world, and indeed he, in the Hereafter, will be among the righteous.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the significance and righteousness of following the religion of Prophet Abraham. It portrays those who turn away from this path as foolish and misguided. It highlights the special status of Prophet Abraham as chosen by Allah, and assures that in the Hereafter, he will be among the righteous individuals who are rewarded for their faith and obedience.
orig: ومن يرغب عن ملة إبراهيم إلا من سفه نفسه ولقد اصطفيناه في الدنيا وإنه في الآخرة لمن الصالحين

translation: When his Lord said to him, 'Submit', he said, 'I have submitted [in Islam] to the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse captures Prophet Ibrahim's unwavering submission to the will of Allah. It illustrates the model of complete surrender and obedience to the Almighty, acknowledging His supreme authority over everything in the universe. Ibrahim's response exemplifies the essence of Islam, emphasizing the importance of submitting oneself wholeheartedly to the Creator, recognizing His infinite wisdom and power.
orig: إذ قال له ربه أسلم قال أسلمت لرب العالمين

translation: And Abraham instructed his sons [to do the same] and [so did] Jacob, [saying], 'O my sons, indeed Allah has chosen for you this religion; so do not die except while you are Muslims.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of following and adhering to the religion chosen by Allah. It emphasizes the significance of living as a Muslim and staying committed to the faith throughout one's life, even until the moment of death. It serves as a reminder of the importance of maintaining one's connection to Islam and ensuring one's submission to the will of Allah.
orig: ووصى بها إبراهيم بنيه ويعقوب يا بني إن الله اصطفى لكم الدين فلا تموتن إلا وأنتم مسلمون

translation: Or were you witnesses when death approached Jacob, when he said to his sons, 'What will you worship after me?' They said, 'We will worship your God and the God of your fathers, Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac - one God. And we are Muslims [in submission] to Him.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the moment of Jacob's impending death where he questions his sons about their beliefs and who they will worship after him. The sons confirm their commitment to worship the same One God that Jacob and their forefathers, Abraham, Ishmael, and Isaac, worshipped. The verse emphasizes the concept of monotheism and submission to God, highlighting a continuity of faith within the family lineage.
orig: أم كنتم شهداء إذ حضر يعقوب الموت إذ قال لبنيه ما تعبدون من بعدي قالوا نعبد إلهك وإله آبائك إبراهيم وإسماعيل وإسحاق إلها واحدا ونحن له مسلمون

translation: That nation has passed away; for them is what they have earned, and for you is what you have earned. And you will not be questioned about what they used to do.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of individual responsibility and accountability in Islam. Each person is accountable for their own actions and will be rewarded or punished accordingly, regardless of what previous generations have done. It emphasizes the importance of personal conduct and the fact that each individual will be answerable for their own deeds on the Day of Judgment.
orig: تلك أمة قد خلت لها ما كسبت ولكم ما كسبتم ولا تسألون عما كانوا يعملون

translation: And they say, "Be Jews or Christians, you will be guided." Say, "Rather, [we follow] the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth, and he was not of the polytheists."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the monotheistic faith of Prophet Abraham as an example for the believers to follow. It rejects the notion that true guidance can only be found by following a specific religious label like Judaism or Christianity, and instead highlights the importance of pure monotheism and dedication to truth in one's faith.
orig: وقالوا كونوا هودا أو نصارى تهتدوا قل بل ملة إبراهيم حنيفا وما كان من المشركين

translation: Say, "We believe in Allah and what has been revealed to us and what has been revealed to Abraham, Ishmael, Isaac, Jacob, and the Descendants, and in what was given to Moses and Jesus, and to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and we are Muslims [submitting] to Him."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the unity and continuity of the message brought by the various prophets of Allah. It instructs believers to have faith in all the prophets and scriptures, without differentiating between them. Muslims are reminded to submit to Allah's guidance as brought to humanity through these chosen messengers.
orig: قولوا آمنا بالله وما أنزل إلينا وما أنزل إلى إبراهيم وإسماعيل وإسحاق ويعقوب والأسباط وما أوتي موسى وعيسى وما أوتي النبيون من ربهم لا نفرق بين أحد منهم ونحن له مسلمون

translation: If they believe in what you believe, they are indeed on the right path; but if they turn back, they are only in dissension, and Allah will suffice you against them. He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of belief and guidance. It explains that those who share in true belief are on the right path, while those who turn away from it are in disagreement and discord. It reassures that Allah will protect and support the believers against those who oppose them. It also highlights the attributes of Allah as the All-Hearing and the All-Knowing, indicating His complete awareness of all matters and His ability to hear the prayers and needs of His servants.
orig: فإن آمنوا بمثل ما آمنتم به فقد اهتدوا وإن تولوا فإنما هم في شقاق فسيكفيكهم الله وهو السميع العليم

translation: The dye of Allah. And who is better than Allah in dyeing? And we are worshippers of Him.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the color or dyeing by Allah is the best and perfect. It signifies that Allah's attributes and qualities are the utmost and unmatched, and we, as believers, are devoted worshippers of Allah, recognizing His greatness and perfection.
orig: صبغة الله ومن أحسن من الله صبغة ونحن له عابدون

translation: Say, "Do you argue with us about Allah while He is our Lord and your Lord? For us are our deeds, and for you are your deeds. And we are sincere [in deed and intention] to Him."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of sincerity and devotion to Allah. It stresses that every individual is accountable for their own actions and that arguing over matters of faith is unnecessary. It reminds believers to focus on performing righteous deeds sincerely for the sake of Allah, rather than engaging in futile arguments.
orig: قل أتحاجوننا في الله وهو ربنا وربكم ولنا أعمالنا ولكم أعمالكم ونحن له مخلصون

translation: Or do you say that Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants were Jews or Christians? Say, 'Are you more knowing or is Allah?' And who is more unjust than one who conceals a testimony he has from Allah? And Allah is not unaware of what you do.
interpretation: This verse questions the claim of some groups who assert that the great prophets and their descendants belonged to a specific religion such as Judaism or Christianity. It highlights the fact that these prophets were essentially submitting to the will of Allah, unbound by any particular religious label. It emphasizes the importance of truthfulness and integrity in acknowledging the guidance from Allah, and warns against concealing the truth or misinterpreting the messages of the prophets. Ultimately, it asserts that Allah's knowledge surpasses all, and no one can escape accountability for their actions.
orig: أم تقولون إن إبراهيم وإسماعيل وإسحاق ويعقوب والأسباط كانوا هودا أو نصارى قل أأنتم أعلم أم الله ومن أظلم ممن كتم شهادة عنده من الله وما الله بغافل عما تعملون

translation: That is a nation which has passed away. It will have the consequence of what [good] it earned, and you will have what [good] you have earned. And you will not be asked about what they used to do.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes individual accountability and the idea that each person will be responsible for their own actions. It highlights that every individual will be judged based on their own deeds, and not on the deeds of others. It serves as a reminder that everyone is accountable for their choices and actions in this life, and that each person will bear the consequences of their own deeds.
orig: تلك أمة قد خلت لها ما كسبت ولكم ما كسبتم ولا تسألون عما كانوا يعملون

translation: The fools among the people will say, 'What has turned them away from their qiblah, which they used to face?' Say, 'To Allah belongs the east and the west. He guides whom He wills to a straight path.'
interpretation: This verse speaks about how some people may question why the Muslims have changed the direction of their qiblah (prayer direction) from Jerusalem to Mecca. The response in the verse explains that the direction in which one prays is insignificant, as Allah is the Lord of all directions. He has the power to guide anyone He wishes towards the right path, regardless of the physical direction they face in prayer.
orig: سيقول السفهاء من الناس ما ولاهم عن قبلتهم التي كانوا عليها قل لله المشرق والمغرب يهدي من يشاء إلى صراط مستقيم

translation: And thus we have made you a median community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you. And We did not make the qiblah which you used to face except that We might make evident who would follow the Messenger from who would turn back on his heels. And indeed, it is difficult except for those whom Allah has guided. And never would Allah have caused you to lose your faith. Indeed Allah is, to the people, Kind and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the role of the Muslim community as a balanced and just nation that serves as witnesses over people. The Prophet Muhammad serves as a witness over the actions of the Muslim community. The change in the direction of prayer (qiblah) from Jerusalem to Mecca was a test to distinguish the true followers of the Messenger from those who would resist change. Only those whom Allah has guided can navigate through such transitions with faith intact. Allah's mercy ensures that the believers' faith will not be wasted, as He is compassionate and benevolent towards humanity.
orig: وكذلك جعلناكم أمة وسطا لتكونوا شهداء على الناس ويكون الرسول عليكم شهيدا وما جعلنا القبلة التي كنت عليها إلا لنعلم من يتبع الرسول ممن ينقلب على عقبيه وإن كانت لكبيرة إلا على الذين هدى الله وما كان الله ليضيع إيمانكم إن الله بالناس لرءوف رحيم

translation: We see the turning of your face to the heaven (for guidance, O Muhammad). So we shall turn you to a direction that shall please you. Turn then your face towards the Sacred Mosque (Kaaba); and wherever you are, turn your faces towards it (when you pray). And those who have been given the Book know well that this is the truth from their Lord; and God is not unaware of what they do.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of Qiblah (the direction Muslims face during prayer), explaining that the change in direction of the Qiblah from Jerusalem to the Kaaba in Mecca was a matter decreed by Allah to please the Prophet Muhammad. It emphasizes the unity of believers in facing the same direction during prayer and acknowledges the awareness that those who have received previous revelations have about the truth of Islam. Ultimately, it underscores that God is fully aware of the intentions and actions of all individuals.
orig: قد نرى تقلب وجهك في السماء فلنولينك قبلة ترضاها فول وجهك شطر المسجد الحرام وحيث ما كنتم فولوا وجوهكم شطره وإن الذين أوتوا الكتاب ليعلمون أنه الحق من ربهم وما الله بغافل عما يعملون

translation: And if you brought to those who were given the Scripture every sign, they would not follow your qiblah. Nor will you be a follower of their qiblah. Nor would they be followers of one another's qiblah. So if you were to follow their desires after what has come to you of knowledge, indeed, you would then be among the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of holding onto one's beliefs and following the guidance given by Allah, rather than giving in to the desires or expectations of others. It emphasizes that true faith is not about blindly following the beliefs or practices of others, but about sincerely following the knowledge and guidance one has received. It warns against compromising one's beliefs for the sake of pleasing others, as that would lead to injustice and wrongdoing.
orig: ولئن أتيت الذين أوتوا الكتاب بكل آية ما تبعوا قبلتك وما أنت بتابع قبلتهم وما بعضهم بتابع قبلة بعض ولئن اتبعت أهواءهم من بعد ما جاءك من العلم إنك إذا لمن الظالمين

translation: Those to whom We gave the Scripture recognize it as they recognize their [own] sons. But indeed, a party of them conceal the truth while they know [it].
interpretation: This verse highlights how some people, despite having been given knowledge and understanding of the Scripture, choose to conceal the truth for personal reasons. It serves as a reminder that having knowledge alone is not enough; one must also have the sincerity and integrity to act upon that knowledge and uphold the truth.
orig: الذين آتيناهم الكتاب يعرفونه كما يعرفون أبناءهم وإن فريقا منهم ليكتمون الحق وهم يعلمون

translation: The truth is from your Lord, so never be among the doubters.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of recognizing and accepting the truth that comes from Allah without any doubt. It warns against being among those who waver in their beliefs or are skeptical, emphasizing the need for unwavering faith and conviction in the truth revealed by Allah.
orig: الحق من ربك فلا تكونن من الممترين

translation: And for every nation is a [specified] term. So race to [all that is] good. Wherever you may be, Allah will bring you forth [for judgement] all together. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the equality of all people in the eyes of Allah and the importance of striving to do good deeds. It encourages believers to race each other in performing good actions, regardless of their backgrounds or circumstances. It also emphasizes the ultimate accountability to Allah, as he has power and control over all things, and will bring all individuals for judgement on a specified time.
orig: ولكل وجهة هو موليها فاستبقوا الخيرات أين ما تكونوا يأت بكم الله جميعا إن الله على كل شيء قدير

translation: And from wherever you go out [for prayer], turn your face toward al-Masjid al-Haram. And wherever you [believers] may be, turn your faces toward it in order that the people will not have any argument against you, except for those of them who commit wrong; so do not fear them but fear Me. And [it is] so I may complete My favor upon you and that you may be guided.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the significance of facing the direction of the Kaaba (al-Masjid al-Haram) during prayers, no matter where you are. It highlights the unity among believers in worshipping one God and following one qiblah (direction of prayer). It also serves as a reminder to hold steadfast to one's faith and not be swayed by those who question or challenge one's beliefs. By adhering to this practice, believers demonstrate their commitment and obedience to God, seeking His pleasure and guidance.
orig: ومن حيث خرجت فول وجهك شطر المسجد الحرام وإنه للحق من ربك وما الله بغافل عما تعملون

translation: And from wherever you go, turn your face toward al-Masjid al-Haram. And wherever you [believers] are, turn your faces toward it [in prayer] so that people will have no argument against you, except for those of them who commit wrong; so do not fear them but fear Me. And [it is] so I may complete My favor upon you and that you may be guided.
interpretation: This verse is instructing the believers to turn towards the Kaaba in Mecca when they pray, regardless of where they are in the world. It emphasizes the unity of the Muslim community and the importance of worshipping in a uniform manner. By obeying this command, believers are reminded to fear Allah alone and to follow His guidance, in order to receive His blessings and guidance.
orig: ومن حيث خرجت فول وجهك شطر المسجد الحرام وحيث ما كنتم فولوا وجوهكم شطره لئلا يكون للناس عليكم حجة إلا الذين ظلموا منهم فلا تخشوهم واخشوني ولأتم نعمتي عليكم ولعلكم تهتدون

translation: Just as We have sent among you a messenger from yourselves reciting to you Our verses and purifying you and teaching you the Book and wisdom and teaching you that which you did not know.
interpretation: This verse refers to the sending of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a messenger to the people, reciting the verses of the Qur'an, purifying their souls, teaching them the Book (Qur'an) and wisdom, and unveiling knowledge that was previously unknown to them. It emphasizes the role of the Prophet in guiding and educating the believers in matters of faith, morals, and wisdom.
orig: كما أرسلنا فيكم رسولا منكم يتلو عليكم آياتنا ويزكيكم ويعلمكم الكتاب والحكمة ويعلمكم ما لم تكونوا تعلمون

translation: So remember Me; I will remember you. Be grateful to Me and do not deny Me.
interpretation: This verse is a reminder from Allah to remember Him regularly, as doing so will lead to Allah remembering and blessing us in return. It emphasizes being grateful to Allah for His countless blessings and warns against denying His existence or neglecting His remembrance.
orig: فاذكروني أذكركم واشكروا لي ولا تكفرون

translation: O you who have believed, seek help through patience and prayer. Indeed, Allah is with the patient.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of patience and prayer in the life of a believer. It encourages believers to seek help and support from Allah through maintaining patience during challenging times and steadfastly performing prayers. By reminding believers that Allah is with the patient, the verse underscores the significance of perseverance and trust in Allah's ultimate support and guidance.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا استعينوا بالصبر والصلاة إن الله مع الصابرين

translation: And do not say about those who are killed in the way of Allah, 'They are dead.' Rather, they are alive, but you perceive [it] not.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers not to consider those who die in the path of Allah as dead, but rather as alive in a different state. It highlights the spiritual life and eternal reward that those who die in service to Allah attain, emphasizing that their sacrifice is not in vain and they are indeed alive in a more meaningful sense. It also serves as a source of comfort for those who have lost loved ones in the cause of righteousness, reassuring them of the eternal life and reward that awaits believers who are martyred in the way of Allah.
orig: ولا تقولوا لمن يقتل في سبيل الله أموات بل أحياء ولكن لا تشعرون

translation: And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth, lives, and fruits. But give good tidings to the patient.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers that they will face trials and hardships in life which may include fear, hunger, loss of wealth, lives, and fruits. Through these difficulties, Allah tests the patience and endurance of His servants. The verse encourages believers to remain patient and steadfast in the face of adversity, as those who persevere will be rewarded.
orig: ولنبلونكم بشيء من الخوف والجوع ونقص من الأموال والأنفس والثمرات وبشر الصابرين

translation: Those who, when disaster strikes them, say, 'Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of patience and submission to the will of Allah during times of calamity or hardship. It teaches believers to acknowledge that all things ultimately belong to Allah and to accept that they will return to Him in the end. By showing patience and trust in Allah during difficult times, believers strengthen their faith and demonstrate their reliance on Him.
orig: الذين إذا أصابتهم مصيبة قالوا إنا لله وإنا إليه راجعون

translation: Upon those [people] are [the] blessings from their Lord and mercy. And those are the [rightly] guided.
interpretation: This verse highlights that those who follow God's guidance and adhere to His commandments will be recipients of blessings and mercy from their Lord. They are the ones who are truly guided on the right path, leading to fulfillment and success in this life and the hereafter.
orig: أولئك عليهم صلوات من ربهم ورحمة وأولئك هم المهتدون

translation: Indeed, Safa and Marwah are among the symbols of Allah. So whoever makes Hajj to the House or performs 'umrah - there is no blame upon him for walking between them. And whoever volunteers good - then indeed, Allah is appreciative and Knowing.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an emphasizes the significance of Safa and Marwah as symbols of Allah during the pilgrimage. It clarifies that it is permissible for pilgrims and those performing 'umrah to walk between these two hills, showcasing the acceptance and recognition of voluntary good deeds by Allah, who is appreciative and all-knowing.
orig: إن الصفا والمروة من شعائر الله فمن حج البيت أو اعتمر فلا جناح عليه أن يطوف بهما ومن تطوع خيرا فإن الله شاكر عليم

translation: Indeed, those who conceal what We sent down of clear proofs and guidance after We made it clear for the people in the Scripture - those are cursed by Allah and cursed by those who curse,
interpretation: This verse highlights the seriousness of concealing or distorting the messages and guidance revealed by Allah. It emphasizes the importance of conveying the knowledge and guidance of the Quran to others without hiding or altering its meanings. Those who choose to deliberately hide the truth from others will face the curse of Allah and the curse of those who invoke His wrath.
orig: إن الذين يكتمون ما أنزلنا من البينات والهدى من بعد ما بيناه للناس في الكتاب أولئك يلعنهم الله ويلعنهم اللاعنون

translation: Except for those who repent, believe, and do righteousness; for those will enter Paradise and will not be wronged at all.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of sincere repentance, belief in Allah, and righteous actions. Those who engage in these actions will be forgiven and rewarded with entry into Paradise, where they will be justly treated with mercy and compassion, due to the repentance and reform they have shown in their lives.
orig: إلا الذين تابوا وأصلحوا وبينوا فأولئك أتوب عليهم وأنا التواب الرحيم

translation: Indeed, those who disbelieve and die while they are disbelievers - upon them will be the curse of Allah and the angels and the people, all together,
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the consequences of dying in a state of disbelief. It states that those who reject faith and die in a state of disbelief will be cursed by Allah, the angels, and all of humanity. This highlights the gravity and seriousness of denying the truth and turning away from faith.
orig: إن الذين كفروا وماتوا وهم كفار أولئك عليهم لعنة الله والملائكة والناس أجمعين

translation: Abiding eternally therein. The punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be reprieved.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the eternal nature of the punishment for those who are destined for Hell. It conveys the idea that there will be no respite or relief from the punishment they face, and no hope for escape or reprieve. The severity and permanence of this punishment are highlighted to serve as a deterrent and a reminder of the consequences of wrongdoing in the eyes of God.
orig: خالدين فيها لا يخفف عنهم العذاب ولا هم ينظرون

translation: And your god is one God. There is no deity [worthy of worship] except Him, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the oneness of God, highlighting that there is only one true God worthy of worship. He is described as the Most Merciful, the Especially Merciful, highlighting His profound mercy and compassion towards His creations.
orig: وإلهكم إله واحد لا إله إلا هو الرحمن الرحيم

translation: Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth, and the alternation of the night and the day, and the [great] ships which sail through the sea with that which benefits people, and what Allah has sent down from the heavens of rain, giving life thereby to the earth after its lifelessness and dispersing therein every [kind of] moving creature, and [His] manipulation of the winds and the clouds controlled between the heaven and the earth are signs [of God's existence] for a people who use reason.
interpretation: This verse highlights the signs of God's existence and power in the created world. It emphasizes the intricacy and balance in the natural phenomena that benefit and sustain life on earth, such as the alternation of night and day, the sailing of ships in the seas, rain bringing life to the earth, different creatures inhabiting the planet, and the control of winds and clouds. These are mentioned as signs for people who reflect and use their intellect to understand and recognize the greatness and wisdom of God in His creation.
orig: إن في خلق السماوات والأرض واختلاف الليل والنهار والفلك التي تجري في البحر بما ينفع الناس وما أنزل الله من السماء من ماء فأحيا به الأرض بعد موتها وبث فيها من كل دابة وتصريف الرياح والسحاب المسخر بين السماء والأرض لآيات لقوم يعقلون

translation: And there are some people who take others besides Allah as equals to Him. They love them as they should love Allah. But those who believe have greater love for Allah. And if the wrongdoers could see, when they will see the punishment, that all power belongs to Allah and that Allah is severe in punishment.
interpretation: This verse highlights the varying degrees of love and devotion people have towards different entities. Some people mistakenly elevate others to the status of equals with Allah in their love and devotion, while those who truly believe have the highest love for Allah. The verse also warns the wrongdoers of the reality of Allah's power and the severity of His punishment, emphasizing the importance of recognizing and submitting to the ultimate authority of Allah.
orig: ومن الناس من يتخذ من دون الله أندادا يحبونهم كحب الله والذين آمنوا أشد حبا لله ولو يرى الذين ظلموا إذ يرون العذاب أن القوة لله جميعا وأن الله شديد العذاب

translation: When those who followed disown those who followed, and they see the punishment, and all their means are cut off.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of accountability in the Hereafter. It illustrates how on the Day of Judgment, those who misled others will dissociate themselves from their followers in fear of the punishment, knowing that they cannot offer any help or support. It serves as a warning against blindly following others and highlights the responsibility of not leading others astray.
orig: إذ تبرأ الذين اتبعوا من الذين اتبعوا ورأوا العذاب وتقطعت بهم الأسباب

translation: And those who followed will say, 'If only we had another turn [at worldly life] so we could disassociate ourselves from them as they have disassociated themselves from us.' Thus will Allah show them their deeds as regrets upon them. And they are never to emerge from the Fire.
interpretation: This verse showcases a regret felt by the followers of wrongdoers who, upon witnessing the consequences of their deeds, wish they could have another chance at life to dissociate from them. However, they are reminded that their fates are sealed based on their own actions and they shall face the consequences, being unable to escape their fate in the Fire.
orig: وقال الذين اتبعوا لو أن لنا كرة فنتبرأ منهم كما تبرءوا منا كذلك يريهم الله أعمالهم حسرات عليهم وما هم بخارجين من النار

translation: O mankind, eat from whatever is on earth [that is] lawful and good and do not follow the footsteps of Satan. Indeed, he is to you a clear enemy.
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the importance of consuming only that which is permissible (halal) and wholesome. It warns against following the temptations and deceptions of Satan, who is known to lead people astray from the right path. By staying away from what is unlawful and following the guidelines set by Allah, one can protect themselves from falling into sin and being swayed by evil influences.
orig: يا أيها الناس كلوا مما في الأرض حلالا طيبا ولا تتبعوا خطوات الشيطان إنه لكم عدو مبين

translation: He only orders you to evil and immorality and to say about Allah what you do not know.
interpretation: This verse highlights the prohibition against engaging in evil deeds, immorality, and speaking untruthfully about Allah. It serves as a reminder of the importance of avoiding sinful actions and speaking only of matters that one has knowledge about, particularly when it comes to attributing false statements or characteristics to Allah.
orig: إنما يأمركم بالسوء والفحشاء وأن تقولوا على الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: And when it is said to them, "Follow what Allah has revealed," they say, "Rather, we will follow that which we found our fathers doing." Even though their fathers understood nothing, nor were they guided?
interpretation: This verse highlights the refusal of some people to follow the guidance of Allah by sticking blindly to the traditions and practices of their forefathers, even if they were based on ignorance and lacked guidance. It serves as a reminder to prioritize following the divine guidance over blindly following tradition.
orig: وإذا قيل لهم اتبعوا ما أنزل الله قالوا بل نتبع ما ألفينا عليه آباءنا أولو كان آباؤهم لا يعقلون شيئا ولا يهتدون

translation: And the example of those who disbelieve is like that of one who shouts at what hears nothing but calls and cries in ignorance - deaf, dumb, and blind. So they do not understand.
interpretation: This verse compares the disbelievers to someone who cannot comprehend the truth despite being surrounded by it, just like a deaf, dumb, and blind person who is unable to hear, speak, or see. The disbelievers are described as ignorant and lacking understanding, even though the signs and messages of truth are evident to them.
orig: ومثل الذين كفروا كمثل الذي ينعق بما لا يسمع إلا دعاء ونداء صم بكم عمي فهم لا يعقلون

translation: O you who have believed, eat from the good things which We have provided for you and be grateful to Allah if it is [indeed] Him that you worship.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of consuming lawful and good things that are provided by Allah. It encourages believers to be grateful to Allah for the sustenance He provides and to worship Him alone. Gratitude and adherence to lawful provisions are essential aspects of worship in Islam.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا كلوا من طيبات ما رزقناكم واشكروا لله إن كنتم إياه تعبدون

translation: He has only forbidden to you dead animals, blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allah. But whoever is forced [by necessity], neither desiring [it] nor transgressing [its limit], there is no sin upon him. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an outlines the permissible and impermissible foods for Muslims. It prohibits consuming dead animals, blood, pork, and any food that has been dedicated to something other than Allah. However, in cases of necessity where one is compelled to consume forbidden food to avoid harm or death, there is no sin upon them. Allah, in His mercy, understands and forgives such situations.
orig: إنما حرم عليكم الميتة والدم ولحم الخنزير وما أهل به لغير الله فمن اضطر غير باغ ولا عاد فلا إثم عليه إن الله غفور رحيم

translation: Indeed, those who conceal what Allah has sent down of the Book and exchange it for a small price - they eat not into their bellies except the Fire. And Allah will not speak to them on the Day of Resurrection, nor will He purify them. And they will have a painful punishment.
interpretation: This verse highlights the severe consequences for those who hide or distort the teachings of the Qur'an for material gain. It indicates that such individuals will face punishment in the Hereafter, as they will be deprived of Allah's guidance and mercy. It serves as a warning against altering or concealing the divine message for personal benefit.
orig: إن الذين يكتمون ما أنزل الله من الكتاب ويشترون به ثمنا قليلا أولئك ما يأكلون في بطونهم إلا النار ولا يكلمهم الله يوم القيامة ولا يزكيهم ولهم عذاب أليم

translation: Those are the ones who have purchased error [in exchange] for guidance and punishment [in exchange] for forgiveness. How patient they are for the Fire!
interpretation: This verse reflects the severe consequences for those who knowingly choose to deviate from the right path despite being shown guidance, and who choose punishment over seeking forgiveness. It demonstrates the irony of their misguided choices and the upcoming punishment they will face. The verse highlights the importance of staying steadfast on the right path and seeking forgiveness to avoid the punishment mentioned.
orig: أولئك الذين اشتروا الضلالة بالهدى والعذاب بالمغفرة فما أصبرهم على النار

translation: That is because Allah has sent down the Book in truth. And indeed, those who differ over the Book are in extreme dissension.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of the Qur'an being revealed by Allah as a source of truth. It also warns against those who engage in disagreements and disputes over the Book, emphasizing that such actions lead to extreme divisions and discord among people.
orig: ذلك بأن الله نزل الكتاب بالحق وإن الذين اختلفوا في الكتاب لفي شقاق بعيد

translation: Righteousness is not that you turn your faces toward the east or the west, but [true] righteousness is [in] one who believes in Allah, the Last Day, the angels, the Book, and the prophets and gives wealth, in spite of love for it, to relatives, orphans, the needy, the traveler, those who ask [for help], and for freeing slaves; [and who] establishes prayer and gives zakah; [those who] fulfill their promise when they promise; and [those who] are patient in poverty and hardship and during battle. Those are the ones who have been true, and it is those who are the righteous.
interpretation: The verse emphasizes that true righteousness is not simply about performing superficial acts such as turning one's face in a certain direction, but rather it lies in genuine faith in Allah, belief in the Last Day, respect for the angels, the Book, and the prophets, and in living a life of moral and ethical values. It discusses the importance of various acts of charity, prayer, fulfilling one's commitments, and demonstrating patience in times of adversity. The verse presents a comprehensive picture of righteousness and highlights the virtues that true believers should embody in their lives.
orig: ليس البر أن تولوا وجوهكم قبل المشرق والمغرب ولكن البر من آمن بالله واليوم الآخر والملائكة والكتاب والنبيين وآتى المال على حبه ذوي القربى واليتامى والمساكين وابن السبيل والسائلين وفي الرقاب وأقام الصلاة وآتى الزكاة والموفون بعهدهم إذا عاهدوا والصابرين في البأساء والضراء وحين البأس أولئك الذين صدقوا وأولئك هم المتقون

translation: O you who have believed, prescribed for you is legal retribution for those murdered - the free for the free, the slave for the slave, and the female for the female. But whoever overlooks from his brother anything, then there should be a suitable follow-up and payment to him with good conduct. This is an alleviation from your Lord and a mercy. But whoever transgresses after that will have a painful punishment.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the principle of legal retribution for murder in Islamic law, stating that the punishment should be equal to the crime committed. However, it also permits forgiveness and reconciliation, urging for kindness and good treatment even in the face of a severe offense. It serves as a reminder of the importance of mercy and compassion, but also warns of a severe punishment for those who continue to transgress the moral boundaries.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا كتب عليكم القصاص في القتلى الحر بالحر والعبد بالعبد والأنثى بالأنثى فمن عفي له من أخيه شيء فاتباع بالمعروف وأداء إليه بإحسان ذلك تخفيف من ربكم ورحمة فمن اعتدى بعد ذلك فله عذاب أليم

translation: And there is life for you in qisas (the law of equality in punishment), O people of understanding, that you may become righteous.
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the importance of the law of equality in punishment (qisas) as a means to ensure justice and maintain peace in society. It is addressing those who possess understanding and insight, urging them to contemplate the significance of this law and its role in promoting righteousness and order. By upholding the principle of qisas, individuals can achieve a deeper level of piety and righteousness that is essential for a harmonious and just society.
orig: ولكم في القصاص حياة يا أولي الألباب لعلكم تتقون

translation: It is ordained for you, when death approaches any of you, if he leaves behind some wealth, to make a bequest to parents and next of kin, according to reasonable usage. This is due from the God-fearing.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the importance of making a will (wasiya) when death approaches, especially if there are assets involved. The will should include provisions for parents and close relatives, in accordance with what is fair and just. This obligation is emphasized for those who are conscious of God and strive to be righteous.
orig: كتب عليكم إذا حضر أحدكم الموت إن ترك خيرا الوصية للوالدين والأقربين بالمعروف حقا على المتقين

translation: So whoever replaces it after he has heard it - the sin is only upon those who replace it. Indeed, Allah is Hearing and Knowing.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of adhering to the teachings of the Qur'an once they have been heard and understood. Those who knowingly distort or change the message of the Qur'an will bear the consequences of their actions, as they are accountable to Allah, who hears and knows all things.
orig: فمن بدله بعدما سمعه فإنما إثمه على الذين يبدلونه إن الله سميع عليم

translation: So whoever fears from a believer danger of bias or sin, then makes reconciliation between them, there is no sin upon him indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of resolving conflicts between believers. It teaches that if someone fears that biases or sins may arise between believers, they should work towards reconciliation. By doing so, they will not be considered sinful. This highlights the importance of maintaining unity and harmony within the community of believers, with a reminder that Allah is Forgiving and Merciful towards those who seek peace and reconciliation.
orig: فمن خاف من موص جنفا أو إثما فأصلح بينهم فلا إثم عليه إن الله غفور رحيم

translation: O you who have believed, decreed upon you is fasting as it was decreed upon those before you that you may become righteous.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an emphasizes the importance of fasting during the month of Ramadan for Muslims. It reminds the believers that fasting is not a new obligation but was also prescribed for earlier generations. By observing fasting, Muslims can attain righteousness and gain taqwa (God-consciousness). Fasting serves as a means to cultivate piety, self-discipline, and spiritual growth.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا كتب عليكم الصيام كما كتب على الذين من قبلكم لعلكم تتقون

translation: Prescribed for you when the days are numbered. And whoever among you is ill or on a journey [during them] - then an equal number of days [are to be made up]. And upon those who are able [to fast, but with hardship] - a ransom [as substitute] of feeding a poor person [each day]. And whoever volunteers good - it is better for him. But to fast is best for you, if you only knew.
interpretation: This verse addresses the regulations around fasting in Islam during the days of Ramadan. It allows flexibility for those who are ill or traveling to make up for missed days after Ramadan. Additionally, it offers the option of providing food for a poor person as a substitute for fasting if one is genuinely unable to fast. However, it is considered better to fast if one is capable. The verse emphasizes the benefits of voluntary good deeds and fasting for the individual, highlighting their importance in Islam.
orig: أياما معدودات فمن كان منكم مريضا أو على سفر فعدة من أيام أخر وعلى الذين يطيقونه فدية طعام مسكين فمن تطوع خيرا فهو خير له وأن تصوموا خير لكم إن كنتم تعلمون

translation: The month of Ramadhan [is that] in which was revealed the Qur'an, a guidance for the people and clear proofs of guidance and criterion. So whoever sights [the new moon of] the month, let him fast it; and whoever is ill or on a journey – then an equal number of days [are to be made up]. Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship and [wants] for you to complete the period and to glorify Allah for that [to] which He has guided you, and perhaps you will be grateful.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an emphasizes the significance of the month of Ramadhan, highlighting it as a time when the Qur'an was revealed as a source of guidance and a criterion for distinguishing right from wrong. Fasting during this month is obligatory for those who are able, but there are exemptions for the ill and travelers. The verse conveys that Allah intends ease for His followers and emphasizes gratitude and glorification of Him for the guidance provided. It encourages believers to complete the fasting period and be grateful for the opportunity to draw closer to Allah.
orig: شهر رمضان الذي أنزل فيه القرآن هدى للناس وبينات من الهدى والفرقان فمن شهد منكم الشهر فليصمه ومن كان مريضا أو على سفر فعدة من أيام أخر يريد الله بكم اليسر ولا يريد بكم العسر ولتكملوا العدة ولتكبروا الله على ما هداكم ولعلكم تشكرون

translation: And when My servants ask you concerning Me, indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me. So let them respond to Me [by obedience] and believe in Me that they may be [rightly] guided.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the nearness of Allah to His servants and His readiness to respond when they call upon Him. It encourages believers to turn to Allah in supplication, obedience, and belief in order to be guided towards righteousness and truth.
orig: وإذا سألك عبادي عني فإني قريب أجيب دعوة الداع إذا دعان فليستجيبوا لي وليؤمنوا بي لعلهم يرشدون

translation: It has been made permissible for you the night preceding fasting to go to your wives [for sexual relations]. They are clothing for you and you are clothing for them. Allah knows that you used to deceive yourselves, so He accepted your repentance and forgave you. So now, have relations with them and seek that which Allah has decreed for you. And eat and drink until the white thread of dawn becomes distinct to you from the black thread [of night]. Then complete the fast until the night. And do not have relations with them as long as you are staying for worship in the mosques. These are the limits [set by] Allah, so do not approach them. Thus does Allah make clear His ordinances to the people that they may become righteous.
interpretation: This verse discusses the permissibility of having sexual relations with one's spouse during the night before fasting commences. It highlights the concept of marital intimacy as being a source of comfort and closeness between spouses. It also emphasizes the importance of following the prescribed limits and guidelines set by Allah, including the fasting hours and the restrictions during the fasting period. The verse also underscores the need for repentance and seeking forgiveness for past mistakes, as well as the importance of maintaining righteousness through adherence to Allah's decrees.
orig: أحل لكم ليلة الصيام الرفث إلى نسائكم هن لباس لكم وأنتم لباس لهن علم الله أنكم كنتم تختانون أنفسكم فتاب عليكم وعفا عنكم فالآن باشروهن وابتغوا ما كتب الله لكم وكلوا واشربوا حتى يتبين لكم الخيط الأبيض من الخيط الأسود من الفجر ثم أتموا الصيام إلى الليل ولا تباشروهن وأنتم عاكفون في المساجد تلك حدود الله فلا تقربوها كذلك يبين الله آياته للناس لعلهم يتقون

translation: And do not consume one another's wealth unjustly or send it [in bribery] to the rulers in order that [they might aid] you [to] consume a portion of the wealth of the people in sin, while you know [it is unlawful].
interpretation: This verse prohibits the unjust consumption of others' wealth or using it for bribery to gain favors from rulers, knowing that it is sinful and unethical. It condemns the abuse of power and corruption that harm the community's wealth and well-being.
orig: ولا تأكلوا أموالكم بينكم بالباطل وتدلوا بها إلى الحكام لتأكلوا فريقا من أموال الناس بالإثم وأنتم تعلمون

translation: They ask you about the new moons. Say, they are measures of time for the people and for Hajj. It is not righteousness to enter houses from the back, but righteousness is [in] one who fears Allah. And enter houses from their doors. And fear Allah that you may succeed.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of the new moons as a means for measuring time and determining the timing of Hajj. It also places importance on righteousness and piety towards Allah, rather than mere external acts such as entering houses from the back. The instruction to enter houses from their doors serves as a metaphor for approaching matters in the prescribed manner and avoiding shortcuts in righteousness. The verse ultimately reminds believers to fear Allah in all their actions, which is the key to success and prosperity.
orig: يسألونك عن الأهلة قل هي مواقيت للناس والحج وليس البر بأن تأتوا البيوت من ظهورها ولكن البر من اتقى وأتوا البيوت من أبوابها واتقوا الله لعلكم تفلحون

translation: And fight in the cause of Allah those who fight you, but do not transgress. Indeed, Allah does not like transgressors.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of self-defense and fighting only those who are engaged in combat against you. It prohibits exceeding the limits of self-defense and aggression, reminding believers that Allah does not approve of those who transgress the boundaries of justice and fairness.
orig: وقاتلوا في سبيل الله الذين يقاتلونكم ولا تعتدوا إن الله لا يحب المعتدين

translation: And kill them wherever you overtake them and expel them from wherever they have expelled you, and fitnah is worse than killing. And do not fight them at al-Masjid al-Haram until they fight you there. But if they fight you, then kill them. Such is the recompense of the disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse speaks about the permission to fight in self-defense and against oppression. It emphasizes the principle of retaliation and self-defense in the face of aggression. However, it also highlights the importance of avoiding transgression in warfare, such as not starting the conflict at places of sanctity or worship unless provoked. The ultimate aim is to establish justice and protect the believers from harm.
orig: واقتلوهم حيث ثقفتموهم وأخرجوهم من حيث أخرجوكم والفتنة أشد من القتل ولا تقاتلوهم عند المسجد الحرام حتى يقاتلوكم فيه فإن قاتلوكم فاقتلوهم كذلك جزاء الكافرين

translation: If they desist, then indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the forgiving and merciful nature of Allah. It emphasizes that if individuals stop their wrongdoing and turn back to Allah, He is ready to forgive them and show mercy. It serves as a reminder of the endless compassion of Allah towards His creation and encourages repentance and seeking forgiveness.
orig: فإن انتهوا فإن الله غفور رحيم

translation: And fight them until there is no Fitnah and [until] the religion, all of it, is for Allah. And if they cease - then indeed, Allah is Seeing of what they do.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of fighting in the cause of Allah until there is no more sedition and all worship and adherence is dedicated to Allah alone. However, the verse also indicates that if the enemy ceases their aggression, then there should be no hostility towards them, except for those who oppress or commit wrongdoing.
orig: وقاتلوهم حتى لا تكون فتنة ويكون الدين لله فإن انتهوا فلا عدوان إلا على الظالمين

translation: The sacred month for the sacred month, and for the prohibited things, there is the law of equality (Qisas). So, if anyone transgresses against you, transgress against him in the same manner as he transgressed against you. And fear Allah, and know that Allah is with those who fear Him.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the principle of reciprocity and justice in dealing with transgressions committed during the sacred months. It instructs believers to retaliate in a manner proportionate to the wrongdoing, while also reminding them to act with God-consciousness (taqwa) as Allah is supportive of those who exhibit piety and righteousness.
orig: الشهر الحرام بالشهر الحرام والحرمات قصاص فمن اعتدى عليكم فاعتدوا عليه بمثل ما اعتدى عليكم واتقوا الله واعلموا أن الله مع المتقين

translation: And spend in the way of Allah and do not throw [yourselves] with your [own] hands into destruction [by refraining]. And do good; indeed, Allah loves the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of spending wealth in the way of Allah, but with wisdom and moderation. It warns against reckless spending or wasting resources that could lead to one's own destruction or harm. Additionally, the verse encourages performing good deeds and acts of kindness, as it is a quality beloved by Allah.
orig: وأنفقوا في سبيل الله ولا تلقوا بأيديكم إلى التهلكة وأحسنوا إن الله يحب المحسنين

translation: And complete the Hajj and Umrah for Allah. But if you are prevented, then [offer] what can be obtained with ease of sacrificial animals. And do not shave your heads until the sacrificial animal has reached its place of slaughter. And whoever among you is ill or has an ailment of the head [making shaving necessary must offer] a ransom of fasting three days or charity or sacrifice. And when you are secure, then whoever performs 'Umrah [during the Hajj months] followed by Hajj [offers] what can be obtained with ease of sacrificial animals. And whoever cannot find [or afford such an animal], then a fast of three days during Hajj and of seven when you have returned [home]. Those are ten complete [days]. This is for those whose family is not in the area of al-Masjid al-Haram. And fear Allah and know that Allah is severe in penalty.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an emphasizes the completion of the Hajj and Umrah rituals for the sake of Allah. It specifies the actions to take if one is prevented from completing the rituals fully, such as offering a ransom instead of shaving the head if one is ill or has an ailment. It also provides alternatives for those who cannot afford the sacrificial animal, highlighting the importance of completing the prescribed rituals with sincerity and piety. The verse also serves as a reminder of the severity of Allah's punishment and the need for consciousness and piety in all actions.
orig: وأتموا الحج والعمرة لله فإن أحصرتم فما استيسر من الهدي ولا تحلقوا رءوسكم حتى يبلغ الهدي محله فمن كان منكم مريضا أو به أذى من رأسه ففدية من صيام أو صدقة أو نسك فإذا أمنتم فمن تمتع بالعمرة إلى الحج فما استيسر من الهدي فمن لم يجد فصيام ثلاثة أيام في الحج وسبعة إذا رجعتم تلك عشرة كاملة ذلك لمن لم يكن أهله حاضري المسجد الحرام واتقوا الله واعلموا أن الله شديد العقاب

translation: The Hajj is [during] well-known months, so whoever has made Hajj obligatory upon himself therein [by entering the state of ihram], there is [to be for him] no sexual relations and no disobedience and no disputing during Hajj. And whatever good you do - Allah knows it. And take provision, but indeed, the best provision is Taqwa (piety). So fear Me, O you of understanding.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of observing righteousness and piety during the pilgrimage (Hajj). Believers are reminded to avoid any misconduct, such as sexual relations, disobedience, or arguments, during this sacred journey. The verse also stresses that Allah is aware of all the good deeds done by individuals. Additionally, it highlights the significance of having Taqwa (God-consciousness) as the best provision for the journey of life, urging people of understanding to fear and be mindful of Allah.
orig: الحج أشهر معلومات فمن فرض فيهن الحج فلا رفث ولا فسوق ولا جدال في الحج وما تفعلوا من خير يعلمه الله وتزودوا فإن خير الزاد التقوى واتقون يا أولي الألباب

translation: There is no blame upon you for seeking bounty from your Lord. But when you depart from 'Arafat, remember Allah at al-Mash'ar al-Haram. And remember Him, as He has guided you, for indeed, you were before that among those astray.
interpretation: This verse highlights the permission for believers to seek blessings and bounty from their Lord. It also emphasizes the importance of remembering Allah at sacred locations during religious rituals, such as 'Arafat and Al-Mash'ar Al-Haram. The verse serves as a reminder to show gratitude for Allah's guidance and to reflect on one's former state of being astray before receiving His guidance.
orig: ليس عليكم جناح أن تبتغوا فضلا من ربكم فإذا أفضتم من عرفات فاذكروا الله عند المشعر الحرام واذكروه كما هداكم وإن كنتم من قبله لمن الضالين

translation: Then depart from the place from where [all] the people depart and ask forgiveness of Allah. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of seeking forgiveness from Allah. It advises believers to ask for forgiveness wherever people seek forgiveness and to not be neglectful in seeking repentance. It also highlights the mercy and forgiveness of Allah, encouraging believers to humble themselves and seek His forgiveness with sincerity and devotion.
orig: ثم أفيضوا من حيث أفاض الناس واستغفروا الله إن الله غفور رحيم

translation: So when you have completed your rites, remember Allah as you remember your fathers or with [much] greater remembrance. But among the people is he who says, 'Our Lord, give us in this world,' and he will have in the Hereafter no share.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers to remember Allah after completing their rituals with the same or even greater devotion than they remember their forefathers. It also warns against those who only seek worldly gains and neglect the Hereafter, emphasizing the importance of seeking rewards in both this world and the next.
orig: فإذا قضيتم مناسككم فاذكروا الله كذكركم آباءكم أو أشد ذكرا فمن الناس من يقول ربنا آتنا في الدنيا وما له في الآخرة من خلاق

translation: And among them are those who say, "Our Lord, give us in this world [that which is] good and in the Hereafter [that which is] good and protect us from the punishment of the Fire."
interpretation: This verse highlights the balanced and holistic supplication of believers, seeking the goodness of both this world and the Hereafter. It shows the importance of maintaining a focus on seeking goodness in both aspects of life, along with seeking protection from the punishment of Hellfire.
orig: ومنهم من يقول ربنا آتنا في الدنيا حسنة وفي الآخرة حسنة وقنا عذاب النار

translation: For those is a share of what they have earned, and Allah is swift in account.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the accountability of one's actions before Allah. It reassures that individuals will receive what they deserve based on their deeds, whether good or bad, as Allah is quick in His judgment and reckoning. It serves as a reminder of the importance of being conscious of our choices and actions as they will have consequences in the hereafter.
orig: أولئك لهم نصيب مما كسبوا والله سريع الحساب

translation: And remember Allah during [specific] numbered days. Then whoever hastens [his departure] in two days - there is no sin upon him; and whoever delays [until the third] - there is no sin upon him, for him who fears Allah. And fear Allah and know that unto Him you will be gathered.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of remembering Allah during specific days and highlights the idea of moderation and flexibility in worship. It teaches that there is no sin for those who hasten their actions or those who take more time, as long as they maintain piety and consciousness of Allah. It serves as a reminder to fear Allah and reflects on the inevitability of being gathered before Him for judgment.
orig: واذكروا الله في أيام معدودات فمن تعجل في يومين فلا إثم عليه ومن تأخر فلا إثم عليه لمن اتقى واتقوا الله واعلموا أنكم إليه تحشرون

translation: And of the people is he whose speech pleases you in worldly life, and he calls Allah to witness as to what is in his heart, yet he is the fiercest of opponents.
interpretation: This verse warns against hypocritical behavior where someone may appear pious and pleasing in speech but harbors ill intentions and hostility in their heart. It serves as a reminder to be cautious of people who may not show their true nature and intentions, as their actions may contradict their words.
orig: ومن الناس من يعجبك قوله في الحياة الدنيا ويشهد الله على ما في قلبه وهو ألد الخصام

translation: And when he goes away, he strives throughout the land to cause corruption therein and destroy crops and animals. And Allah does not like corruption.
interpretation: This verse highlights the destructive nature of those who spread corruption and mischief in the land. It warns against individuals who actively work to undermine peace, harmony, and prosperity, leading to harm and devastation for livelihoods and future generations. The verse emphasizes that such actions are displeasing to Allah, who values righteousness and goodness. It serves as a reminder to strive for positive and constructive behavior, promoting justice, decency, and overall well-being in society.
orig: وإذا تولى سعى في الأرض ليفسد فيها ويهلك الحرث والنسل والله لا يحب الفساد

translation: And when it is said to him, "Fear Allah," pride in the sin takes hold of him. Sufficient for him is Hellfire, and how wretched is the resting place.
interpretation: This verse warns against arrogance and stubbornness when one is advised to be mindful of Allah. It describes how some individuals, upon being reminded of God-consciousness, react with defiance and arrogance, leading to their own downfall. The verse emphasizes the consequences of this attitude, highlighting the eventual punishment in Hellfire and the severity of that outcome.
orig: وإذا قيل له اتق الله أخذته العزة بالإثم فحسبه جهنم ولبئس المهاد

translation: And of the people is he who sells himself, seeking means to the approval of Allah. And Allah is kind to His servants.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of self-sacrifice for the sake of Allah, where a person willingly gives up their desires and comforts in order to seek the pleasure and approval of Allah. It emphasizes the importance of putting Allah's satisfaction above personal gain, and reassures believers that Allah is compassionate and merciful towards His worshippers.
orig: ومن الناس من يشري نفسه ابتغاء مرضات الله والله رءوف بالعباد

translation: O you who have believed, enter into Islam completely [and perfectly] and do not follow the footsteps of Satan. Indeed, he is to you a clear enemy.
interpretation: This verse urges the believers to fully embrace Islam and practice it wholeheartedly without any compromise. It warns against following the temptations and deceptions of Satan, who is a clear enemy of humanity. The believers are advised to be vigilant and constantly seek refuge in Allah from Satan's whispers and influences.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا ادخلوا في السلم كافة ولا تتبعوا خطوات الشيطان إنه لكم عدو مبين

translation: So if you deviate after clear proofs have come to you, then know that Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of holding steadfast to the guidance provided by Allah and the clear signs He sends. It warns against deviating from the right path after receiving such clear guidance, reminding that Allah is All-Powerful and All-Wise. Therefore, it is crucial for believers to remain firm in their faith and not be swayed by doubts or temptations.
orig: فإن زللتم من بعد ما جاءتكم البينات فاعلموا أن الله عزيز حكيم

translation: Do they await but that Allah should come to them in covers of clouds and the angels [as well] and the matter is [then] decided? And to Allah [all] matters are returned.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the power and authority of Allah, indicating that the people who are waiting for a sign or a manifestation of His power should realize that His judgment will come when they least expect it. It reminds believers that ultimately all matters are decided by Allah and return to Him for final judgment.
orig: هل ينظرون إلا أن يأتيهم الله في ظلل من الغمام والملائكة وقضي الأمر وإلى الله ترجع الأمور

translation: Ask the Children of Israel how many clear signs We have given them. And whoever exchanges the blessing of God after it has come to him - then indeed, God is severe in penalty.
interpretation: This verse serves as a reminder to the Children of Israel, emphasizing the numerous clear signs and blessings that God has bestowed upon them. It warns against ingratitude and the rejection of God's blessings, indicating that those who disregard His favors may face severe consequences. The message underscores the importance of recognizing and appreciating God's blessings and adhering to His guidance.
orig: سل بني إسرائيل كم آتيناهم من آية بينة ومن يبدل نعمة الله من بعد ما جاءته فإن الله شديد العقاب

translation: Beautiful for those who disbelieve is the worldly life, and they ridicule those who believe. But those who fear Allah are above them on the Day of Resurrection. And Allah gives provision to whom He wills without measure.
interpretation: This verse highlights the contrast between the disbelievers who prioritize the material pleasures of this worldly life and mock the believers, and the believers who fear Allah and exhibit patience and faith despite ridicule and hardship. It also emphasizes that on the Day of Judgment, those who remained obedient and God-conscious will be elevated above the disbelievers. Furthermore, the verse reminds that it is Allah who provides sustenance abundantly and without limits to whomever He wishes, serving as a reminder that ultimate provision comes from Him alone and is not tied to worldly measures of success.
orig: زين للذين كفروا الحياة الدنيا ويسخرون من الذين آمنوا والذين اتقوا فوقهم يوم القيامة والله يرزق من يشاء بغير حساب

translation: Mankind was [of] one religion [before their deviation]; then Allah sent the prophets as bringers of good tidings and warners and sent down with them the Scripture in truth to judge between the people concerning that in which they differed. And none differed over the Scripture except those who were given it—after the clear proofs came to them—out of jealous animosity among themselves. And Allah guided those who believed to the truth concerning that over which they had differed, by His permission. And Allah guides whom He wills to a straight path.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of monotheism and the original unity of mankind in faith before deviating. It explains how Allah sent prophets with scriptures to guide people and settle disputes among them. The verse emphasizes that those who differ on the scripture do so out of envy and Allah guides the believers to the truth through His will. It stresses the importance of divine guidance and the sovereignty of Allah in leading those who believe towards the straight path.
orig: كان الناس أمة واحدة فبعث الله النبيين مبشرين ومنذرين وأنزل معهم الكتاب بالحق ليحكم بين الناس فيما اختلفوا فيه وما اختلف فيه إلا الذين أوتوه من بعد ما جاءتهم البينات بغيا بينهم فهدى الله الذين آمنوا لما اختلفوا فيه من الحق بإذنه والله يهدي من يشاء إلى صراط مستقيم

translation: Or do you think that you will enter Paradise while such [trial] has not yet come to you as came to those who passed on before you? They were touched by poverty and hardship and were shaken until [even their] messenger and those who believed with him said, 'When is the help of Allah?' Unquestionably, the help of Allah is near.
interpretation: This verse serves as a reminder to believers that entering Paradise requires steadfastness and perseverance through trials and hardships. It highlights that facing difficulties is part of the path to Paradise, as seen in the struggles of those before us. The verse encourages patience and faith in Allah's support, assuring that Allah's help is close at hand for those who remain steadfast in their belief and trust in Him.
orig: أم حسبتم أن تدخلوا الجنة ولما يأتكم مثل الذين خلوا من قبلكم مستهم البأساء والضراء وزلزلوا حتى يقول الرسول والذين آمنوا معه متى نصر الله ألا إن نصر الله قريب

translation: They ask you, [O Muhammad], what they should spend. Say, "Whatever wealth you spend is for parents and relatives and orphans and the needy and the traveler. And whatever you do of good - indeed, Allah is Knowing of it."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of giving in charity and spending wealth for the betterment of society. It specifies that such spending should be directed towards various categories including parents, relatives, orphans, the needy, and travelers. It also highlights that any act of kindness or charity will be recognized and rewarded by Allah, as He is All-Knowing of our intentions and deeds.
orig: يسألونك ماذا ينفقون قل ما أنفقتم من خير فللوالدين والأقربين واليتامى والمساكين وابن السبيل وما تفعلوا من خير فإن الله به عليم

translation: Fighting has been prescribed upon you while it is hateful to you; but perhaps you hate a thing and it is good for you, and perhaps you love a thing and it is bad for you. And Allah knows, while you know not.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers that sometimes they may dislike something which is actually good for them, or they may like something which is actually harmful. It emphasizes the importance of trusting in Allah's wisdom and knowledge, even when we may not understand the reasons behind certain commandments or events in our lives.
orig: كتب عليكم القتال وهو كره لكم وعسى أن تكرهوا شيئا وهو خير لكم وعسى أن تحبوا شيئا وهو شر لكم والله يعلم وأنتم لا تعلمون

translation: They ask you about the sacred month - about fighting therein. Say, 'Fighting therein is great [sin], but averting [people] from the way of Allah and disbelief in Him and [preventing access to] the Sacred Mosque and the expulsion of its people therefrom are greater [evil] in the sight of Allah. And fitnah is greater than killing.' And they will continue to fight you until they turn you back from your religion if they are able. And whoever of you reverts from his religion [to disbelief] and dies while he is a disbeliever - for those, their deeds have become worthless in this world and the Hereafter, and those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: This verse addresses the question regarding fighting in the sacred month. It clarifies that while fighting during this period is a serious transgression, the greater sins are to obstruct people from the path of Allah, disbelieve in Him, prevent access to the Sacred Mosque, and forcibly expel its inhabitants. It emphasizes that creating discord and chaos (fitnah) is even more serious than killing. The verse also warns that the opponents of the believers will persist in their hostility until they manage to turn them away from their faith.
