orig: قال فبما أغويتني لأقعدن لهم صراطك المستقيم

translation: Then We will come to them from before them and from behind them and on their right and on their left, and You will not find most of them grateful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of Allah's knowledge and power. It illustrates that no matter how we try to escape or hide from the consequences of our actions, ultimately, we will be held accountable. The lack of gratitude among many people is highlighted here, drawing attention to the importance of being appreciative of Allah's blessings and guidance.
orig: ثم لآتينهم من بين أيديهم ومن خلفهم وعن أيمانهم وعن شمائلهم ولا تجد أكثرهم شاكرين

translation: He (God) will say, 'Depart therein in disgrace and do not speak to Me! Indeed, among My servants is the one who says, Our Lord, we have believed, so forgive us and have mercy upon us, and You are the best of the merciful.'
interpretation: In this verse, God is conveying that those who followed the wrong path will be told to depart and are doomed to disgrace. However, a group of believers also seek forgiveness from God, acknowledging their faith and seeking His mercy. This verse emphasizes the importance of repentance and seeking God's mercy and forgiveness, even in the face of difficulty and punishment.
orig: قال اخرج منها مذءوما مدحورا لمن تبعك منهم لأملأن جهنم منكم أجمعين

translation: And O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise and eat therefrom in [ease and] abundance from wherever you will. But do not approach this tree, lest you be among the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse is a reminder to Adam and his wife of the blessings of Paradise and the freedom they have to enjoy its provisions except for one restriction. It emphasizes the importance of following the commandments of Allah and refraining from what has been prohibited, as disobedience would lead them to be among the wrongdoers.
orig: ويا آدم اسكن أنت وزوجك الجنة فكلا من حيث شئتما ولا تقربا هذه الشجرة فتكونا من الظالمين

translation: But Satan whispered to them to make apparent to them that which was concealed from them of their private parts. He said, "Your Lord did not forbid you this tree except that you become angels or become of the immortal."
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an refers to the story of Adam and Eve being tempted by Satan to eat from the forbidden tree. Satan tries to manipulate them by suggesting that if they were to eat from the tree, they would become angels or immortal. The verse serves as a reminder of the deceptive nature of evil and the importance of following the guidance of Allah.
orig: فوسوس لهما الشيطان ليبدي لهما ما ووري عنهما من سوآتهما وقال ما نهاكما ربكما عن هذه الشجرة إلا أن تكونا ملكين أو تكونا من الخالدين

translation: And he swore [by Allah] to both [of them], 'Indeed, I am to you from among the sincere advisors.'
interpretation: This verse refers to Prophet Hud's warning to his people, the people of 'Aad, about their sins and the consequences they will face if they do not repent. It serves as a reminder that prophets are sincere in advising their people, and their warnings come from a place of genuine concern for their well-being and guidance.
orig: وقاسمهما إني لكما لمن الناصحين

translation: So he made them fall, through deception. And when they tasted the tree, their private parts became apparent to them, and they began to fasten together over themselves from the leaves of Paradise. And their Lord called out to them, 'Did I not forbid you from that tree and tell you that Satan is to you a clear enemy?'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an is recounting the story of Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden. It highlights the consequences of their disobedience to God's command not to eat from a specific tree. The verse serves as a lesson on the deceptive nature of Satan and the importance of following God's guidance to avoid falling into temptation and sin.
orig: فدلاهما بغرور فلما ذاقا الشجرة بدت لهما سوآتهما وطفقا يخصفان عليهما من ورق الجنة وناداهما ربهما ألم أنهكما عن تلكما الشجرة وأقل لكما إن الشيطان لكما عدو مبين

translation: They said, 'Our Lord, we have wronged ourselves, and if You do not forgive us and have mercy upon us, we will surely be among the losers.'
interpretation: This verse reflects the humility and repentance of believers who acknowledge their mistakes and seek forgiveness and mercy from Allah. It emphasizes the importance of seeking forgiveness and mercy from Allah to avoid being among the losers in the Hereafter.
orig: قالا ربنا ظلمنا أنفسنا وإن لم تغفر لنا وترحمنا لنكونن من الخاسرين

translation: He said, 'Descend, being to one another enemies. And for you on the earth is a place of settlement and enjoyment for a time.'
interpretation: This verse describes the disagreement between Adam and Satan, symbolizing the ongoing struggle between good and evil. It emphasizes the temporary nature of worldly life, where individuals may have conflicts and differing interests, but ultimately they all have a place to stay on earth and enjoy its provisions until a designated time.
orig: قال اهبطوا بعضكم لبعض عدو ولكم في الأرض مستقر ومتاع إلى حين

translation: Saying, 'In it you will live, and in it you will die, and from it you will be brought forth.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the cycle of life and death that is part of the natural order decreed by Allah. It serves as a reminder that humans are created from the earth, live their lives on earth, and will eventually return to the earth after death, only to be resurrected on the Day of Judgment.
orig: قال فيها تحيون وفيها تموتون ومنها تخرجون

translation: O children of Adam, We have bestowed upon you clothing to conceal your private parts and as adornment. But the clothing of righteousness - that is best. That is from the signs of Allah that perhaps they will remember.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of modesty and righteousness in behavior and appearance. It highlights that while physical clothing is necessary to cover one's body, the true adornment lies in righteousness and good deeds. It reminds believers that displaying righteousness in their actions is a greater sign of faith and awareness of God's teachings.
orig: يا بني آدم قد أنزلنا عليكم لباسا يواري سوآتكم وريشا ولباس التقوى ذلك خير ذلك من آيات الله لعلهم يذكرون

translation: O Children of Adam! Let not Satan deceive you as he removed your parents from Paradise, stripping them of their clothing to show them their private parts. Verily, he and his tribe watch you from where you cannot see them. We have made the devils allies of those who do not believe.
interpretation: This verse serves as a warning to all humanity, reminding them not to be deceived by Satan as he deceived Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden. It cautions believers against falling prey to the tricks and temptations of Satan, who aims to lead them astray and ultimately away from the path of righteousness. The verse emphasizes that Satan and his followers are always watching and seeking to mislead people, especially those who do not have faith. Therefore, it is a call to be vigilant, seek protection from God, and stay steadfast in one's faith to avoid falling into the traps set by Satan.
orig: يا بني آدم لا يفتننكم الشيطان كما أخرج أبويكم من الجنة ينزع عنهما لباسهما ليريهما سوآتهما إنه يراكم هو وقبيله من حيث لا ترونهم إنا جعلنا الشياطين أولياء للذين لا يؤمنون

translation: And when they commit an immorality, they say, 'We found our fathers doing it, and Allah has ordered us to do it.' Say, 'Indeed, Allah does not order immorality. Do you say about Allah that which you do not know?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the tendency of some individuals to justify their wicked actions by attributing them to their ancestors or, erroneously, to Allah's command. The verse challenges this excuse by declaring that Allah does not command immorality or sinful deeds. It warns against making false claims about Allah based on ignorance or misguided beliefs, emphasizing the importance of personal accountability and righteousness in one's actions.
orig: وإذا فعلوا فاحشة قالوا وجدنا عليها آباءنا والله أمرنا بها قل إن الله لا يأمر بالفحشاء أتقولون على الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: Say, "My Lord has ordered justice and [said], 'Set your faces at every place of worship and call upon Him, making religion pure for Him only. As He brought you into being, so you will return.'"
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of justice and sincerity in worship. It instructs believers to uphold justice in all aspects of their lives and worship Allah sincerely and purely. By calling upon Him with devotion and sincerity, they are reminded that their ultimate return is to Allah, the One who created them.
orig: قل أمر ربي بالقسط وأقيموا وجوهكم عند كل مسجد وادعوه مخلصين له الدين كما بدأكم تعودون

translation: There is a group He has guided, and there is a group deserving of misguidance. Indeed, they have taken the devils as allies instead of Allah while they assume that they are rightly guided.
interpretation: This verse highlights the division between those whom Allah has guided and those who have strayed due to their own actions. It emphasizes the consequences of deviating from the path of righteousness and warns against turning to sources of evil for guidance instead of relying on Allah. It serves as a reminder to choose one's allies wisely and not to delude oneself into thinking they are on the right path when they have strayed.
orig: فريقا هدى وفريقا حق عليهم الضلالة إنهم اتخذوا الشياطين أولياء من دون الله ويحسبون أنهم مهتدون

translation: O Children of Adam! Take your adornment at every masjid, and eat and drink, but be not excessive. Indeed, He likes not the excessive.
interpretation: This verse reminds mankind to maintain their dignity and modesty in their appearance when visiting places of worship such as mosques. It also advises moderation in eating and drinking, warning against excessiveness, as one of the traits that Allah dislikes.
orig: يا بني آدم خذوا زينتكم عند كل مسجد وكلوا واشربوا ولا تسرفوا إنه لا يحب المسرفين

translation: Say, 'Who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good [lawful] things of provision?' Say, 'They are for those who believe during the worldly life [but] exclusively [for them] on the Day of Resurrection.' Thus do We detail the verses for a people who know.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the permission granted by Allah to enjoy the lawful bounties and beauties of life as a provision for the believers in this world. It also implies that these pleasures will be exclusively for the believers in the Hereafter, highlighting the idea that the rewards of the righteous will be distinct and abundant in the afterlife. This verse serves as a reminder for believers to appreciate the blessings and provisions provided by Allah in this world while maintaining faith and righteousness.
orig: قل من حرم زينة الله التي أخرج لعباده والطيبات من الرزق قل هي للذين آمنوا في الحياة الدنيا خالصة يوم القيامة كذلك نفصل الآيات لقوم يعلمون

translation: Say, "My Lord has only forbidden immoralities - what is apparent of them and what is concealed - and sin, and oppression without right, and that you associate with Allah that for which He has not sent down authority, and that you say about Allah that which you do not know."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the prohibition of immoral actions and behaviors, both those that are done openly and those that are done in secret, as well as any form of oppression and wrongdoing. It also warns against associating partners with Allah without any basis or authority, and speaking about Allah without knowledge. The verse calls for righteousness and emphasizes the importance of abstaining from sin and injustice.
orig: قل إنما حرم ربي الفواحش ما ظهر منها وما بطن والإثم والبغي بغير الحق وأن تشركوا بالله ما لم ينزل به سلطانا وأن تقولوا على الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: And for every nation is a [specified] term. So when their time has come, they will not remain behind an hour, nor will they precede [it].
interpretation: This verse highlights the appointed time for every nation and individual, emphasizing that once the fixed term arrives, there can be no delay or advancement. It serves as a reminder of the divine decree and the inevitability of accountability and judgement, urging believers to prepare for the appointed time through righteous actions and faith.
orig: ولكل أمة أجل فإذا جاء أجلهم لا يستأخرون ساعة ولا يستقدمون

translation: O Children of Adam! Whenever messengers come to you from among you, reciting My verses to you, then whoever practices piety and mends their ways – they will have no fear, nor will they grieve.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of heeding the messages and signs sent by Allah through His messengers. Those who fear Allah, follow His guidance, and seek to mend their ways will be granted peace of mind and protection from fear and sorrow. It serves as a reminder for believers to stay steadfast in faith and righteous deeds to attain tranquility and security in both this world and the Hereafter.
orig: يا بني آدم إما يأتينكم رسل منكم يقصون عليكم آياتي فمن اتقى وأصلح فلا خوف عليهم ولا هم يحزنون

translation: And those who deny Our signs and are arrogant toward them - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: This verse warns that those who reject the signs of Allah and display arrogance towards them will be the dwellers of the Hellfire for eternity. It emphasizes the consequences of denying the messages of Allah and highlights the seriousness of pride as a barrier to guidance.
orig: والذين كذبوا بآياتنا واستكبروا عنها أولئك أصحاب النار هم فيها خالدون

translation: So who is more unjust than one who invents a lie about Allah or denies His signs? Indeed, those will attain their portion of the Book until, when Our messengers come to them to take them in death, they will say, 'Where are those you used to invoke besides Allah?' They will say, 'They have departed from us,' and will bear witness against themselves that they were disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse highlights the severe injustice and wrongdoing of those who fabricate lies about Allah or reject His signs. It speaks about how those who engage in such actions will ultimately face the consequences of their deeds when the messengers of Allah come to take their souls at the time of death. At that moment, the disbelievers will realize their error and attempt to distance themselves from their false idols or beliefs, but they will bear witness against themselves that they were indeed deniers of the truth.
orig: فمن أظلم ممن افترى على الله كذبا أو كذب بآياته أولئك ينالهم نصيبهم من الكتاب حتى إذا جاءتهم رسلنا يتوفونهم قالوا أين ما كنتم تدعون من دون الله قالوا ضلوا عنا وشهدوا على أنفسهم أنهم كانوا كافرين

translation: He will say, 'Enter among nations which had passed before you of jinn and mankind into the Fire.' Every time a nation entered, it cursed its sister nation until, when they had all overtaken one another therein, the last of them will say about the first of them, 'Our Lord, these had misled us, so give them a double punishment of the Fire.' He will say, 'For each is double, but you do not know.'
interpretation: This verse illustrates the scene on the Day of Judgment where the nations of jinn and mankind are brought into the Fire. Each nation that enters the Fire will blame the previous nations for leading them astray. The cycle of blame will continue until the last nation will request a double punishment for the first nation. However, Allah clarifies that each nation will face its due punishment, though the individuals do not fully understand the consequences of their actions.
orig: قال ادخلوا في أمم قد خلت من قبلكم من الجن والإنس في النار كلما دخلت أمة لعنت أختها حتى إذا اداركوا فيها جميعا قالت أخراهم لأولاهم ربنا هؤلاء أضلونا فآتهم عذابا ضعفا من النار قال لكل ضعف ولكن لا تعلمون

translation: And the first of them said to the last of them, 'Then you have not any favor over us, so taste the punishment for what you used to earn.'
interpretation: This verse alludes to a scenario where those who were sinful and disbelieving will not have any superiority over others on the Day of Judgment. Each soul will bear the consequences of their actions, and no one will be able to escape the consequences of their deeds. It serves as a reminder of personal accountability and individual responsibility in front of God.
orig: وقالت أولاهم لأخراهم فما كان لكم علينا من فضل فذوقوا العذاب بما كنتم تكسبون

translation: Indeed, those who deny Our verses and are arrogant toward them - the gates of Heaven will not be opened for them, and they will not enter Paradise until a camel enters into the eye of a needle. And thus do We recompense the criminals.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the consequence of denying and being arrogant towards the signs and teachings of Allah. It conveys the idea that those who reject the clear signs and truth of Allah will not be granted access to Paradise, highlighting the severity of their error. The metaphor of a camel passing through the eye of a needle symbolizes the impossibility of such individuals entering Paradise due to their disbelief and arrogance. It serves as a warning and reminder that those who persist in sinful actions will face just retribution in the Hereafter.
orig: إن الذين كذبوا بآياتنا واستكبروا عنها لا تفتح لهم أبواب السماء ولا يدخلون الجنة حتى يلج الجمل في سم الخياط وكذلك نجزي المجرمين

translation: For them in Hell will be a bed and over them coverings [of fire]. And thus do We [accurately] recompense the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse describes the punishment that awaits the wrongdoers in Hell. They will have a bed in Hell, which signifies a state of rest in agony, and coverings of fire over them, symbolizing intense heat and torment. The verse emphasizes that the punishment of Hell is a just recompense for the wrongdoing they committed in the world.
orig: لهم من جهنم مهاد ومن فوقهم غواش وكذلك نجزي الظالمين

translation: But those who believe and do righteous deeds - We will not burden a soul beyond its capacity. Those are the companions of Paradise; they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of fairness and justice in Islam. It reassures believers that Allah will not burden them with more than they can handle, showing His mercy and compassion towards His creation. Those who have faith and perform good deeds will be rewarded with entry into Paradise, where they will dwell forever in peace and happiness.
orig: والذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات لا نكلف نفسا إلا وسعها أولئك أصحاب الجنة هم فيها خالدون

translation: And We removed whatever ill-feeling was in their hearts. Rivers flow beneath them, and they said, 'All praise is due to Allah, who has guided us to this. We would not have been guided had Allah not guided us. Certainly, the messengers of our Lord brought the truth.' And they are called, 'This is the Garden, which you are inherited for what you used to do.'
interpretation: This verse speaks about how Allah removes hatred and negativity from the hearts of the believers. It emphasizes the guidance provided by Allah through messengers who brought the truth. The believers express gratitude to Allah for this guidance, recognizing that it is through His mercy that they have been guided. The verse also highlights the concept of inheriting paradise as a result of the righteous actions performed in this world.
orig: ونزعنا ما في صدورهم من غل تجري من تحتهم الأنهار وقالوا الحمد لله الذي هدانا لهذا وما كنا لنهتدي لولا أن هدانا الله لقد جاءت رسل ربنا بالحق ونودوا أن تلكم الجنة أورثتموها بما كنتم تعملون

translation: And the companions of Paradise will call out to the companions of the Fire, 'We have already found what our Lord promised us to be true. Have you found what your Lord promised to be true?' They will say, 'Yes.' Then an announcer will announce among them, 'The curse of Allah is upon the wrongdoers.'
interpretation: This verse depicts a scene on the Day of Judgment, where the people of Paradise will converse with the people of Hell. The believers will affirm that the promises of Allah have been fulfilled for them, while the disbelievers will also recognize that what they were warned about has indeed come to pass. The announcement of Allah's curse on the wrongdoers emphasizes the severity of their transgressions and the justice of divine retribution.
orig: ونادى أصحاب الجنة أصحاب النار أن قد وجدنا ما وعدنا ربنا حقا فهل وجدتم ما وعد ربكم حقا قالوا نعم فأذن مؤذن بينهم أن لعنة الله على الظالمين

translation: Those who avert [people] from the way of Allah and seek to make it [seem] deviant while they, concerning the Hereafter, are disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an condemns those who obstruct or block others from the path of Allah, guiding them away from the right way. These individuals intentionally distort the teachings of Islam and misguide others. Furthermore, it highlights that, despite their actions, they deny or reject the concept of the Hereafter, thereby showing a lack of faith and belief in the ultimate accountability that awaits in the afterlife.
orig: الذين يصدون عن سبيل الله ويبغونها عوجا وهم بالآخرة كافرون

translation: And between them will be a partition, and on [i.e., the elevations] are men who recognize all by their mark. And they call out to the companions of Paradise, "Peace be upon you." They have not [yet] entered it, but they long intensely.
interpretation: This verse describes a scene in the Hereafter where there is a barrier separating the people of Paradise from those on the heights. The people on the heights recognize the people of Paradise and greet them with peace, even though they have not yet entered Paradise themselves. The verse highlights the anticipation and yearning for Paradise felt by those who have not yet attained it.
orig: وبينهما حجاب وعلى الأعراف رجال يعرفون كلا بسيماهم ونادوا أصحاب الجنة أن سلام عليكم لم يدخلوها وهم يطمعون

translation: And when their eyes are turned towards the companions of the Fire, they say, 'Our Lord, do not place us with the wrongdoing people.'
interpretation: This verse describes a scene on the Day of Judgment where the disbelievers, upon seeing the punishment of the wrongdoers in Hell, will plead with Allah to not associate them with the unjust people. It signifies the fear and regret that they will experience at that moment, realizing the consequences of their actions and wishing to distance themselves from the wrongdoers.
orig: وإذا صرفت أبصارهم تلقاء أصحاب النار قالوا ربنا لا تجعلنا مع القوم الظالمين

translation: And the companions of the Elevations will call out to men [who they will] recognize by their mark, saying, 'What use were your companies and hoarding, [from] that which you used to take pride in?'
interpretation: This verse illustrates a scene from the day of judgment where the companions of the Elevations will question individuals recognized by their deeds. It highlights that wealth and status amassed during worldly life will be of no benefit when facing judgment, and those who were arrogant and proud of their earthly achievements will find them worthless in the hereafter.
orig: ونادى أصحاب الأعراف رجالا يعرفونهم بسيماهم قالوا ما أغنى عنكم جمعكم وما كنتم تستكبرون

translation: Those are the ones whom you swore that Allah would never extend mercy to. Enter Paradise; no fear will there be concerning you, nor will you grieve.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of divine mercy and forgiveness. It indicates that those who have been judged harshly or deemed unworthy of Allah's mercy by others may still ultimately receive mercy from Allah and be granted entry into Paradise. It is a reminder that Allah's mercy transcends human judgments and expectations, offering hope and reassurance to believers.
orig: أهؤلاء الذين أقسمتم لا ينالهم الله برحمة ادخلوا الجنة لا خوف عليكم ولا أنتم تحزنون

translation: And the companions of the Fire will call to the companions of Paradise, 'Pour upon us some water or from whatever Allah has provided you.' They will say, 'Indeed, Allah has forbidden them both to the disbelievers.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the clear division between the inhabitants of Paradise and the inhabitants of Hell. The people of Hell will desperately seek relief from the torment they are facing and will ask the people of Paradise for water or any provision from Allah. However, the people of Paradise, recognizing the clear decree of Allah, will respond that such provisions are prohibited for the disbelievers. This underscores the justice of Allah's judgment and the distinct destinies of the righteous and the disbelievers in the Hereafter.
orig: ونادى أصحاب النار أصحاب الجنة أن أفيضوا علينا من الماء أو مما رزقكم الله قالوا إن الله حرمهما على الكافرين

translation: Those who have taken their religion as distraction and amusement and whom the worldly life deluded. So today We will forget them just as they forgot the meeting of this Day of theirs and for rejecting Our verses.
interpretation: This verse highlights a warning against those who prioritize worldly distractions over their religion, leading to them being deceived by the temporary pleasures of this life. It emphasizes the consequence of forgetting the remembrance of God and neglecting the signs and revelations provided by Allah. The verse serves as a reminder of the consequences of neglecting one's spiritual duties in favor of worldly desires.
orig: الذين اتخذوا دينهم لهوا ولعبا وغرتهم الحياة الدنيا فاليوم ننساهم كما نسوا لقاء يومهم هذا وما كانوا بآياتنا يجحدون

translation: And We have certainly brought them a Book which We have detailed with knowledge, as guidance and mercy to a people who believe.
interpretation: This verse highlights the significance of the Qur'an as a divine book revealed with clear explanations, leading to guidance and mercy for those who have faith. It emphasizes that the Qur'an is a source of knowledge that provides guidance and blessings to believers.
orig: ولقد جئناهم بكتاب فصلناه على علم هدى ورحمة لقوم يؤمنون

translation: Do they wait except for its interpretation? The Day its interpretation comes, those who had ignored it before will say, 'The messengers of our Lord had come with the truth. So are there [now] any intercessors to intercede for us or could we be sent back to do other than we used to do?' They will have lost themselves, and lost from them is what they used to invent.
interpretation: This verse highlights the regret of those who ignored the signs and messages of the messengers of Allah in the world, realizing their loss and seeking intercession or a chance to return to the world to make amends. However, it will be too late for them as they will have to face the consequences of their actions and the falsehoods they used to follow.
orig: هل ينظرون إلا تأويله يوم يأتي تأويله يقول الذين نسوه من قبل قد جاءت رسل ربنا بالحق فهل لنا من شفعاء فيشفعوا لنا أو نرد فنعمل غير الذي كنا نعمل قد خسروا أنفسهم وضل عنهم ما كانوا يفترون

translation: Indeed, your Lord is Allah, who created the heavens and the earth in six days and then established Himself above the Throne, arranging the matter. There is no intercessor except after His permission. That is Allah, your Lord, so worship Him. Then will you not remember?
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the ultimate power and authority of Allah as the creator of the heavens and the earth. It highlights His control over the universe, with the night and day, the sun, the moon, and the stars all following His command. The verse calls for the worship of Allah alone and reminds humanity of His exclusive dominion and sovereignty over all creation.
orig: إن ربكم الله الذي خلق السماوات والأرض في ستة أيام ثم استوى على العرش يغشي الليل النهار يطلبه حثيثا والشمس والقمر والنجوم مسخرات بأمره ألا له الخلق والأمر تبارك الله رب العالمين

translation: Call upon your Lord in humility and privately; indeed, He does not like the aggressors.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of making supplications to Allah in a state of humility and sincerity, away from showing off or seeking attention. It highlights that arrogance and aggression are displeasing traits to Allah, urging believers to approach Him with humility and reverence.
orig: ادعوا ربكم تضرعا وخفية إنه لا يحب المعتدين

translation: And do not cause corruption upon the earth after its reformation. And invoke Him in fear and aspiration. Indeed, the mercy of Allah is near to the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers not to cause corruption after the earth has been reformed. It emphasizes the importance of maintaining peace and righteousness after achieving it. The verse also encourages believers to pray to Allah with both fear and hope, showing humility and dependence on Him. It highlights that Allah's mercy is close to those who do good deeds, encouraging righteous behavior and seeking closeness to Allah.
orig: ولا تفسدوا في الأرض بعد إصلاحها وادعوه خوفا وطمعا إن رحمت الله قريب من المحسنين

translation: And it is He who sends the winds as good tidings before His mercy, and when they have carried heavy clouds, We drive them to a dead land. Then We send down water, and bring forth with it all kinds of fruits. Thus We will bring forth the dead. Perhaps you may be reminded.
interpretation: This verse illustrates the power and mercy of Allah, who sends winds as a sign of the coming of His mercy in the form of rain to revive a dead land with abundant fruits. The cycle portrayed here, where life is restored to the earth through water, serves as a reminder of the resurrection of the dead, emphasizing the ultimate power of Allah over life and death, and urging people to reflect upon the signs of Allah's creation.
orig: وهو الذي يرسل الرياح بشرا بين يدي رحمته حتى إذا أقلت سحابا ثقالا سقناه لبلد ميت فأنزلنا به الماء فأخرجنا به من كل الثمرات كذلك نخرج الموتى لعلكم تذكرون

translation: By the land that is good. Indeed, My signs are well-established for people who believe.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of the productivity of good land compared to barren land, drawing a parallel with how signs from Allah are clear and evident to those who are grateful and believe. It emphasizes the importance of recognizing and appreciating the signs of Allah in the world around us as a means to strengthen faith and gratitude.
orig: والبلد الطيب يخرج نباته بإذن ربه والذي خبث لا يخرج إلا نكدا كذلك نصرف الآيات لقوم يشكرون

translation: Certainly We sent Noah to his people, and he said, 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a great Day.'
interpretation: Prophet Noah was sent to his people to call them to worship Allah alone and to warn them of the severe punishment in the Hereafter for those who associate partners with Allah. This verse emphasizes the importance of monotheism and the consequences of disbelief.
orig: لقد أرسلنا نوحا إلى قومه فقال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره إني أخاف عليكم عذاب يوم عظيم

translation: The eminent among his people said, 'Indeed, we see you in clear error.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the opposition that prophets often faced from some of their own people, specifically those in positions of power and influence, who not only rejected their message but also went as far as to publicly declare them as being in clear error. It serves as a reminder of the challenges faced by those who stand up for truth and righteousness, often finding themselves opposed by those who are entrenched in their own ways and interests.
orig: قال الملأ من قومه إنا لنراك في ضلال مبين

translation: He said, 'O my people, there is not in me error, but I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse highlights Prophet Hud's declaration to his people that he is indeed a messenger from Allah, confirming his sincerity and truthfulness in delivering the message of Islam to the people of 'Ad. It serves as a reminder that messengers are chosen by Allah to convey His message and guide people, and they do not err in their mission.
orig: قال يا قوم ليس بي ضلالة ولكني رسول من رب العالمين

translation: I convey to you the messages of my Lord and advise you, and I know from Allah that which you do not know.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the role of the messenger of Allah (in this case, Prophet Hud) as a conveyor of divine messages and as an advisor to the people. It also highlights the knowledge granted by Allah to the messenger that surpasses the knowledge possessed by others, emphasizing the importance of following the guidance and advice provided by the messengers of Allah.
orig: أبلغكم رسالات ربي وأنصح لكم وأعلم من الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: Or do you wonder that there has come to you a reminder from your Lord through a man from among you, that he may warn you and that you may fear Allah, so that you might receive mercy?
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the delivery of the message by a human being, chosen by God to warn and remind people to fear Allah. It highlights the importance of heeding the reminders and warnings given by the messengers in order to attain the mercy of Allah.
orig: أوعجبتم أن جاءكم ذكر من ربكم على رجل منكم لينذركم ولتتقوا ولعلكم ترحمون

translation: So they denied him, and We saved him and those with him in the ship, and We drowned those who denied Our signs. Indeed, they were a blind people.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an describes the story of Prophet Noah and his people. Despite their denial of him and his message, Allah saved Prophet Noah and those who believed in him in the ark while drowning those who rejected the signs of Allah. The verse highlights the consequences of disbelief and the fate of those who choose to turn away from the guidance of Allah. It serves as a reminder of the importance of belief, obedience, and the inevitable judgment that awaits all.
orig: فكذبوه فأنجيناه والذين معه في الفلك وأغرقنا الذين كذبوا بآياتنا إنهم كانوا قوما عمين

translation: And to 'Aad [We sent] their brother Hud. He said, 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Then will you not fear?'
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the message of the Prophet Hud to the people of 'Aad, urging them to worship and fear only Allah, the One true God. It highlights the call to monotheism and warns against associating partners with Allah. The prophet is reminding the people to be conscious of God's presence and to acknowledge His supreme power.
orig: وإلى عاد أخاهم هودا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره أفلا تتقون

translation: The eminent ones who disbelieved among his people said, 'Indeed, we see you in foolishness, and indeed, we think you are of the liars.'
interpretation: This verse presents the response of the disbelievers among Prophet Hud's people, who belittled and mocked him. They accused him of foolishness and deceit, reflecting their denial of the truth and their arrogance. It illustrates the challenges prophets faced in conveying the message of God to their people and the resistance they encountered from those who refused to believe.
orig: قال الملأ الذين كفروا من قومه إنا لنراك في سفاهة وإنا لنظنك من الكاذبين

translation: He said, 'O my people, there is not foolishness in me, but I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: In this verse, the speaker is claiming to be a messenger of Allah to his people. He refutes the accusation of being foolish and emphasizes that he is conveying a message from the Lord of all worlds. This verse highlights the importance of prophets in delivering divine guidance and the rejection that they often face from their communities.
orig: قال يا قوم ليس بي سفاهة ولكني رسول من رب العالمين

translation: I convey to you the messages of my Lord and I am to you a trustworthy advisor.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the role of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a trustworthy and sincere advisor to his people. It highlights the importance of delivering the messages from Allah faithfully and guiding others towards righteousness.
orig: أبلغكم رسالات ربي وأنا لكم ناصح أمين

translation: Do you find it strange that a reminder from your Lord has come to you through a man from among you, to warn you? And remember when He made you successors after the people of Noah, and increased you in stature extensively. So remember the bounties of Allah, so that you may succeed.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of receiving guidance and warnings from Allah through messengers who are human like us. It reminds us of the succession granted to us after the people of Noah, and how Allah has blessed us by increasing us in number and stature. The verse urges us to reflect on the blessings and favors of Allah with the hope that such contemplation will lead us to success.
orig: أوعجبتم أن جاءكم ذكر من ربكم على رجل منكم لينذركم واذكروا إذ جعلكم خلفاء من بعد قوم نوح وزادكم في الخلق بسطة فاذكروا آلاء الله لعلكم تفلحون

translation: They said, 'Have you come to us to make us worship Allah alone and abandon what our fathers used to worship? Then bring us what you promise us, if you should be among the truthful.'
interpretation: This verse reflects the resistance of some people to the message of monotheism brought by the Prophet. They question the need to abandon the beliefs of their forefathers and challenge the Prophet to provide proof of his claims. It emphasizes the common theme in the Qur'an of the struggle between adhering to traditions versus embracing the truth, even when it challenges established norms.
orig: قالوا أجئتنا لنعبد الله وحده ونذر ما كان يعبد آباؤنا فأتنا بما تعدنا إن كنت من الصادقين

translation: He said, "Already has it fallen upon you from your Lord, [O Muhammad], wrath and curse. Do you dispute with me concerning [mere] names you have named them, you and your fathers, for which Allah has not sent down any authority? Then wait, indeed, I am with you among those who wait."
interpretation: In this verse, the Qur'an is emphasizing the consequences that have been decreed by God for those who engage in disputing about matters without any evidence or authority. It warns against following traditions or beliefs that do not have a basis in divine revelation. Additionally, it reminds the believers to exercise patience in the face of adversity and to trust in God's timing and decree.
orig: قال قد وقع عليكم من ربكم رجس وغضب أتجادلونني في أسماء سميتموها أنتم وآباؤكم ما نزل الله بها من سلطان فانتظروا إني معكم من المنتظرين

translation: So We saved him and those with him by mercy from Us, and We cut off the roots of those who denied Our signs and were not believers.
interpretation: This verse highlights how Allah saved Prophet Noah and those who believed in him, while punishing those who rejected his signs. It underscores the concept of divine mercy towards the believers and the consequences faced by disbelievers.
orig: فأنجيناه والذين معه برحمة منا وقطعنا دابر الذين كذبوا بآياتنا وما كانوا مؤمنين

translation: And to Thamud [We sent] their brother Salih. He said, 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. There has come to you clear evidence from your Lord. This is the she-camel of Allah [sent] to you as a sign. So leave her to eat within Allah's land and do not touch her with harm, lest there seize you a painful punishment.'
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the story of the people of Thamud and the prophet Salih sent to them. Salih is reminding his people to worship Allah alone and warning them not to harm the miraculous she-camel sent as a sign from Allah. The verse emphasizes the consequences of disobedience and the importance of following the clear evidence and signs from Allah.
orig: وإلى ثمود أخاهم صالحا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره قد جاءتكم بينة من ربكم هذه ناقة الله لكم آية فذروها تأكل في أرض الله ولا تمسوها بسوء فيأخذكم عذاب أليم

translation: And mention when He made you successors after the 'Aad and settled you in the land, [and] you take for yourselves palaces from its plains and carve from the mountains, homes. So remember the favors of Allah and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption.
interpretation: This verse reminds the believers of the blessings bestowed upon them by Allah, such as being appointed as successors on earth and being provided with resources and provisions. The verse also warns against misuse of these blessings, advising them not to be corrupt and cause harm or disorder in the land.
orig: واذكروا إذ جعلكم خلفاء من بعد عاد وبوأكم في الأرض تتخذون من سهولها قصورا وتنحتون الجبال بيوتا فاذكروا آلاء الله ولا تعثوا في الأرض مفسدين

translation: The eminent among his people who disbelieved said to those who were oppressed - to those who believed among them, 'Do you [actually] know that Salih is sent from his Lord?' They said, 'Indeed we, in that with which he has been sent, are believers.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the interactions between the disbelievers and the believers in the context of the message brought by Prophet Salih. The disbelievers among the people questioned the believers about their faith in Prophet Salih, implying doubt in his prophethood. However, the believers affirmed their faith and trust in the message brought by Prophet Salih from his Lord, emphasizing their unwavering belief in him as a messenger of God.
orig: قال الملأ الذين استكبروا من قومه للذين استضعفوا لمن آمن منهم أتعلمون أن صالحا مرسل من ربه قالوا إنا بما أرسل به مؤمنون

translation: Those who were arrogant will say, 'Indeed, we are disbelievers in what you believe.'
interpretation: This verse describes the response of those who were arrogant in this life and denied the truth of the message of Islam on the Day of Judgment. They will disbelieve in the truth that the believers followed, even though it will be evident to them then.
orig: قال الذين استكبروا إنا بالذي آمنتم به كافرون

translation: They hamstrung the she-camel and defied the command of their Lord and said, 'O Salih, bring us what you promise us, if you should be of the messengers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the people who disbelieved in the message of the prophet Salih and demanded a miraculous sign from him to prove his prophethood. When Salih asked them to refrain from harming the she-camel that was a test from Allah, they defied his command and killed the she-camel instead. This act of disobedience towards Allah's command and the prophet's warning ultimately led to their punishment.
orig: فعقروا الناقة وعتوا عن أمر ربهم وقالوا يا صالح ائتنا بما تعدنا إن كنت من المرسلين

translation: So the earthquake seized them, and they became [lifeless] in their home, lying [lifeless] like corpses.
interpretation: This verse describes the punishment that befell a group of disbelievers. The earthquake mentioned here is not merely a physical tremor, but a metaphor for a catastrophic event that overtook them as a consequence of their wrongdoing. The suddenness and severity of the punishment is highlighted by the fact that they were struck down in their own homes, lying lifeless like corpses, emphasizing the ultimate power and justice of Allah.
orig: فأخذتهم الرجفة فأصبحوا في دارهم جاثمين

translation: So he turned away from them and said, 'O my people, I had certainly conveyed to you the message of my Lord and advised you, but you do not like advisors.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the Prophet's struggle to convey the message of Allah to his people and advise them sincerely. It reflects the resistance and rejection faced by prophets when conveying the truth, despite their genuine concern for their people's well-being. It serves as a reminder of the importance of accepting sincere advice and guidance.
orig: فتولى عنهم وقال يا قوم لقد أبلغتكم رسالة ربي ونصحت لكم ولكن لا تحبون الناصحين

translation: And [mention] Lot, when he said to his people, 'Do you commit such immorality as no one has preceded you with from among the worlds?'
interpretation: This verse is referring to Prophet Lot (Lut in Arabic) questioning his people about their commitment to such immoral acts that were unheard of in the world before them. Prophet Lot is warning them about the gravity of their sins and reminding them of the consequences of their actions.
orig: ولوطا إذ قال لقومه أتأتون الفاحشة ما سبقكم بها من أحد من العالمين

translation: Indeed, you approach men with desire, instead of women. Rather, you are a transgressing people.
interpretation: This verse is a reminder to the people who engage in sinful acts of homosexuality, condemning their actions as transgressive. It highlights the deviation from the natural order prescribed by Allah, where relationships should be between men and women, not between men. It serves as a warning against such behavior and a call to adhere to the moral boundaries set by Islam.
orig: إنكم لتأتون الرجال شهوة من دون النساء بل أنتم قوم مسرفون

translation: And the answer of his people was only that they said, 'Evict them from your city; indeed, they are people who keep themselves pure.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the reaction of Prophet Lut's people when he warned them about their immoral behavior. Despite being called to righteousness, the people responded with hostility and demanded the expulsion of Prophet Lut and his followers from the city. The disbelievers viewed them as a threat to their lifestyle, failing to recognize the purity and righteousness of Prophet Lut and his companions.
orig: وما كان جواب قومه إلا أن قالوا أخرجوهم من قريتكم إنهم أناس يتطهرون

translation: So We saved him and his family, except for his wife; she was of those who remained behind.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Lut (Lot) and how he and his family were saved from the destruction of the people of Sodom, except for his wife who did not believe and therefore perished. It serves as a reminder of the consequences of disbelief and disobedience.
orig: فأنجيناه وأهله إلا امرأته كانت من الغابرين

translation: And We rained upon them a rain [of stones]. Then see how was the end of the criminals.
interpretation: This verse highlights the punishment that befell the wrongdoers who opposed the prophets. It serves as a reminder of the consequences of disobedience and the Divine justice that awaits those who commit heinous acts.
orig: وأمطرنا عليهم مطرا فانظر كيف كان عاقبة المجرمين

translation: And to the people of Madyan [We sent] their brother Shu'aib. He said, 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. There has come to you clear evidence from your Lord. So fulfill the measure and weight and do not deprive people of their due and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption after its reformation. That is better for you, if you should be believers.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the message of Prophet Shu'aib to his people, reminding them to worship Allah alone and adhere to justice and fairness in their dealings. It emphasizes the importance of fulfilling one's obligations, treating others with equity, and avoiding corruption or wrongdoing. The verse underscores that true belief includes not only faith in Allah but also the practice of righteousness in all aspects of life.
orig: وإلى مدين أخاهم شعيبا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره قد جاءتكم بينة من ربكم فأوفوا الكيل والميزان ولا تبخسوا الناس أشياءهم ولا تفسدوا في الأرض بعد إصلاحها ذلكم خير لكم إن كنتم مؤمنين

translation: And do not sit on every path, threatening and averting from the way of Allah those who believe in Him, seeking to make it [seem] deviant. And remember when you were few and He increased you. And see how was the end of the corrupters.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of not obstructing or hindering the path of others who believe in Allah. It reminds believers to be aware of their actions and intentions, as they should not seek to misguide or hinder those on the righteous path. The verse also serves as a reminder of the consequences faced by those who disrupt and corrupt the way of Allah. It encourages reflection on the past when believers were few in number but were eventually increased by Allah's will, underscoring the rewards for those who remain steadfast in faith and righteousness.
orig: ولا تقعدوا بكل صراط توعدون وتصدون عن سبيل الله من آمن به وتبغونها عوجا واذكروا إذ كنتم قليلا فكثركم وانظروا كيف كان عاقبة المفسدين

translation: And if a faction of you believes in that with which I have been sent down, and a faction does not believe, then be patient until Allah judges between us. And He is the best of judges.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of patience and trust in Allah's ultimate judgment. It acknowledges that differences in faith may exist among people, but instructs believers to remain patient and wait for Allah's decision. It reminds us to have faith that Allah, being the most just and wise of judges, will ultimately resolve any conflicts or disagreements among us.
orig: وإن كان طائفة منكم آمنوا بالذي أرسلت به وطائفة لم يؤمنوا فاصبروا حتى يحكم الله بيننا وهو خير الحاكمين

translation: The eminent ones among his people who were arrogant said, 'We will surely drive you out, O Shu'ayb, and those who have believed with you from our city, or you must return to our religion.' He said, 'Even if we are unwilling?'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an illustrates the scenario where the arrogant leaders of a community threaten Prophet Shu'ayb and the believers with expulsion if they do not comply with the community's wishes. Shu'ayb, undeterred by the ultimatum, questions the necessity of obedience if it goes against their beliefs. The verse showcases the importance of standing firm in one's faith and principles, even in the face of opposition and coercion.
orig: قال الملأ الذين استكبروا من قومه لنخرجنك يا شعيب والذين آمنوا معك من قريتنا أو لتعودن في ملتنا قال أولو كنا كارهين

translation: We have certainly fabricated lies about Allah, if we return to your religion after Allah has saved us from it. It is not for us to return to it unless Allah, our Lord, wills. Our Lord has encompassed everything in knowledge. Upon Allah we have relied. Our Lord, decide between us and our people in truth, and You are the best of those who decide."
interpretation: This verse expresses the commitment to the truth, the rejection of falsehood, and the reliance on Allah's will. It emphasizes that once Allah has guided someone out of ignorance or falsehood, it is not permissible to return to it willingly. It also highlights the importance of seeking Allah's guidance and judgment in resolving disputes or conflicts. The believers trust in Allah's knowledge and wisdom, and they ask for His judgment to prevail in all matters.
orig: قد افترينا على الله كذبا إن عدنا في ملتكم بعد إذ نجانا الله منها وما يكون لنا أن نعود فيها إلا أن يشاء الله ربنا وسع ربنا كل شيء علما على الله توكلنا ربنا افتح بيننا وبين قومنا بالحق وأنت خير الفاتحين

translation: And the eminent among his people who disbelieved said, 'If you follow Shuaib, indeed, you will then be losers.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the resistance and opposition faced by the Prophet Shuaib from the leaders of his community who were disbelievers. They tried to dissuade the people from following Shuaib by spreading doubt and fear, warning them that they would be losers if they followed him. It serves as a reminder that prophets often faced opposition and criticism from those in power, but their message of righteousness and faithfulness stood firm despite the challenges.
orig: وقال الملأ الذين كفروا من قومه لئن اتبعتم شعيبا إنكم إذا لخاسرون

translation: So the earthquake seized them, and they became within their home [corpses] fallen prone.
interpretation: This verse describes a scene where a group of people who denied the truth and rejected the message of their prophet were punished with a sudden earthquake that struck them in their own homes, leaving them lifeless. It serves as a reminder of the consequences of disbelief and disobedience to divine guidance.
orig: فأخذتهم الرجفة فأصبحوا في دارهم جاثمين

translation: Those who denied Shu'ayb - it was as though they had never resided there. Those who denied Shu'ayb - it was they who were the losers.
interpretation: This verse refers to the people who rejected the message of the prophet Shu'ayb. It highlights that their denial and opposition will ultimately result in their loss and ruin, as if they had never benefitted from their existence in that place. The verse serves as a warning that rejecting the truth and opposing the prophets leads to ultimate failure and loss in both this life and the Hereafter.
orig: الذين كذبوا شعيبا كأن لم يغنوا فيها الذين كذبوا شعيبا كانوا هم الخاسرين

translation: So he turned away from them and said, 'O my people, I had certainly conveyed to you the messages of my Lord and advised you, so how could I grieve for a disbelieving people?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the responsibility of a messenger to convey the message of the Lord to their people and provide sincere advice. It also emphasizes the detachment a messenger should have from the outcome of their efforts, as it is ultimately up to individuals to believe or disbelieve. The messenger's grief is not for the disbelief of the people, but rather for their guidance and well-being.
orig: فتولى عنهم وقال يا قوم لقد أبلغتكم رسالات ربي ونصحت لكم فكيف آسى على قوم كافرين

translation: And We did not send any prophet to a city except that We seized its people with hardship and suffering that they might humble themselves.
interpretation: This verse highlights that throughout history, whenever a prophet was sent to a community, and when that community persisted in their wrongdoing and disbelief, they were eventually met with consequences in the form of hardships and calamities. These tests were meant to serve as a reminder and a means for the people to reflect, seek forgiveness, and turn back to Allah in humility and repentance. It emphasizes the mercy of Allah in giving opportunities for people to return to the right path, even through trials and tribulations.
orig: وما أرسلنا في قرية من نبي إلا أخذنا أهلها بالبأساء والضراء لعلهم يضرعون

translation: And We exchanged their misdeeds for good deeds until they increased in number and said, "Our forefathers were touched by both hardship and ease." So We seized them suddenly while they were unaware.
interpretation: This verse speaks about how Allah granted respite to the wrongdoers, switching their bad deeds for good deeds in order to give them a chance to repent and change their ways. However, instead of showing gratitude and remorse for their past actions, they began to attribute the hardships and prosperity they faced to mere coincidences or luck. As a result of their heedlessness, they were seized by Allah swiftly and unexpectedly, indicating the importance of being mindful and humble in the face of blessings and trials.
orig: ثم بدلنا مكان السيئة الحسنة حتى عفوا وقالوا قد مس آباءنا الضراء والسراء فأخذناهم بغتة وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And if the people of the cities had believed and feared Allah, We would have opened upon them blessings from the heaven and the earth; but they denied [the messengers], so We seized them for what they were earning.
interpretation: This verse points out that if the people of the towns had believed in the messengers and had consciousness of Allah, they would have been showered with abundant blessings from both the heavens and the earth. However, due to their disbelief and rejection of the message, they faced the consequences of their actions and were punished accordingly for their deeds.
orig: ولو أن أهل القرى آمنوا واتقوا لفتحنا عليهم بركات من السماء والأرض ولكن كذبوا فأخذناهم بما كانوا يكسبون

translation: Do the people of the towns feel secure that Our punishment will not come to them by night while they are asleep?
interpretation: This verse serves as a reminder to the people of the towns that they should not feel secure from Allah's punishment, even while they are asleep at night. It emphasizes the importance of being constantly aware of one's actions and seeking forgiveness and protection from Allah at all times.
orig: أفأمن أهل القرى أن يأتيهم بأسنا بياتا وهم نائمون

translation: Or are the people of the towns secure from Our punishment coming to them by night while they are asleep?
interpretation: This verse questions if the people of the towns should feel safe from the punishment of Allah while they are inattentive or heedless in their actions. It serves as a reminder of the unpredictability and inevitability of divine retribution, urging people to be conscious of their deeds and not become complacent in their security.
orig: أوأمن أهل القرى أن يأتيهم بأسنا ضحى وهم يلعبون

translation: Do they feel secure from the scheme of Allah? None feel secure from the scheme of Allah except the losing people.
interpretation: This verse serves as a reminder that no one can be completely secure from the will and plan of Allah. Those who believe themselves to be immune to Divine intervention and planning are mistaken, as ultimately, all power and control lies in the hands of Allah. It warns those who are heedless and arrogant, thinking they are beyond the reach of Allah's plan, that they are in fact the ones who are bound to fail and suffer loss in the end.
orig: أفأمنوا مكر الله فلا يأمن مكر الله إلا القوم الخاسرون

translation: Does it not suffice for those who inherit the land after its previous inhabitants that if We willed, We could afflict them for their sins, and seal their hearts so they would not listen?
interpretation: This verse highlights the accountability and warning for those who inherit lands and reap the benefits of the exploitation and sins of previous dwellers. It communicates that God has the power to punish them for their wrongdoings and deafen their hearts to prevent them from perceiving guidance and wisdom if they continue in their unjust ways.
orig: أولم يهد للذين يرثون الأرض من بعد أهلها أن لو نشاء أصبناهم بذنوبهم ونطبع على قلوبهم فهم لا يسمعون

translation: These are the towns whose stories We relate unto thee (Muhammad). Their messengers came unto them with clear proofs (of Allah's Sovereignty), but they could not believe because they had before denied. Thus doth Allah print upon the hearts of disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse highlights the towns and civilizations that had received messengers with clear signs from Allah, inviting them to believe. However, these people had persistently rejected the truth, and as a consequence of their denial, Allah sealed their hearts with disbelief. It serves as a reminder of the importance of recognizing and accepting the signs of Allah, as rejecting them can lead to a hardening of the heart towards faith.
orig: تلك القرى نقص عليك من أنبائها ولقد جاءتهم رسلهم بالبينات فما كانوا ليؤمنوا بما كذبوا من قبل كذلك يطبع الله على قلوب الكافرين

translation: And We did not find most of them true to their covenant, indeed We found most of them defiantly disobedient.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the reality that most people fail to uphold their agreements and promises with Allah. Despite being given covenants and obligations, many still choose to disobey and turn away from the truth. It serves as a reminder about the importance of staying true to one's commitments and being obedient to Allah's guidance.
orig: وما وجدنا لأكثرهم من عهد وإن وجدنا أكثرهم لفاسقين

translation: Then We sent Moses with Our signs to Pharaoh and his establishment, but they wrongfully rejected them. So see how was the end of the corruptors.
interpretation: This verse points out how even when clear signs and proofs are presented to those who are arrogant and unjust, they still persist in their wrongdoing. The verse emphasizes the ultimate fate of those who spread corruption and reject the truth, serving as a lesson for all. It highlights the consequences of arrogance and injustice in the face of divine signs and warnings.
orig: ثم بعثنا من بعدهم موسى بآياتنا إلى فرعون وملئه فظلموا بها فانظر كيف كان عاقبة المفسدين

translation: And Moses said, 'O Pharaoh, indeed I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse highlights Prophet Moses' confidence and conviction in proclaiming his message to Pharaoh, asserting his divine authority granted by the Lord of all worlds. It exemplifies the courage and steadfastness required in delivering the message of truth to those in positions of power and authority, regardless of the challenges and opposition faced.
orig: وقال موسى يا فرعون إني رسول من رب العالمين

translation: It is the truth from me to say nothing about Allah except the truth. I have come to you with clear evidence from your Lord, so send the Children of Israel with me.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of truthfulness when speaking about Allah and His messages. It also highlights the role of the prophet Moses (peace be upon him) as a messenger of clear evidence from Allah, sent to lead the Children of Israel. The verse underscores the credibility and authenticity of Moses' mission, as well as the necessity for people to accept and follow the message brought by the prophets.
orig: حقيق على أن لا أقول على الله إلا الحق قد جئتكم ببينة من ربكم فأرسل معي بني إسرائيل

translation: He said, "If you have come with a sign, then bring it, if you should be among the truthful."
interpretation: This verse highlights a challenge made to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) by the disbelievers of his time, demanding him to produce a miraculous sign as proof of his prophethood. It emphasizes the importance of evidence and truthfulness in conveying the message of Islam.
orig: قال إن كنت جئت بآية فأت بها إن كنت من الصادقين

translation: So he threw down his staff and there it was, a clearly visible serpent.
interpretation: This verse describes the miraculous event of Prophet Moses turning his staff into a serpent as a sign of his prophethood and the power bestowed upon him by Allah. It signifies the truth of his message and serves as a proof of his divine appointment as a messenger to Pharaoh and his people.
orig: فألقى عصاه فإذا هي ثعبان مبين

translation: And he drew out his hand; thereupon it was white for the observers.
interpretation: This verse refers to the miracle where the hand of Prophet Moses was turned white as a sign of his truthfulness and the authenticity of his message. This transformation served as a clear and undeniable proof of his connection to Allah and his status as a prophet, and it was meant to make a powerful impact on the people who witnessed it.
orig: ونزع يده فإذا هي بيضاء للناظرين

translation: The chiefs among Pharaoh's people said, 'This man is indeed a skilled sorcerer,'
interpretation: This verse highlights the reaction of the chiefs of Pharaoh's people when they witnessed the miracles performed by Prophet Moses. Their immediate response was to attribute his abilities to sorcery rather than recognizing the signs of Allah. This shows how some individuals may refuse to acknowledge the truth even when it is presented clearly to them, opting instead to dismiss it or twist it in a way that suits their own beliefs or desires.
orig: قال الملأ من قوم فرعون إن هذا لساحر عليم

translation: He wants to drive you out of your land; what then do you counsel?
interpretation: This verse highlights a situation where a community is being forcibly driven out of their land. It poses a question about what their response should be in this challenging circumstance. The verse serves as a reminder to reflect on the actions and decisions to be taken in times of adversity and to seek counsel and guidance in such situations.
orig: يريد أن يخرجكم من أرضكم فماذا تأمرون

translation: They said, 'Delay him and his brother and send among the cities gatherers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a group of people planning to delay or harm two individuals and send spies to gather information for their ill intentions. It warns against deceitful schemes and the importance of being cautious of those who may conspire against others.
orig: قالوا أرجه وأخاه وأرسل في المدائن حاشرين

translation: They come to you with every skillful magician.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the challenges faced by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) from those who sought to deceive and mislead people through their skills in magic and trickery. It serves as a reminder to be aware of those who try to lead others astray with powers that are not aligned with the truth and guidance of God.
orig: يأتوك بكل ساحر عليم

translation: And the magicians came to Pharaoh. They said, 'Indeed, for us is a reward if we are the predominant.'
interpretation: This verse describes a scene where the magicians, who were summoned by Pharaoh to challenge Prophet Moses, expressed their desire for a reward if they were able to defeat Prophet Moses. Their focus was on worldly gains and recognition rather than seeking the truth and guidance from Allah. It serves as a reminder to prioritize sincerity and seeking the pleasure of Allah over materialistic desires and rewards.
orig: وجاء السحرة فرعون قالوا إن لنا لأجرا إن كنا نحن الغالبين

translation: He said, 'Yes, and indeed, you will be among those near [to me].'
interpretation: This verse is a statement affirming that those mentioned will indeed be among those close to Allah. It conveys the message of reassurance and promise of a special closeness to Allah for the believers who strive in their faith and good deeds.
orig: قال نعم وإنكم لمن المقربين

translation: They said, 'O Moses, either you throw or we will be the first to throw.'
interpretation: This verse reflects a situation where the magicians challenged Prophet Moses to make the first move in their contest. It shows their confidence and arrogance before witnessing the truth and power of God through the miracles performed by Prophet Moses.
orig: قالوا يا موسى إما أن تلقي وإما أن نكون نحن الملقين

translation: He said, 'Throw!' And when they threw, they bewitched the eyes of the people and struck terror into them, and presented a great [feat of] magic.
interpretation: This verse describes a scene where sorcerers attempted to challenge the Prophet Moses, peace be upon him, by casting spells and performing illusions. However, the miracles performed by the Prophet Moses that followed exposed the falsehood and deceit of their sorcery. The verse highlights the power of divine miracles over illusions and serves as a reminder of the supremacy of God's guidance and truth over any form of deception or trickery.
orig: قال ألقوا فلما ألقوا سحروا أعين الناس واسترهبوهم وجاءوا بسحر عظيم

translation: And We inspired Moses, 'Throw your staff,' and at once it devoured what they were falsifying.
interpretation: This verse highlights one of the miracles granted to the Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) by Allah. By casting his staff, it transformed into a serpent and swallowed the illusory snakes conjured by the magicians of Pharaoh. It demonstrates the divine power bestowed upon the Prophets and serves as a reminder of the authority and oneness of Allah.
orig: وأوحينا إلى موسى أن ألق عصاك فإذا هي تلقف ما يأفكون

translation: And the truth has been established, and what they used to do has been nullified.
interpretation: This verse signifies the inevitability of truth prevailing and falsehood being abolished. It serves as a reminder that ultimately all deeds will be judged based on their truth and righteousness, and any actions that were built on falsehood will be rendered void. It highlights the importance of sincerity and integrity in one's beliefs and actions, as these will be the foundation upon which true success is built in the eyes of God.
orig: فوقع الحق وبطل ما كانوا يعملون

translation: So they overcame them by the permission of Allah, and they became small in their own eyes.
interpretation: This verse highlights the victory of the believers over their enemies with the permission and support of Allah. It also emphasizes the importance of humility, as the enemies who were once arrogant and oppressive became small in their own eyes after their defeat.
orig: فغلبوا هنالك وانقلبوا صاغرين

translation: And the sorcerers fell down in prostration.
interpretation: This verse refers to the moment when the sorcerers who were summoned by the Pharaoh to challenge Prophet Musa (Moses) in a magic contest, witnessed the miracle of his staff turning into a serpent and surrendered to the truth of Musa’s message, thus prostrating in submission to Allah. It signifies the defeat of falsehood by the power of truth and faith.
orig: وألقي السحرة ساجدين

translation: They said, 'We have believed in the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the essence of faith in Islam, which is the belief in the Lord of all worlds. It emphasizes the comprehensive nature of monotheism and the acknowledgment of the universal sovereignty of the Creator. Belief in the Lord of the worlds encompasses trust, submission, and devotion to God, recognizing His authority over everything in existence.
orig: قالوا آمنا برب العالمين

translation: The Lord of Moses and Aaron.
interpretation: This verse acknowledges the Lordship of Allah over both Moses and Aaron, indicating that they are under His guidance and protection. It emphasizes the divine authority and power that governs all beings, regardless of their status or position.
orig: رب موسى وهارون

translation: Pharaoh said, 'You believed in him before I gave you permission. Indeed, this is a conspiracy which you conspired in the city to expel therefrom its people. But you are going to know.'
interpretation: This verse is describing how Pharaoh accused the believers of conspiring against him and plotting to expel the people of the city. It illustrates Pharaoh's paranoia and unjust actions towards those who followed the message of truth. It also warns about the consequences of disbelief and arrogance, as ultimately, the truth will prevail and falsehood will be exposed.
orig: قال فرعون آمنتم به قبل أن آذن لكم إن هذا لمكر مكرتموه في المدينة لتخرجوا منها أهلها فسوف تعلمون

translation: I will surely cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides, then I will surely crucify you all.
interpretation: This verse serves as a warning against those who commit acts of corruption, mischief, or spreading disorder in the land. It illustrates the severe consequences of such actions and highlights the importance of maintaining peace and justice in society.
orig: لأقطعن أيديكم وأرجلكم من خلاف ثم لأصلبنكم أجمعين

translation: They said, 'Indeed, we are returning to our Lord.'
interpretation: This verse suggests the acknowledgment and acceptance of the ultimate return to Allah, emphasizing the concept of accountability in the hereafter. It reflects the believers' awareness of their inevitable return to Allah for judgment and highlights the importance of keeping a conscious connection with Him throughout their lives.
orig: قالوا إنا إلى ربنا منقلبون

translation: And you take vengeance upon us only because we believed in the signs of our Lord when they came to us. Our Lord, pour upon us patience and let us die as Muslims.
interpretation: This verse reflects the steadfast belief and faith of believers in the face of adversity and persecution. It emphasizes the idea of remaining patient and steadfast in one's faith even in the face of challenges and difficulties. It also portrays the believers' submission to Allah's will and their willingness to die as Muslims, surrendering themselves completely to Allah. Overall, it highlights the importance of faith, patience, and submission in the life of a believer.
orig: وما تنقم منا إلا أن آمنا بآيات ربنا لما جاءتنا ربنا أفرغ علينا صبرا وتوفنا مسلمين

translation: And the eminent among the people of Pharaoh said, 'Will you leave Moses and his people to cause corruption in the land and abandon you and your gods?' [Pharaoh] said, 'We will kill their sons and keep their women alive; and indeed, we are to them subjugators.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the level of arrogance and cruelty exhibited by Pharaoh and his followers. They saw Prophet Moses and his followers as a threat to their power and authority, intending to oppress and destroy them. It illustrates a desire for domination over others and a willingness to commit grave injustices in the pursuit of maintaining control and enforcing tyranny.
orig: وقال الملأ من قوم فرعون أتذر موسى وقومه ليفسدوا في الأرض ويذرك وآلهتك قال سنقتل أبناءهم ونستحيي نساءهم وإنا فوقهم قاهرون

translation: Moses said to his people, 'Seek help through Allah and be patient. Indeed, the earth belongs to Allah. He causes to inherit it whom He wills of His servants. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous.'
interpretation: This verse reminds us of the importance of seeking help from Allah and being patient in times of difficulty. It highlights the fact that the ownership of the earth ultimately belongs to Allah, and He chooses whom to grant it to. The verse emphasizes that the ultimate success and reward are for those who are righteous and God-conscious, who fear Allah and follow His guidance.
orig: قال موسى لقومه استعينوا بالله واصبروا إن الأرض لله يورثها من يشاء من عباده والعاقبة للمتقين

translation: They said, 'We were harmed before you came to us, and after you have come to us.' [Moses] said, 'Perhaps your Lord will destroy your enemy and grant you succession in the land and see how you will act.'
interpretation: This verse reflects a dialogue between Prophet Moses and the Children of Israel. The people complained about the harm they had faced both before and after Moses came to them. In response, Moses advised them to be patient and have faith in Allah's plan. He hinted at the possibility that Allah would destroy their enemy and grant them victory and power in the land. The verse serves as a reminder to have faith in God's wisdom and power, as well as the importance of patience in times of hardship.
orig: قالوا أوذينا من قبل أن تأتينا ومن بعد ما جئتنا قال عسى ربكم أن يهلك عدوكم ويستخلفكم في الأرض فينظر كيف تعملون

translation: And We certainly seized the people of Pharaoh with years of famine and a deficiency in fruits that perhaps they would be reminded.
interpretation: This verse highlights how Allah uses various ways to remind people of their arrogance and disobedience. In this case, the people of Pharaoh were afflicted with shortages in their resources and livelihood as a form of punishment, with the hope that they would remember Allah and turn back to Him in repentance.
orig: ولقد أخذنا آل فرعون بالسنين ونقص من الثمرات لعلهم يذكرون

translation: So when good came to them, they said, 'This is for us.' But if a bad [condition] struck them, they saw an evil omen in Moses and those with him. Unquestionably, their fortune is with Allah, but most of them do not know.
interpretation: This verse highlights the human tendency to attribute positive outcomes to themselves while blaming others, even Prophets like Moses, for negative situations. It reminds believers that ultimate control and decree lies with Allah, and that many fail to recognize this truth.
orig: فإذا جاءتهم الحسنة قالوا لنا هذه وإن تصبهم سيئة يطيروا بموسى ومن معه ألا إنما طائرهم عند الله ولكن أكثرهم لا يعلمون

translation: And they say, 'We will not believe you until you bring down to us a book that we can read.' Say, 'Glorified is my Lord! Am I anything but a human messenger?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the stubbornness and arrogance of some who demanded miracles or specific signs to believe in the message of the Prophet. The Prophet is reminded to place his trust in Allah and continue delivering the message, regardless of the disbelief of some individuals. It also emphasizes the human nature of the Prophet and his role as a messenger of Allah, rather than a performer of miracles to satisfy the whims of the disbelievers.
orig: وقالوا مهما تأتنا به من آية لتسحرنا بها فما نحن لك بمؤمنين

translation: So We sent upon them the flood and the locusts and the lice and the frogs and the blood as distinct signs. But they were arrogant and were a criminal people.
interpretation: This verse illustrates how despite the clear signs and warnings sent by God in various forms as a consequence of their wrongdoing, some people continued to show arrogance and disbelief. It serves as a reminder that arrogance and persisting in wrongful actions can blind individuals from recognizing and accepting the truth, leading them further astray.
orig: فأرسلنا عليهم الطوفان والجراد والقمل والضفادع والدم آيات مفصلات فاستكبروا وكانوا قوما مجرمين

translation: And when the punishment fell upon them, they said, 'O Moses, invoke your Lord for us by what He has promised you. If you [can] remove the punishment from us, we will surely believe you, and we will send with you the Children of Israel.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the behavior of some of the Children of Israel during a time of hardship, where they turned to Prophet Moses asking for his supplication to Allah to remove the punishment inflicted upon them. Their condition was such that they promised to believe in Prophet Moses and even support him by sending the Children of Israel with him if the punishment was lifted. However, this incident serves as a reminder of how the human tendency to seek help in times of distress may lead to temporary faith, rather than a lasting belief rooted in sincere conviction and devotion to Allah.
orig: ولما وقع عليهم الرجز قالوا يا موسى ادع لنا ربك بما عهد عندك لئن كشفت عنا الرجز لنؤمنن لك ولنرسلن معك بني إسرائيل

translation: So when We removed from them the affliction, for a term which they were to reach, behold, they broke their promise.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting how some people, when relieved from a hardship they were facing for a certain period, end up breaching their commitment and breaking their promises to God. It serves as a reminder to be steadfast and grateful to God in both times of ease and difficulty.
orig: فلما كشفنا عنهم الرجز إلى أجل هم بالغوه إذا هم ينكثون

translation: So We took retribution from them, and We drowned them in the sea because they denied Our signs and were heedless of them.
interpretation: This verse refers to the punishment inflicted upon the disbelieving people by drowning them in the sea due to their denial of the signs of Allah and their negligence towards them. It serves as a reminder of the consequences of rejecting the messages of God and being oblivious to His guidance.
orig: فانتقمنا منهم فأغرقناهم في اليم بأنهم كذبوا بآياتنا وكانوا عنها غافلين

translation: And We made the people who were considered weak inherit the eastern regions of the land and the western ones which We had blessed. And the good word of your Lord was fulfilled for the Children of Israel because of their patience. And We destroyed what Pharaoh and his people had built and what they had been making.
interpretation: This verse highlights how Allah's decree granted victory to the weak and oppressed people, allowing them to inherit lands that were once held by powerful oppressors. It also emphasizes the importance of patience in receiving the blessings promised by Allah. The verse contrasts the fate of the oppressed with the downfall of Pharaoh and his people, illustrating the consequences of their tyranny and arrogance.
orig: وأورثنا القوم الذين كانوا يستضعفون مشارق الأرض ومغاربها التي باركنا فيها وتمت كلمت ربك الحسنى على بني إسرائيل بما صبروا ودمرنا ما كان يصنع فرعون وقومه وما كانوا يعرشون
