translation: He said, 'If only I had the power to resist you or could take refuge in a strong support.'
interpretation: In this verse, the speaker is expressing a sense of helplessness and vulnerability in the face of a challenging situation. They wish for the strength to resist and overcome the difficulties they are facing, or to find refuge in a strong support or protector. This reflects the human tendency to seek assistance and protection when feeling overwhelmed or threatened, as well as the yearning for inner strength and resilience in times of adversity.
orig: قال لو أن لي بكم قوة أو آوي إلى ركن شديد

translation: They said, 'O Lot, indeed we are messengers of your Lord; [therefore], they will never reach you. So set out with your family during a portion of the night and let not any among you look back - except your wife; indeed, she will be struck by that which strikes them. Indeed, their appointment is [for] the morning. Is not the morning near?'
interpretation: This verse describes the messengers of Lot advising him to leave his city with his family during the night without looking back, except for his wife who will be punished for her disbelief along with the rest of the people of the city. The verse conveys that the appointed time for their destruction is the morning, emphasizing the imminent nature of their punishment.
orig: قالوا يا لوط إنا رسل ربك لن يصلوا إليك فأسر بأهلك بقطع من الليل ولا يلتفت منكم أحد إلا امرأتك إنه مصيبها ما أصابهم إن موعدهم الصبح أليس الصبح بقريب

translation: So when Our command came, We made the highest part [of the city] its lowest and rained upon them stones of hard clay, in layers,
interpretation: This verse describes a divine punishment inflicted upon a disobedient people wherein their city was destroyed by turning its highest parts into its lowest, and then raining upon it stones of hard clay. It serves as a reminder of the consequences of rejecting God's commands and the severity of His punishment for wrongdoing.
orig: فلما جاء أمرنا جعلنا عاليها سافلها وأمطرنا عليها حجارة من سجيل منضود

translation: Prescribed by your Lord and it is not from the wrongdoers far.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the laws and decrees set by God are just and fair, and they are not beyond the reach of those who follow them. It serves as a reminder that the divine guidance and commandments are for the benefit of humanity and are not burdensome or unjust.
orig: مسومة عند ربك وما هي من الظالمين ببعيد

translation: And to [the people of] Midian [We sent] their brother Shu'ayb. He said, 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. And do not decrease from the measure and the scale. Indeed, I see you in prosperity, but indeed, I fear for you the punishment of an all-encompassing Day.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of the prophet Shu'ayb sent to the people of Midian, advising them to worship only Allah and to be just in their dealings, warning them about the consequences of their actions. The interpretation emphasizes the importance of monotheism, honesty, and fairness in societies, and the consequences that may follow if these values are not upheld.
orig: وإلى مدين أخاهم شعيبا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره ولا تنقصوا المكيال والميزان إني أراكم بخير وإني أخاف عليكم عذاب يوم محيط

translation: O my people, give full measure and weight in justice and do not deprive the people of their due and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of justice, honesty, and fairness in all dealings. It instructs people to be just in their measurements and transactions, not cheating others or causing corruption in society. It highlights the Islamic principles of upholding integrity, fairness, and respect for others in economic and social interactions.
orig: ويا قوم أوفوا المكيال والميزان بالقسط ولا تبخسوا الناس أشياءهم ولا تعثوا في الأرض مفسدين

translation: Allah is sufficient for you; He is the best protector.
interpretation: This verse of the Qur'an reminds believers that Allah alone is enough for them as a protector and provider. It emphasizes the importance of having faith and trust in Allah's abilities and promises, knowing that He will take care of His faithful servants. It teaches that relying on Allah is far superior to relying on anyone or anything else in this world.
orig: بقيت الله خير لكم إن كنتم مؤمنين وما أنا عليكم بحفيظ

translation: They said, 'O Shu'aib, does your prayer command you that we should leave what our fathers worship or not do with our wealth as we please? Indeed, you are the forbearing, the discerning!'
interpretation: This verse reflects a conversation where a group of people questioned the teachings of Prophet Shu'aib, asking if his prayers and devotion truly guide him to instruct them to abandon the beliefs of their forefathers and regulate how they spend their wealth. Prophet Shu'aib is described as patient and wise in dealing with their queries and criticisms.
orig: قالوا يا شعيب أصلاتك تأمرك أن نترك ما يعبد آباؤنا أو أن نفعل في أموالنا ما نشاء إنك لأنت الحليم الرشيد

translation: He said, "O my people, have you considered: if I am upon clear evidence from my Lord and He has provided me with a good provision from Him...? And I do not intend to differ from you in that which I have forbidden you; I only intend reform as much as I am able. And my success is not but through Allah. Upon Him I have relied, and to Him I return."
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the importance of following clear evidence and relying on provisions and guidance from Allah. The speaker is expressing a commitment to righteousness and reform, relying on Allah for success and guidance. It emphasizes the importance of following the path that Allah has set and seeking His help in all endeavors.
orig: قال يا قوم أرأيتم إن كنت على بينة من ربي ورزقني منه رزقا حسنا وما أريد أن أخالفكم إلى ما أنهاكم عنه إن أريد إلا الإصلاح ما استطعت وما توفيقي إلا بالله عليه توكلت وإليه أنيب

translation: And O my people, let not [your] dissension from me cause you to be struck by that similar to what struck the people of Noah or the people of Hud or the people of Salih. And the people of Lot are not from you far away.
interpretation: This verse warns the people against the consequences of their division and opposition to the prophets sent to guide them. It reminds them of the punishment that befell previous nations like the people of Noah, Hud, Salih, and Lot, and emphasizes that they are not immune to such punishment if they persist in their disobedience and rejection of guidance.
orig: ويا قوم لا يجرمنكم شقاقي أن يصيبكم مثل ما أصاب قوم نوح أو قوم هود أو قوم صالح وما قوم لوط منكم ببعيد

translation: And seek forgiveness of your Lord and repent to Him. Indeed, my Lord is Merciful and Affectionate.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of seeking forgiveness from God and turning back to Him in repentance. It highlights the qualities of God's mercy and love, reminding believers that no matter what they have done, God is always ready to forgive and welcome them back with love and compassion.
orig: واستغفروا ربكم ثم توبوا إليه إن ربي رحيم ودود

translation: They said, 'O Shu'ayb, we do not understand much of what you say, and indeed, we consider you among us as weak. And if not for your family, we would have stoned you. And you are not to us one respected.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the struggles of the Prophet Shu'ayb in conveying his message to his people, as they found it difficult to comprehend and rejected him due to his perceived weakness. Despite facing opposition and threats, Shu'ayb remained steadfast in his mission, facing rejection and ridicule, but he continued to convey the message of Allah with determination and patience.
orig: قالوا يا شعيب ما نفقه كثيرا مما تقول وإنا لنراك فينا ضعيفا ولولا رهطك لرجمناك وما أنت علينا بعزيز

translation: He said, 'O my people, have you considered: if I am upon clear evidence from my Lord and He has provided me with a good provision from Him...? And I do not intend to differ from you in that which I have forbidden you; I only intend reform as much as I am able. And my success is not but through Allah. Upon Him I have relied, and to Him I return.'
interpretation: This verse conveys the message of a prophet addressing his people, asserting that his guidance and provisions come from Allah, and he only seeks to guide his people towards righteousness. The prophet clarifies that his reliance and success come solely from Allah, and he ultimately returns to Him. The verse emphasizes the prophet's commitment to reform and reliance on Allah.
orig: قال يا قوم أرهطي أعز عليكم من الله واتخذتموه وراءكم ظهريا إن ربي بما تعملون محيط

translation: And O my people, work according to your position; indeed, I am working. You are going to know to whom will come a torment that will disgrace him and who is a liar. So watch; indeed, I am with you, a watcher.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of righteousness and warns of the consequences of falsehood and wrongdoing. It highlights the idea that actions have consequences and that even if people may not see them immediately, there is a divine watcher who is aware of everything. It serves as a reminder to strive for good deeds and honesty, as ultimately, the truth will prevail, and those who are deserving of punishment will not escape it.
orig: ويا قوم اعملوا على مكانتكم إني عامل سوف تعلمون من يأتيه عذاب يخزيه ومن هو كاذب وارتقبوا إني معكم رقيب

translation: And when Our command came, We saved Shu'aib and those who believed with him by mercy from Us. And the blast seized those who wronged, and they became within their homes [corpses] fallen prone.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an narrates the story of how Prophet Shu'aib and the believers with him were saved by Allah's mercy when the command of destruction came. Those who had done wrong were struck by a blast and perished, serving as a reminder of the consequences of wrongdoing and the importance of following the guidance of the prophets.
orig: ولما جاء أمرنا نجينا شعيبا والذين آمنوا معه برحمة منا وأخذت الذين ظلموا الصيحة فأصبحوا في ديارهم جاثمين

translation: As if they had never prospered there. Unquestionably, Thamud denied their Lord; then, away with Thamud.
interpretation: This verse is conveying the fate of the people of Thamud who denied and disobeyed their Lord. The verse illustrates that their denial of the truth led to their destruction and downfall despite their initial prosperity. It serves as a reminder of the consequences of rejecting faith and disobeying the teachings of Allah.
orig: كأن لم يغنوا فيها ألا بعدا لمدين كما بعدت ثمود

translation: And We certainly sent Moses with Our signs and a clear authority.
interpretation: This verse highlights the appointment of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) by Allah as a messenger, emphasizing that he was equipped with clear miracles and a manifest authority to convey the message of Islam to the people. It underscores the Divine support and evidence granted to Prophet Moses in his mission to guide his people towards righteousness and the worship of the One true God.
orig: ولقد أرسلنا موسى بآياتنا وسلطان مبين

translation: To Pharaoh and his establishment, but they followed the command of Pharaoh, and the command of Pharaoh was not [at all] discerning.
interpretation: This verse highlights the blind obedience of Pharaoh and his followers to his commands, even though they lacked wisdom and righteousness. It serves as a reminder against blindly following oppressive authorities without questioning their actions or morals.
orig: إلى فرعون وملئه فاتبعوا أمر فرعون وما أمر فرعون برشيد

translation: He will present his people [on the Day of Judgement], then drive them towards the Fire. And evil is the place to which they are driven.
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the accountability and consequences on the Day of Judgment. It portrays a scene where individuals will be presented with their deeds and then driven towards the Fire as a punishment for their wrongdoings. The verse serves as a warning about the severe consequences of rejecting faith and committing evil deeds in this world.
orig: يقدم قومه يوم القيامة فأوردهم النار وبئس الورد المورود

translation: And they will be followed in this world with a curse and the Day of Resurrection. And wretched is the gift which is given.
interpretation: This verse warns those who disobey God that they will face consequences in this world and in the Hereafter. Their deeds will be cursed, and the outcome of such disobedience will be dreadful and unpleasant.
orig: وأتبعوا في هذه لعنة ويوم القيامة بئس الرفد المرفود

translation: That is from the news of the cities which We relate to you; of them, some are [still] standing, and some have been mown down.
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the transitory nature of civilizations and cities. It serves as a reminder of the rise and fall of nations throughout history. The mention of some cities being 'standing' and others 'mown down' highlights the aspect of impermanence and change in the world, urging reflection on the lessons that can be learned from past civilizations.
orig: ذلك من أنباء القرى نقصه عليك منها قائم وحصيد

translation: And We did not wrong them, but they wronged themselves. And they were not availed at all by their gods which they invoked other than Allah when there came the command of your Lord. And they did not increase them in anything except ruin.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that no injustice was done to people by God; rather, it was their own wrongdoing that led them astray. It highlights the futility of worshiping false gods and emphasizes that when the decree of God comes, these false deities will not be able to protect or benefit their worshipers, and in fact, they will only lead them to their own destruction.
orig: وما ظلمناهم ولكن ظلموا أنفسهم فما أغنت عنهم آلهتهم التي يدعون من دون الله من شيء لما جاء أمر ربك وما زادوهم غير تتبيب

translation: And thus is the seizure of your Lord when He seizes the cities while they are committing wrong. Indeed, His seizure is painful and severe.
interpretation: This verse describes how the punishment of Allah descends upon cities that engage in wrongdoing. It emphasizes that the punishment inflicted by Allah is severe and painful, serving as a warning to those who transgress the limits set by Him.
orig: وكذلك أخذ ربك إذا أخذ القرى وهي ظالمة إن أخذه أليم شديد

translation: Verily, in that is a sign for those who fear the punishment of the Hereafter. That is a Day for which the people will be gathered, and that is a Day witnessed.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of reflecting on the signs of the Hereafter for those who fear God's punishment. The verse describes the Day of Judgment as a day when all humanity will be gathered and witnessed by all.
orig: إن في ذلك لآية لمن خاف عذاب الآخرة ذلك يوم مجموع له الناس وذلك يوم مشهود

translation: And We delay it only for a specified term.
interpretation: This verse highlights that God delays certain events only for an appointed time. It teaches us that everything happens according to a divine plan and schedule, and that there is wisdom and purpose behind every delay we experience in life.
orig: وما نؤخره إلا لأجل معدود

translation: On the Day when it comes, no soul will speak except by His permission; and among them will be the wretched and the prosperous.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an is highlighting the concept of accountability on the Day of Judgment. It emphasizes that on that Day, no one will be able to speak or defend themselves except by the permission of Allah. It also indicates that there will be two groups of people on that Day – those who will be in a state of wretchedness due to their wrongdoings and those who will be in a state of prosperity due to their adherence to righteousness and good deeds.
orig: يوم يأت لا تكلم نفس إلا بإذنه فمنهم شقي وسعيد

translation: As for those who were [destined to be] wretched, they will be in the Fire, sighing and wailing.
interpretation: This verse describes the fate of those who have chosen the path of disobedience and rejection of God's guidance. They will be in the Fire, experiencing intense suffering and regret, represented by sighing and wailing. The verse serves as a warning about the consequence of straying from the right path and the importance of seeking forgiveness and guidance to avoid such a fate.
orig: فأما الذين شقوا ففي النار لهم فيها زفير وشهيق

translation: Eternally they will abide therein, as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except as your Lord wills. Indeed, your Lord is an effective doer of what He intends.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of eternity in the afterlife for the believers. It highlights that the duration of their stay in paradise is linked to the longevity of the heavens and the earth, except as decreed by Allah. It serves as a reminder of Allah's absolute power and authority, affirming that He is fully capable of carrying out His will.
orig: خالدين فيها ما دامت السماوات والأرض إلا ما شاء ربك إن ربك فعال لما يريد

translation: And as for those who were [destined to be] prosperous, they will be in Paradise, abiding therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except what your Lord should will - a gift uninterrupted.
interpretation: This verse describes the fate of the righteous and successful individuals who will have an eternal place in Paradise, where they will dwell for as long as the universe exists, enjoying endless bliss and blessings as a gift from Allah without any interruption.
orig: وأما الذين سعدوا ففي الجنة خالدين فيها ما دامت السماوات والأرض إلا ما شاء ربك عطاء غير مجذوذ

translation: So do not be in doubt of what these [people] worship; they do not worship except as their fathers worshipped before. And indeed, We will give them their share undiminished.
interpretation: This verse reminds us not to doubt the beliefs and practices of others simply because they may differ from our own. It highlights the idea that people often follow the religion of their ancestors without questioning or understanding it deeply. The verse also emphasizes that everyone will receive what they deserve in full measure from God, without any reduction or diminishment.
orig: فلا تك في مرية مما يعبد هؤلاء ما يعبدون إلا كما يعبد آباؤهم من قبل وإنا لموفوهم نصيبهم غير منقوص

translation: And We had certainly given Moses the Scripture, but it came under disagreement. And if not for a word that preceded from your Lord, it would have been judged between them. And indeed they are, concerning the Qur'an, in doubt and confusion.
interpretation: This verse highlights the reality of disagreements and doubts that can arise among people regarding the scripture. It emphasizes the importance of divine guidance and intervention in resolving such disputes. The verse also serves as a reminder for believers to seek clarity and understanding in the face of confusion or doubt.
orig: ولقد آتينا موسى الكتاب فاختلف فيه ولولا كلمة سبقت من ربك لقضي بينهم وإنهم لفي شك منه مريب

translation: And each soul shall be compensated in full for what it has done; and your Lord is aware of what they do.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of individual accountability and justice in Islam. It emphasizes that every person will be recompensed fully for their deeds by their Lord, who is fully aware and knowledgeable of all their actions. It serves as a reminder that Allah's judgment is just and precise, and no deed, good or bad, will go unnoticed or unrewarded.
orig: وإن كلا لما ليوفينهم ربك أعمالهم إنه بما يعملون خبير

translation: So remain on the right course as you have been commanded, [you] and those who have turned back with you [to Allah], and do not transgress. Indeed, He is Seeing of what you do.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of steadfastness in following the commandments of Allah and not straying from the right path. It encourages believers to stay on the righteous path, along with those who have repented and returned to Allah. The verse also warns against transgression and reminds that Allah is fully aware and observant of all our actions.
orig: فاستقم كما أمرت ومن تاب معك ولا تطغوا إنه بما تعملون بصير

translation: And do not incline toward those who do wrong, lest you be touched by the Fire, and you would not have other than Allah any protectors; then you would not be helped.
interpretation: This verse reminds us not to support or align ourselves with wrongdoers, as doing so may lead us towards the punishment of Hellfire. It emphasizes the importance of staying away from evil and not seeking protection or alliances from anyone other than Allah, as only Allah is the ultimate Protector and Helper.
orig: ولا تركنوا إلى الذين ظلموا فتمسكم النار وما لكم من دون الله من أولياء ثم لا تنصرون

translation: And establish prayer at the two ends of the day and at the approaches of the night. Indeed, good deeds do away with misdeeds. That is a reminder for those who remember.
interpretation: This verse is reminding believers to establish prayers regularly during the day and night. It emphasizes the importance of performing good deeds, as they have the power to erase or outweigh the bad deeds committed. It serves as a reminder for those who actively remember and reflect upon their faith.
orig: وأقم الصلاة طرفي النهار وزلفا من الليل إن الحسنات يذهبن السيئات ذلك ذكرى للذاكرين

translation: And be patient, for indeed, Allah does not allow to be lost the reward of those who do good.
interpretation: This verse encourages believers to exercise patience in all aspects of life, as a way to demonstrate faith and trust in Allah. It emphasizes that those who perform good deeds and show patience will be rewarded generously by Allah, and their efforts will never be in vain.
orig: واصبر فإن الله لا يضيع أجر المحسنين

translation: So why were there not among the generations before you those of enduring discrimination forbidding corruption on earth - except a few of those We saved from among them? But those who wronged pursued what luxury they were given therein, and they were criminals.
interpretation: This verse highlights a recurring pattern throughout history where only a few individuals from past nations stood against corruption and wrongdoing, while the majority indulged in luxuries and committed crimes. It serves as a reminder for people to uphold righteousness and denounce corruption, even in the face of challenges and temptations.
orig: فلولا كان من القرون من قبلكم أولو بقية ينهون عن الفساد في الأرض إلا قليلا ممن أنجينا منهم واتبع الذين ظلموا ما أترفوا فيه وكانوا مجرمين

translation: And your Lord would never destroy the cities unjustly while their people are righteous.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the justice and mercy of Allah, stating that He would never punish or destroy a community if its inhabitants were righteous and just. It serves as a reminder that Allah's justice is perfect and that He does not punish the innocent along with the guilty.
orig: وما كان ربك ليهلك القرى بظلم وأهلها مصلحون

translation: And if your Lord had willed, He could have made mankind one community, but they will not cease to differ.
interpretation: This verse highlights the diversity and differences among people as part of Allah's divine will. It emphasizes that unity among people is not necessarily achieved by making everyone the same, but rather by celebrating diversity while still working towards harmony and understanding despite disagreements and differences.
orig: ولو شاء ربك لجعل الناس أمة واحدة ولا يزالون مختلفين

translation: Except for those upon whom your Lord has mercy; and for that He created them. And the word of your Lord has been fulfilled: 'I will surely fill Hell with jinn and men all together.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of divine mercy and justice. It emphasizes that Allah's mercy is the primary reason for the creation of mankind and jinn. At the same time, it serves as a reminder that Allah's decree is inevitable, and that Hell will indeed be populated by both jinn and humans who have chosen to disobey and reject Him. It underscores the importance of seeking Allah's mercy and forgiveness in order to avoid the punishment of Hell.
orig: إلا من رحم ربك ولذلك خلقهم وتمت كلمة ربك لأملأن جهنم من الجنة والناس أجمعين

translation: And each [story] We relate to you from the news of the messengers is that by which We make firm your heart. And there has come to you, in this, the truth and an instruction and a reminder for the believers.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the stories of the messengers are narrated to strengthen and reassure the hearts of the believers. The accounts of the prophets' struggles and triumphs serve as a means of reminding and instructing the believers, providing them with guidance, truth, and wisdom to strengthen their faith and increase their certainty in the message of Islam.
orig: وكلا نقص عليك من أنباء الرسل ما نثبت به فؤادك وجاءك في هذه الحق وموعظة وذكرى للمؤمنين

translation: And say to those who do not believe, 'Work according to your position; indeed, we are working.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of everyone working diligently and responsibly within their own capacities, regardless of others' beliefs. It teaches that each individual is accountable for their actions and should focus on fulfilling their own responsibilities rather than being concerned with the beliefs or actions of others.
orig: وقل للذين لا يؤمنون اعملوا على مكانتكم إنا عاملون

translation: And wait; indeed, we are waiting.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of patience and perseverance in times of difficulty, reassuring believers that Allah is also patiently waiting to fulfill His promises. It serves as a reminder to have faith and trust in Allah's timing, knowing that He is aware of all situations and will fulfill His plans at the most appropriate time.
orig: وانتظروا إنا منتظرون

translation: And to Allah belongs the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth, and to Him will be returned the matter, all of it. So worship Him and rely upon Him. And your Lord is not unaware of what you do.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that Allah has knowledge of all that is hidden in the heavens and the earth, and all matters will ultimately return to Him. It urges believers to worship and trust in Him, highlighting that Allah is fully aware of their actions and deeds.
orig: ولله غيب السماوات والأرض وإليه يرجع الأمر كله فاعبده وتوكل عليه وما ربك بغافل عما تعملون

translation: Alif, Lam, Ra. These are the verses of the clear Book.
interpretation: This verse refers to the unique letters that begin some chapters of the Qur'an. The meaning and significance of these letters are known only to Allah. They serve as a reminder of the miraculous nature of the Qur'an and emphasize its clarity and guidance for those who seek it. They also highlight the eloquence and power of the Qur'anic language, inviting reflection and contemplation for the believers.
orig: الر تلك آيات الكتاب المبين

translation: We have sent it down as an Arabic Qur'an, in order that you may understand.
interpretation: Allah states that the Qur'an is revealed in the Arabic language so that people may understand its message clearly and easily. The choice of Arabic as the language of the Qur'an is significant as it was the language of the people to whom the Prophet Muhammad was sent. The use of Arabic, the language they spoke and understood, enabled a deeper comprehension and a more effective communication of the message of the Qur'an to the people at that time and for all generations to come.
orig: إنا أنزلناه قرآنا عربيا لعلكم تعقلون

translation: We relate to you, [O Muhammad], the best of stories in what We have revealed to you of this Qur'an although you were, before it, among the unaware.
interpretation: In this verse, Allah is telling the Prophet Muhammad that the stories in the Qur'an are among the best stories, and that the Qur'an itself is a revelation that helps guide and enlighten humanity. Before receiving the Qur'an, the Prophet was unaware of the knowledge it contained, emphasizing the importance of the divine revelation in bringing guidance and knowledge to mankind.
orig: نحن نقص عليك أحسن القصص بما أوحينا إليك هذا القرآن وإن كنت من قبله لمن الغافلين

translation: When Joseph said to his father, 'O my father, indeed I have seen [in a dream] eleven stars and the sun and the moon; I saw them prostrating to me.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an narrates how Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) shared a dream with his father, indicating that not only his eleven brothers but also his parents would one day bow down to him. This dream ultimately foretold Joseph's future leadership and elevated status in his family, as well as the trials and tribulations he would face before reaching that position.
orig: إذ قال يوسف لأبيه يا أبت إني رأيت أحد عشر كوكبا والشمس والقمر رأيتهم لي ساجدين

translation: He said, "My son, do not relate your vision to your brothers, or they will contrive a plot against you; surely Satan is an open enemy to mankind."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of discretion and being cautious about sharing one's dreams or aspirations with everyone, as not everyone may have good intentions towards us. It also serves as a reminder of the presence of Satan, who is constantly trying to lead humanity astray and create discord among them.
orig: قال يا بني لا تقصص رؤياك على إخوتك فيكيدوا لك كيدا إن الشيطان للإنسان عدو مبين

translation: And thus will your Lord choose you and teach you the interpretation of narratives and complete His favor upon you and upon the family of Jacob, as He completed it upon your fathers, Abraham and Isaac. Indeed, your Lord is Knowing and Wise.
interpretation: This verse highlights the special chosen status of Prophet Joseph by God, stating that God will select him, teach him the interpretation of dreams, and bestow His favor upon him and his family. It also emphasizes the continuity of divine wisdom and knowledge across generations, as seen in the mention of previous Prophets. The verse underscores God's all-knowing and wise nature in guiding His chosen ones.
orig: وكذلك يجتبيك ربك ويعلمك من تأويل الأحاديث ويتم نعمته عليك وعلى آل يعقوب كما أتمها على أبويك من قبل إبراهيم وإسحاق إن ربك عليم حكيم

translation: Certainly were there in the story of Joseph and his brothers signs for those who ask.
interpretation: This verse highlights the story of Prophet Joseph and his brothers as a source of guidance and lessons for those who seek knowledge and understanding. The trials, betrayals, and ultimate forgiveness and reconciliation that occurred in their story serve as valuable lessons for believers, reminding them of the importance of patience, trust in Allah's plan, and the power of forgiveness.
orig: لقد كان في يوسف وإخوته آيات للسائلين

translation: When they said, 'Joseph and his brother are more beloved to our father than we, while we are a strong band. Indeed, our father is in clear error.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the jealousy and animosity of Joseph's brothers towards him, as they resent their father's favoritism towards Joseph and feel superior in their collective strength. The verse also conveys the arrogance and lack of understanding of Joseph's brothers who believe their father is clearly wrong in his love for Joseph.
orig: إذ قالوا ليوسف وأخوه أحب إلى أبينا منا ونحن عصبة إن أبانا لفي ضلال مبين

translation: Kill Joseph or cast him out to [another] land; the countenance of your father will [then] be solely for you, and after that you can be righteous people.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) from the Qur'an. It serves as a divine narrative that showcases the trials and tribulations faced by Prophet Joseph at the hands of his brothers, who contemplated whether to kill him or cast him out. The interpretation of this verse can be understood as a lesson in patience, trust in Allah, and the ultimate triumph of righteousness over jealousy and evil intentions.
orig: اقتلوا يوسف أو اطرحوه أرضا يخل لكم وجه أبيكم وتكونوا من بعده قوما صالحين

translation: One of them said, 'Do not kill Joseph, but if you must do something, throw him into the bottom of the well; some travellers may pick him up, if you must act.'
interpretation: This verse talks about the plan of some of the brothers of Joseph to get rid of him by throwing him into a well instead of killing him. It shows the presence of conflicting intentions and the belief in the possibility of someone finding and saving Joseph. It signifies that even in the darkest of situations, there may be hope for rescue and redemption.
orig: قال قائل منهم لا تقتلوا يوسف وألقوه في غيابت الجب يلتقطه بعض السيارة إن كنتم فاعلين

translation: They said, 'O our father, why do you not entrust us with Joseph, while indeed we are to him sincere counselors?'
interpretation: This verse comes from Surah Yusuf and is part of the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and his brothers. In this verse, Yusuf's brothers are questioning their father, Prophet Yaqub (Jacob), asking why he does not trust them with Yusuf. They claim to be sincere and trustworthy, but their intentions are not pure as they plan to harm Yusuf. This verse teaches us the importance of discerning people's true intentions and being cautious of deceptive behavior, even if it comes from close family members.
orig: قالوا يا أبانا ما لك لا تأمنا على يوسف وإنا له لناصحون

translation: Send him with us tomorrow to enjoy himself and play. And indeed, we will be his guardians.
interpretation: This verse refers to the brothers of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf), convincing their father Prophet Jacob (Ya'qub) to let Yusuf go with them. They promised his safety and protection while emphasizing that Yusuf would have a good time, showing their intention to mend their relationship with him. The verse reminds us of the importance of family unity and trustworthiness in keeping promises.
orig: أرسله معنا غدا يرتع ويلعب وإنا له لحافظون

translation: He said, 'Indeed, it saddens me that you should take him, and I fear lest a wolf should eat him while you are unaware of him.'
interpretation: This verse reflects the concern of Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him) for his beloved son, Joseph. It shows the depth of his paternal love and worry for the safety of his son, fearing harm may come to him when he is away. It reminds us of the human emotions of love and fear, even within the family of prophets.
orig: قال إني ليحزنني أن تذهبوا به وأخاف أن يأكله الذئب وأنتم عنه غافلون

translation: They said, 'If the wolf should eat him while we are a [strong] clan, indeed, we would then be losers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and his brothers. The brothers plotted to get rid of Yusuf by leaving him in a well. They were confident in their plan, but the verse shows their concern that if the worst were to happen (such as Yusuf being eaten by a wolf), they would be viewed as failures. This teaches us that even the best-laid plans can have unintended consequences, and that ultimately, one's actions will have consequences that cannot be avoided.
orig: قالوا لئن أكله الذئب ونحن عصبة إنا إذا لخاسرون

translation: So when they took him [out for hunting] and agreed to put him into the depths of the well... And We inspired to him, 'You will surely inform them [someday] about this affair of theirs while they do not perceive.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (peace be upon him) being thrown into a well by his brothers. One of the key lessons from this verse is the concept of divine wisdom and the unseen plan of God. Despite the immediate difficulty and hardship faced by Prophet Joseph, it was part of God's greater plan to elevate him to a position of honor later in his life. The verse emphasizes that even in times of trial and tribulation, we may not understand the bigger picture or the wisdom behind certain events, but we must trust in God's plan and have faith that everything happens for a reason.
orig: فلما ذهبوا به وأجمعوا أن يجعلوه في غيابت الجب وأوحينا إليه لتنبئنهم بأمرهم هذا وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And they came to their father at night, weeping.
interpretation: This verse tells the story of Prophet Joseph's brothers returning to their father Jacob during the night, crying. It highlights the guilt and remorse they felt after their betrayal of Joseph. It also serves as a reminder of the consequences of jealousy, deceit, and betrayal, emphasizing the importance of honesty, repentance, and seeking forgiveness in Islam.
orig: وجاءوا أباهم عشاء يبكون

translation: They said, 'O our father, indeed we went racing each other and left Joseph with our possessions, and a wolf ate him. But you would not believe us, even if we were truthful.'
interpretation: This verse depicts a scene from the story of Prophet Joseph in the Qur'an, where his brothers lie to their father about his fate. It shows the consequences of jealousy, deception, and the pain caused by the breakdown of family relationships. The verse teaches us about the importance of honesty, trust, and the consequences of our actions.
orig: قالوا يا أبانا إنا ذهبنا نستبق وتركنا يوسف عند متاعنا فأكله الذئب وما أنت بمؤمن لنا ولو كنا صادقين

translation: And they came with false blood on his shirt. [Jacob] said, 'Nay, but your souls have made the matter light for you, but patience is good, and Allah is the One sought for help against that which you describe.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) and how his brothers tried to deceive their father Prophet Jacob (Ya'qub) by showing him Joseph's shirt stained with false blood. This incident reminds us that sometimes people may try to deceive us or make situations appear different from reality, but it is important to have patience and trust in Allah to seek help against false accusations and misunderstandings.
orig: وجاءوا على قميصه بدم كذب قال بل سولت لكم أنفسكم أمرا فصبر جميل والله المستعان على ما تصفون

translation: And there came a company of travelers; then they sent their water-drawer, and he let down his bucket. He said, 'Good news! Here is a boy.' And they concealed him, [taking him] as merchandise; and Allah was knowing of what they did.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an (12:19) tells the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) when he was thrown into a well by his brothers. The travelers later found him, took him out, and sold him as a slave. This verse shows how events unfold according to Allah's plan, even if people's actions might seem unjust or cruel. It conveys the idea that Allah is aware of everything that happens, even if it is hidden from human eyes, and that ultimately, everything is part of a greater divine plan.
orig: وجاءت سيارة فأرسلوا واردهم فأدلى دلوه قال يا بشرى هذا غلام وأسروه بضاعة والله عليم بما يعملون

translation: And they sold him for a reduced price - for a few dirhams - and they were, concerning him, of those content with little.
interpretation: This verse talks about how Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) was sold into slavery by his brothers for a very low price, symbolizing betrayal and greed. It also highlights that despite their actions, they were content with this unjust act, showing how individuals can justify their wrongdoings and remain unrepentant.
orig: وشروه بثمن بخس دراهم معدودة وكانوا فيه من الزاهدين

translation: And the one from Egypt who bought him said to his wife, 'Make his residence comfortable. Perhaps he will benefit us, or we will adopt him as a son.' And thus, We established Joseph in the land that We might teach him the interpretation of events. And Allah is predominant over His affair, but most of the people do not know.
interpretation: This verse narrates the moment when Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) was bought as a slave in Egypt. Joseph's master instructed his wife to treat Joseph well and to make his stay comfortable, with hopes of benefiting from his presence or even adopting him as a son. This incident marked the beginning of Joseph's journey where he eventually became a prominent figure in Egypt. The verse highlights the divine plan behind Joseph's experiences, emphasizing that everything happens under Allah's control and for a higher purpose, even though many people may not fully comprehend or appreciate it.
orig: وقال الذي اشتراه من مصر لامرأته أكرمي مثواه عسى أن ينفعنا أو نتخذه ولدا وكذلك مكنا ليوسف في الأرض ولنعلمه من تأويل الأحاديث والله غالب على أمره ولكن أكثر الناس لا يعلمون

translation: And when he reached his full strength and maturity, We gave him wisdom and knowledge. Thus do We reward the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) in the Qur'an. It indicates that after facing many challenges and trials, when a person reaches maturity and stays steadfast in faith and righteousness, Allah rewards them with wisdom, knowledge, and success. It emphasizes the concept of divine reward for those who are patient and remain good in character despite adversity.
orig: ولما بلغ أشده آتيناه حكما وعلما وكذلك نجزي المحسنين

translation: And she certainly determined [to seduce] him, and he would have inclined to her had he not seen the proof of his Lord. And thus [it was] that We should avert from him evil and immorality. Indeed, he was of Our chosen servants.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an tells the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf), when he was tempted by a woman to commit a sin with her. Despite her attempts to seduce him, Joseph refused due to his faith and righteousness. The verse emphasizes the importance of staying steadfast in faith and morality, and how God's guidance can help one overcome trials and temptations.
orig: وراودته التي هو في بيتها عن نفسه وغلقت الأبواب وقالت هيت لك قال معاذ الله إنه ربي أحسن مثواي إنه لا يفلح الظالمون

translation: And he certainly desired her, and she would have desired him if it were not that he saw the proof of his Lord. And thus [it was] that We should avert from him evil and immorality. Indeed, he was of Our chosen servants.
interpretation: This verse tells the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) when he was tempted by a woman. However, he resisted the temptation, fearing Allah's punishment. This incident highlights the importance of taqwa (God-consciousness) and the reward for maintaining purity and righteousness even in the face of temptations. It shows that Allah supports and protects those who remain steadfast in their faith and devotion to Him.
orig: ولقد همت به وهم بها لولا أن رأى برهان ربه كذلك لنصرف عنه السوء والفحشاء إنه من عبادنا المخلصين

translation: And they both raced to the door, and she tore his shirt from the back, and they found her husband at the door. She said, 'What is the recompense of one who intended evil for your wife but that he be imprisoned or a painful punishment?'
interpretation: This verse speaks about an incident from the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) when he was falsely accused of wrongdoing. It highlights the importance of justice and the consequences for those who intend harm towards others. It serves as a reminder that those who plot evil will face consequences, either by being punished in this world or in the hereafter.
orig: واستبقا الباب وقدت قميصه من دبر وألفيا سيدها لدى الباب قالت ما جزاء من أراد بأهلك سوءا إلا أن يسجن أو عذاب أليم

translation: She said, 'It was he who sought to seduce me.' And a witness from her own household bore witness: 'If his shirt is torn from the front, then she speaks the truth and he is of the liars.'
interpretation: This verse is about the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and how his chastity was challenged. It highlights the importance of evidence and witnesses in determining the truth in any situation. It also emphasizes the consequences of false accusations and the significance of upholding justice and honesty.
orig: قال هي راودتني عن نفسي وشهد شاهد من أهلها إن كان قميصه قد من قبل فصدقت وهو من الكاذبين

translation: And if his shirt is torn from the back, then she has told the truth, and he is of the truthful.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) in the Qur'an, where his brothers plotted against him and tried to convince their father that Yusuf had been eaten by a wolf. However, the torn shirt of Yusuf from the back proved their deceit and Yusuf's innocence. The verse emphasizes the importance of truth and honesty, and that ultimately the truth will prevail over falsehood.
orig: وإن كان قميصه قد من دبر فكذبت وهو من الصادقين

translation: So when he saw his shirt torn from the back, he said, 'Indeed, it is [as] a plot of you women. Indeed, your plan is great.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) who was accused of wrongdoing by the women of the household. The interpretation here is about how individuals may wrongly accuse others and plot against them, as well as the importance of remaining patient and trusting in God's plan during times of difficulty and adversity.
orig: فلما رأى قميصه قد من دبر قال إنه من كيدكن إن كيدكن عظيم

translation: Joseph, turn away from this, and ask forgiveness for your sin. You are indeed one of the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse is advising Joseph to avoid the situation he is in and seek forgiveness for any wrongdoing he might have committed. It serves as a reminder that seeking forgiveness and turning away from sinful behavior is essential when one recognizes their faults and mistakes. It also emphasizes the importance of repentance in Islam.
orig: يوسف أعرض عن هذا واستغفري لذنبك إنك كنت من الخاطئين

translation: And the women in the city said, 'The wife of al-'Azeez is seeking to seduce her slave boy; indeed, she has infatuated him with her love. Surely we see her in clear error.'
interpretation: This verse narrates the story of the wife of the ruler (al-'Azeez) who tried to seduce her slave, but failed due to his righteousness and faithfulness. It serves as a reminder of the moral consequences of succumbing to desires and the importance of staying firm in faith and righteousness.
orig: وقال نسوة في المدينة امرأت العزيز تراود فتاها عن نفسه قد شغفها حبا إنا لنراها في ضلال مبين

translation: So when she heard of their scheming, she sent for them and prepared for them a feast and gave each one of them a knife and said [to Joseph], 'Come out before them.' And when they saw him, they greatly admired him and cut their hands and said, 'Perfect is Allah! This is not a man; this is none but a noble angel.'
interpretation: This verse narrates the story of the women who tried to seduce Prophet Joseph (peace be upon him), but upon seeing his awe-inspiring appearance, they acknowledged his purity and chastity by praising Allah and realizing that he was not an ordinary man, but rather an honorable and noble being.
orig: فلما سمعت بمكرهن أرسلت إليهن وأعتدت لهن متكأ وآتت كل واحدة منهن سكينا وقالت اخرج عليهن فلما رأينه أكبرنه وقطعن أيديهن وقلن حاش لله ما هذا بشرا إن هذا إلا ملك كريم

translation: She said, 'That is the one about whom you blamed me. And I certainly sought to seduce him, but he firmly refused. And if he will not do what I order him, he will surely be imprisoned and will be among the debased.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an depicts a moment where Prophet Yusuf's chastity is tested by the wife of his master. Despite facing temptation and pressure to transgress, Yusuf remains steadfast in his piety and chooses to obey God's commandments. The verse teaches us the importance of resisting temptation and remaining faithful to our beliefs and values even in the face of adversity.
orig: قالت فذلكن الذي لمتنني فيه ولقد راودته عن نفسه فاستعصم ولئن لم يفعل ما آمره ليسجنن وليكونا من الصاغرين

translation: The Lord of the prison said, 'I love more those with whom they are enquiring about me than the enquirers. If you do not avert from me their scheme, I might incline toward them and become one of the ignorant.'
interpretation: This verse shows the humility and trust in God's plan by Prophet Joseph (Yusuf), who remained patient during his time in prison. He expresses that his love is more towards those who remember him and seek guidance, rather than those who try to trap or deceive him. He acknowledges his vulnerability to falling into their deceitful plans if not protected by God's wisdom. It serves as a reminder to prioritize the connection with God and to stay vigilant against deception and ignorance.
orig: قال رب السجن أحب إلي مما يدعونني إليه وإلا تصرف عني كيدهن أصب إليهن وأكن من الجاهلين

translation: So his Lord responded to him and averted from him their plan. Indeed, He is the Hearing, the Knowing.
interpretation: This verse demonstrates that Allah protects His servants from the evil plans of others when they turn to Him in supplication. It reassures us of Allah's attributes of being All-Hearing and All-Knowing, emphasizing His ability to hear our prayers and respond accordingly.
orig: فاستجاب له ربه فصرف عنه كيدهن إنه هو السميع العليم

translation: Then there came to light for them, after they had seen the signs, that which they might recognize as a means of access.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the reluctance of some people to believe even after witnessing clear signs and miracles from God. It shows that some individuals will still be obstinate in their disbelief, despite being presented with undeniable evidence of the truth.
orig: ثم بدا لهم من بعد ما رأوا الآيات ليسجننه حتى حين

translation: And there entered with him [into the prison] two young men. One of them said, 'Indeed, I have seen myself [in a dream] pressing wine.' And the other said, 'Indeed, I have seen myself carrying upon my head [some] bread, from which the birds were eating. Inform us of the interpretation of this, indeed, we see you to be of those who do good.'
interpretation: This verse narrates a scene from the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) when he was in prison and two young men approached him seeking the interpretation of their dreams. It highlights the belief in the ability of righteous and pious individuals, like Prophet Joseph, to have insight and wisdom to interpret dreams and solve problems. It also showcases the importance of seeking guidance from those who are known for their piety and good deeds when seeking answers to challenging issues.
orig: ودخل معه السجن فتيان قال أحدهما إني أراني أعصر خمرا وقال الآخر إني أراني أحمل فوق رأسي خبزا تأكل الطير منه نبئنا بتأويله إنا نراك من المحسنين

translation: He said, "You will not be provided with food that is regularly provided to you, except that I will inform you of its interpretation before it comes to you. That is from what my Lord has taught me. Indeed, I have left a people who do not believe in Allah, and they are disbelievers in the Hereafter."
interpretation: This verse is highlighting Prophet Yusuf's (Joseph) knowledge of interpreting dreams as a gift from Allah. It also conveys his decision to distance himself from disbelievers who deny Allah and the concept of the Hereafter.
orig: قال لا يأتيكما طعام ترزقانه إلا نبأتكما بتأويله قبل أن يأتيكما ذلكما مما علمني ربي إني تركت ملة قوم لا يؤمنون بالله وهم بالآخرة هم كافرون

translation: And I have followed the religion of my fathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. And it was not for us to associate anything with Allah. That is of the favor of Allah upon us and upon the people, but most of the people are not grateful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of holding onto the monotheistic faith followed by the Prophets Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. It emphasizes the rejection of associating partners with Allah and acknowledges the blessings and favor that come from maintaining this pure belief. The verse laments the lack of gratitude shown by many people towards these blessings and the guidance provided by Allah.
orig: واتبعت ملة آبائي إبراهيم وإسحاق ويعقوب ما كان لنا أن نشرك بالله من شيء ذلك من فضل الله علينا وعلى الناس ولكن أكثر الناس لا يشكرون

translation: O my two companions of prison, are separate lords better or Allah, the One, the Prevailing?
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an is reminding us of the oneness and supremacy of Allah. It questions the wisdom of worshiping multiple deities or entities when Allah, the One and the Almighty, is sufficient and superior to all. It emphasizes the importance of monotheism and the belief in the ultimate power and authority of Allah.
orig: يا صاحبي السجن أأرباب متفرقون خير أم الله الواحد القهار

translation: You worship besides Him only names which you have named, you and your fathers, for which Allah has sent down no authority. The command belongs only to Allah; He has commanded that you worship none but Him. That is the right religion, but most people do not know.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the concept of monotheism and the prohibition of associating partners with Allah in worship. It emphasizes that the only legitimate object of worship is Allah, and that the names or entities worshipped besides Him are merely human constructs without any true authority. The verse underscores the importance of following the right religion of worshipping Allah alone, but laments the fact that many people are ignorant of this fundamental truth.
orig: ما تعبدون من دونه إلا أسماء سميتموها أنتم وآباؤكم ما أنزل الله بها من سلطان إن الحكم إلا لله أمر ألا تعبدوا إلا إياه ذلك الدين القيم ولكن أكثر الناس لا يعلمون

translation: O my fellow inmates! As for one of you, he will pour wine for his master to drink; and as for the other, he will be crucified, and birds will eat from his head. The matter has been decreed about which you both inquire."
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an is a story of two prisoners who had dreams and approached Prophet Joseph (peace be upon him) to interpret them. Through these dreams, Allah showed them the outcomes of their deeds in the future. One prisoner was destined to be released and serve a position of honor, while the other was to face a severe punishment of crucifixion. The verse highlights the concept of destiny and the ultimate decree of Allah, showcasing that everything happens according to His will and wisdom.
orig: يا صاحبي السجن أما أحدكما فيسقي ربه خمرا وأما الآخر فيصلب فتأكل الطير من رأسه قضي الأمر الذي فيه تستفتيان

translation: And the one who had been released and was saved remembered after a time, and said, 'I will inform you of its interpretation, so send me forth.' But Satan made him forget the mention [to] his master, so [Joseph] remained in prison several years.
interpretation: This verse from Surah Yusuf (12:42) highlights the concept of reliance on God and the consequences of forgetting to acknowledge Him. It shows that even when people promise to remember God and seek His help, they can be swayed by negative influences such as Satan and forget their duty to their Creator. This story serves as a reminder to remain steadfast in faith and to seek assistance and guidance from Allah in all circumstances, as He is the ultimate source of support and protection.
orig: وقال للذي ظن أنه ناج منهما اذكرني عند ربك فأنساه الشيطان ذكر ربه فلبث في السجن بضع سنين

translation: And the king said, 'Indeed, I have seen [in a dream] seven fat cows being eaten by seven [that were] lean, and seven green spikes [of grain] and others [that were] dry. O eminent ones, explain to me my vision, if you should interpret visions.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a dream that the king had and he sought interpretation from his advisors. It demonstrates the importance of seeking guidance and insight when faced with dreams or visions that may have symbolic meanings. It also emphasizes the significance of interpreting signs and symbols correctly to understand the message being conveyed.
orig: وقال الملك إني أرى سبع بقرات سمان يأكلهن سبع عجاف وسبع سنبلات خضر وأخر يابسات يا أيها الملأ أفتوني في رؤياي إن كنتم للرؤيا تعبرون

translation: They say, 'These are but confused dreams; nay, he has forged it: nay, he is a poet. Let him then bring us a sign even as the former (prophets) were sent.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the response of the disbelievers to the message of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). They rejected his message of the Qur'an as being mere dreams, fabrications, or poetry, refusing to accept it as divine revelation. The verse emphasizes the importance of bringing forth evidence or miracles to prove the truth of the message, similar to the prophets before Muhammad who were also given signs by God to validate their prophethood.
orig: قالوا أضغاث أحلام وما نحن بتأويل الأحلام بعالمين

translation: And the one who was saved among them said, 'I will inform you of its interpretation before it comes to you. Send me.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a person who was given knowledge of interpreting dreams or signs, and he expressed his willingness to share this knowledge with others before its fulfillment/manifestation. It highlights the importance of seeking knowledge, sharing wisdom, and being prepared for the signs and revelations of the divine.
orig: وقال الذي نجا منهما وادكر بعد أمة أنا أنبئكم بتأويله فأرسلون

translation: Yusuf, O truthful one, explain to us about seven fat cows, which seven lean ones ate, and seven green spikes [of wheat] and others [that were] dry - that I may return to the people; perhaps they will know.
interpretation: This verse is from the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) in the Qur'an. Here, Prophet Yusuf is being asked to interpret a dream involving seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean ones, and seven green spikes of wheat and others that were dry. Prophet Yusuf's ability to interpret dreams is highlighted here, emphasizing his wisdom and knowledge. This verse showcases Prophet Yusuf's position and role as a trusted and reliable interpreter sent by God to guide people towards understanding and wisdom.
orig: يوسف أيها الصديق أفتنا في سبع بقرات سمان يأكلهن سبع عجاف وسبع سنبلات خضر وأخر يابسات لعلي أرجع إلى الناس لعلهم يعلمون

translation: He said, "You will plant for seven consecutive years; and what you harvest, leave in its spikes, except a little from which you will eat."
interpretation: This verse is a reminder of the importance of planning for the future and being prepared for times of hardship. It teaches the concept of saving and being mindful of times of scarcity that may follow periods of abundance. It encourages people to be wise in managing their resources and not to consume everything they have without considering the future.
orig: قال تزرعون سبع سنين دأبا فما حصدتم فذروه في سنبله إلا قليلا مما تأكلون

translation: Then there will come after that seven difficult years which will consume what you stored for them, except for a little of what you are preserving.
interpretation: This verse from Surah Yusuf (Chapter 12, Verse 47) refers to a warning and lesson from the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) in the Qur'an. It speaks about a period of abundance followed by a time of difficulty and scarcity. It teaches us the importance of proper planning, moderation, and saving resources for the future, as times of hardship may come unexpectedly. The verse reminds us to be mindful of our actions and to prepare for challenges that may arise in life.
orig: ثم يأتي من بعد ذلك سبع شداد يأكلن ما قدمتم لهن إلا قليلا مما تحصنون

translation: Then there comes after that a year in which people will be given rain and in which they will press grapes.
interpretation: This verse suggests the alternating nature of life's trials and blessings. Just as there are difficult times where people struggle and face hardship, there will also be times of ease and abundance. It reminds believers to remain patient and grateful, knowing that life is a series of ups and downs, and that each phase serves a purpose in the grand scheme of things.
orig: ثم يأتي من بعد ذلك عام فيه يغاث الناس وفيه يعصرون

translation: And the king said, 'Bring him to me.' But when the messenger came to him, [Joseph] said, 'Return to your master and ask him what is the case of the women who cut their hands. Indeed, my Lord is Knowing of their plan.'
interpretation: This verse narrates the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) and how, when presented with false accusations by the women who cut their hands out of infatuation with him, Joseph remains steadfast in his innocence and entrusts his affairs to God, confident that God is aware of the truth and will ultimately protect him. It serves as a reminder of the importance of trust in God's wisdom and justice, even in the face of false allegations and difficulties.
orig: وقال الملك ائتوني به فلما جاءه الرسول قال ارجع إلى ربك فاسأله ما بال النسوة اللاتي قطعن أيديهن إن ربي بكيدهن عليم

translation: The women said, 'What is the reason for this, that you have concerted about Joseph?' She said, 'Perfect is Allah! We know no evil against him.' The wife of Al-Aziz said, 'Now the truth is made manifest! It was I who tried to seduce him, and he is indeed truthful.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an (Surah Yusuf, 12:51) refers to the incident where the wife of Al-Aziz tried to seduce Prophet Joseph (Yusuf), but he resisted her advances out of piety and righteousness. The verse highlights the integrity and truthfulness of Prophet Joseph in the face of temptation and false accusations. It teaches us the importance of steadfastness in faith, even in the midst of trials and difficult situations.
orig: قال ما خطبكن إذ راودتن يوسف عن نفسه قلن حاش لله ما علمنا عليه من سوء قالت امرأت العزيز الآن حصحص الحق أنا راودته عن نفسه وإنه لمن الصادقين

translation: That is so He will know that I did not betray Him in [His] absence and that Allah does not guide the plan of the deceitful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of divine knowledge and guidance. It emphasizes that Allah is aware of all actions, whether hidden or apparent, and that He does not support or guide the deceptive schemes of those who betray His trust. It serves as a reminder that one cannot deceive or outwit the ultimate wisdom and justice of Allah.
orig: ذلك ليعلم أني لم أخنه بالغيب وأن الله لا يهدي كيد الخائنين

translation: And I do not acquit myself. Indeed, the soul is a persistent enjoiner of evil, except those upon which my Lord has mercy. Indeed, my Lord is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse reflects the humble acknowledgment of human weakness and tendency towards evil. It highlights the constant struggle within oneself against the temptations of wrongdoing. However, the mercy and forgiveness of God are emphasized as a source of hope and redemption for those who seek His guidance and repentance. It serves as a reminder of the importance of seeking God's mercy and forgiveness in combating the innate inclinations towards sin.
orig: وما أبرئ نفسي إن النفس لأمارة بالسوء إلا ما رحم ربي إن ربي غفور رحيم

translation: And the king said, 'Bring him to me; I will appoint him exclusively for myself.' And when he spoke to him, he said, 'Indeed, you are today established [in position] and trusted.'
interpretation: This verse talks about a situation where a king is impressed by someone's abilities and character, and decides to appoint him exclusively for himself. The king acknowledges the person's talents and trustworthiness, recognizing that he is established and can be relied upon. This highlights the importance of competence, integrity, and being trustworthy in gaining recognition and opportunities.
orig: وقال الملك ائتوني به أستخلصه لنفسي فلما كلمه قال إنك اليوم لدينا مكين أمين

translation: He (Solomon) said, 'Grant me the ability to manage the resources of this world. Verily, I am a capable guardian.'
interpretation: This verse is a supplication from Prophet Solomon (peace be upon him) asking Allah for the ability to govern and be responsible for the treasures and resources of the earth. It shows his awareness of the responsibility that comes with such authority, and his acknowledgment of his abilities and knowledge given to him by Allah.
orig: قال اجعلني على خزائن الأرض إني حفيظ عليم

translation: And thus did We establish Joseph in the land to settle therein wherever he willed. We touch with Our mercy whom We will, and We do not allow to be lost the reward of the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse describes how Allah granted Prophet Joseph the power and authority to choose where to settle in the land. It emphasizes that Allah's mercy is bestowed upon whomever He wills, and He does not disregard the reward of those who do good deeds. The verse highlights the importance of faith, patience, and righteousness, as exemplified in the story of Prophet Joseph, and shows that Allah's will and mercy are above all.
orig: وكذلك مكنا ليوسف في الأرض يتبوأ منها حيث يشاء نصيب برحمتنا من نشاء ولا نضيع أجر المحسنين

translation: And the Hereafter is better for those who believed and were mindful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of belief and piety in this life, highlighting that the ultimate reward and success lie in the Hereafter for those who have faith in Allah and are conscious of Him in their actions. It serves as a reminder that the true success and ultimate reward are in the Hereafter for the believers who adhere to righteousness and God-consciousness in their lives.
orig: ولأجر الآخرة خير للذين آمنوا وكانوا يتقون

translation: And Joseph's brothers came and presented themselves before him; and he recognized them, but they did not recognize him.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an describes the moment when Joseph's brothers came to him in Egypt seeking food during the time of famine. Though Joseph recognized his brothers, they did not recognize him as he had become unrecognizable from the time they had thrown him into a well and separated from him. This verse underscores themes of forgiveness, redemption, and the eventual reunion of Joseph with his family, as well as the subtleties of fate and destiny woven by the will of God.
orig: وجاء إخوة يوسف فدخلوا عليه فعرفهم وهم له منكرون

translation: And when he had furnished them with their supplies, he said, "Bring me a brother of yours from your father. Do you not see that I give full measure and that I am the best of hosts?
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an refers to a situation where Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) converses with his brothers who had come to him during a time of famine seeking provisions. Joseph, after helping them with their supplies, instructs them to bring their brother from their father, wanting to test their truthfulness and also possibly to reunite with his beloved brother Benjamin. Additionally, Joseph emphasizes his generosity and integrity, highlighting that he fulfills his promises and is a gracious host.
orig: ولما جهزهم بجهازهم قال ائتوني بأخ لكم من أبيكم ألا ترون أني أوفي الكيل وأنا خير المنزلين

translation: So if you do not bring him to me, then no measure will there be for you from me, nor will you approach me.
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the importance of fulfilling promises and obligations. In this context, it refers to a specific situation where a condition is set, and if it is not met, there will be consequences. It serves as a reminder that one should uphold their commitments and responsibilities to avoid negative outcomes.
orig: فإن لم تأتوني به فلا كيل لكم عندي ولا تقربون

translation: They said, 'We will attempt to dissuade his father from him, and indeed, we will do it.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a group of people planning to deceive and manipulate others for their own benefit. It serves as a reminder of the importance of being cautious of those who might try to harm us or lead us astray, and to seek protection and guidance from Allah to avoid falling into their traps.
orig: قالوا سنراود عنه أباه وإنا لفاعلون

translation: And he said to his servants, "Put their merchandise into their saddlebags so they might recognize it when they have gone back to their people that perhaps they will [again] return."
interpretation: This verse refers to a moment in the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) where he instructs his servants to return the goods of his brothers that they had purchased in Egypt. Prophet Joseph does this with the intention of revealing his identity to his brothers and leading them to reflect on their actions and perhaps change their ways. The verse teaches us about forgiveness, reconciliation, and the importance of setting things right even in difficult circumstances.
orig: وقال لفتيانه اجعلوا بضاعتهم في رحالهم لعلهم يعرفونها إذا انقلبوا إلى أهلهم لعلهم يرجعون

translation: When they returned to their father, they said, 'O our father, further measure [of grain] has been denied to us, so send with us our brother [to get grain]; we will be his guardians.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an (12:64) comes from the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) and his brothers. In this part of the story, Joseph's brothers return to their father Jacob (Ya'qub) with a request to send their younger brother Benjamin with them to Egypt. They are trying to resolve a situation where they need more provisions but are being asked to bring their younger brother to prove their honesty. The brothers are demonstrating a sense of responsibility and care for their younger brother by promising to protect him during the journey, showing a form of repentance for their past actions. This verse highlights the importance of family relationships, responsibility, and trust in God's plan in difficult situations.
orig: فلما رجعوا إلى أبيهم قالوا يا أبانا منع منا الكيل فأرسل معنا أخانا نكتل وإنا له لحافظون

translation: He said, 'Shall I entrust him to you except as I entrusted his brother to you before? But Allah is the best guardian, and He is the most merciful of the merciful.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the theme of trust in the ultimate guardianship of Allah. It emphasizes that Allah is the best protector and the most merciful. It serves as a reminder that ultimate trust should be placed in Allah's wisdom and protection, as He is the most compassionate and caring towards His creation.
orig: قال هل آمنكم عليه إلا كما أمنتكم على أخيه من قبل فالله خير حافظا وهو أرحم الراحمين

translation: And when they opened their baggage, they found their merchandise returned to them. They said, 'O our father, what [more] could we desire? This is our merchandise returned to us. And we will obtain food for our family and protect our brother and obtain an increase of a camel's load; that is an easy measurement.'
interpretation: This verse from Surah Yusuf (Chapter 12) describes the moment when Yusuf's brothers found their goods returned to them in their bags after being accused of theft. The brothers are relieved and grateful for the return of their merchandise, which they believe is a sign of divine mercy and protection. They are now able to provide for their family, protect their brother Benjamin, and even gain extra provisions easily. This incident highlights the themes of trust in God's plan, forgiveness, and the unfolding of divine wisdom and mercy in difficult situations.
orig: ولما فتحوا متاعهم وجدوا بضاعتهم ردت إليهم قالوا يا أبانا ما نبغي هذه بضاعتنا ردت إلينا ونمير أهلنا ونحفظ أخانا ونزداد كيل بعير ذلك كيل يسير

translation: He said, 'I will not send him with you until you give me a solemn pledge by Allah that you will certainly bring him back to me, unless you are completely surrounded.' And when they gave him their solemn pledge, he said, 'Allah is the Guarantor over what we say.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the importance of trust and accountability. Prophet Yaqub (Jacob) wanted a solemn pledge from his sons to bring their brother, Prophet Yusuf (Joseph), back to him. This pledge served as a means to ensure that they would fulfill their promise. The statement 'Allah is the Guarantor over what we say' shows a reliance on Allah's oversight and protection in upholding the promise made.
orig: قال لن أرسله معكم حتى تؤتون موثقا من الله لتأتنني به إلا أن يحاط بكم فلما آتوه موثقهم قال الله على ما نقول وكيل

translation: And [Jacob] said, 'O my sons, do not enter from one gate but enter from different gates; however, I cannot save you from Allah at all. The decision is only for Allah. Upon Him, I have relied, and upon Him let those who would rely [indeed] rely.'
interpretation: This verse from Surah Yusuf advises on the importance of taking precautions and not exposing oneself to unnecessary risks. Jacob instructs his sons to enter the city from different gates to avoid drawing undue attention or causing suspicion. At the same time, he reminds them that ultimate protection and security come from Allah alone and it is upon Him that they should place their trust. The verse emphasizes the necessity of combining human effort with reliance on Allah for true success and safety.
orig: وقال يا بني لا تدخلوا من باب واحد وادخلوا من أبواب متفرقة وما أغني عنكم من الله من شيء إن الحكم إلا لله عليه توكلت وعليه فليتوكل المتوكلون

translation: And when they entered from where their father had ordered them, it could not avail them against God at all except [it was a need] within the soul of Jacob, which he satisfied. And he was certainly a possessor of knowledge because of what We had taught him, but most of the people do not know.
interpretation: This verse highlights the story of Prophet Jacob's sons when they entered Egypt as instructed by their father. Despite their father's instructions, their actions could not circumvent the will of God. It emphasizes the importance of following divine guidance and the limited power humans have in the face of God's decree. It also serves as a reminder that true knowledge and wisdom come from God, yet many people remain unaware of this reality.
orig: ولما دخلوا من حيث أمرهم أبوهم ما كان يغني عنهم من الله من شيء إلا حاجة في نفس يعقوب قضاها وإنه لذو علم لما علمناه ولكن أكثر الناس لا يعلمون

translation: And when they entered upon Joseph, he took his brother to himself; he said, "Indeed, I am your brother, so do not despair over what they used to do."
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an tells the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) reuniting with his brothers who had wronged him in the past. It highlights Joseph's forgiveness and compassion as he reassures his brothers, conveying the message of letting go of resentment and embracing forgiveness even in the face of past wrongdoings.
orig: ولما دخلوا على يوسف آوى إليه أخاه قال إني أنا أخوك فلا تبتئس بما كانوا يعملون

translation: And when Joseph had furnished them with their provisions, he put the drinking cup in his brother's saddlebag; then a crier called out, 'O caravan, you are indeed thieves!'
interpretation: This verse refers to a point in the story of Prophet Joseph when he tests his brothers. It highlights Joseph's wisdom and strategy in testing his brothers' honesty and loyalty. By placing the drinking cup in his brother's bag and accusing them of theft, Joseph reveals their true characters and sets the stage for a powerful lesson in forgiveness and redemption.
orig: فلما جهزهم بجهازهم جعل السقاية في رحل أخيه ثم أذن مؤذن أيتها العير إنكم لسارقون

translation: They said, 'And what is it that you are missing?'
interpretation: This verse portrays a scene where the disbelievers challenged the believers by asking them what they were lacking since they believed in Allah. The believers, in response, demonstrated their unwavering faith and trust in Allah, implying that they were not lacking anything by submitting to Him. This serves as a reminder that true believers find completeness and contentment in their faith, and they do not feel deprived or lacking in any way. It highlights the idea that true wealth and happiness lie in faith and devotion to Allah.
orig: قالوا وأقبلوا عليهم ماذا تفقدون

translation: They said, 'We have lost the measure of the king and for whoever brings it is the reward of a camel. And I am responsible for it.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the accountability and responsibility placed on individuals entrusted with tasks. It emphasizes the importance of fulfilling one's duties diligently and the consequences of failing in them. It also underscores the value of honesty and integrity, as well as the concept of rightful reward for completing responsibilities.
orig: قالوا نفقد صواع الملك ولمن جاء به حمل بعير وأنا به زعيم

translation: They said, 'By Allah, you have certainly known that we did not come to cause corruption in the land, and we have not been thieves.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of honesty and integrity in society. The individuals mentioned in this verse are asserting their innocence and denying any intent to cause harm or commit wrongdoing. It serves as a reminder to always speak the truth and uphold one's integrity, even in challenging situations.
orig: قالوا تالله لقد علمتم ما جئنا لنفسد في الأرض وما كنا سارقين

translation: They said, 'Then what is his recompense if you should be truthful?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the disbelievers questioning the Prophet Muhammad about the punishment they will face if they reject his message. The questioning reflects their doubt and disbelief in the consequences of their rejection of the truth. It serves as a reminder of the Day of Judgment and the accountability that all individuals will face for their beliefs and actions.
orig: قالوا فما جزاؤه إن كنتم كاذبين

translation: They said, 'Its recompense is that he in whose bag it is found - he [himself] will be [the penalty for it]. Thus do we recompense the wrongdoers.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that whoever is found with the forbidden item will bear the consequences themselves. It emphasizes the principle of personal responsibility and accountability for one's actions. The wrongful act cannot be shifted to someone else; each individual is responsible for their own deeds and will face the consequences accordingly.
orig: قالوا جزاؤه من وجد في رحله فهو جزاؤه كذلك نجزي الظالمين

translation: So he began [the search] with their bags before the bag of his brother; then he extracted it from the bag of his brother. Thus did We plan for Joseph. He could not have taken his brother within the religion of the king except that Allah willed. We raise in degrees whom We will, but over every possessor of knowledge is one [more] knowing.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph, highlighting how events unfolded according to a divine plan. Joseph's actions were guided by Allah's will and wisdom, even though it may have seemed otherwise. It reminds believers that everything happens by the decree of Allah, and He raises in ranks those whom He wills. Ultimately, Allah's knowledge surpasses all other knowledge.
orig: فبدأ بأوعيتهم قبل وعاء أخيه ثم استخرجها من وعاء أخيه كذلك كدنا ليوسف ما كان ليأخذ أخاه في دين الملك إلا أن يشاء الله نرفع درجات من نشاء وفوق كل ذي علم عليم

translation: They said, 'If he steals - a brother of his has stolen before.' But Joseph kept it within himself and did not reveal it to them. He said, 'You are worse in position, and Allah is most knowing of what you describe.'
interpretation: This verse speaks about a moment in the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) when his brothers accused him of theft. Even though Joseph was innocent, his brothers made false accusations. The verse highlights Joseph's patience and wisdom in handling the situation, choosing not to expose the wrongdoings of his brothers. It emphasizes the importance of holding onto one's integrity and not seeking revenge, leaving matters to be known by Allah who sees and knows all.
orig: قالوا إن يسرق فقد سرق أخ له من قبل فأسرها يوسف في نفسه ولم يبدها لهم قال أنتم شر مكانا والله أعلم بما تصفون
