translation: They said, 'O Aziz, indeed he has a father [who is] an old man, so take one of us in place of him. Indeed, we see you as one of the doers of good.'
interpretation: In this verse, the brothers of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) are suggesting to the Aziz of Egypt (the minister who had brought Yusuf into his home) to imprison one of them instead of Yusuf. It highlights the complex dynamics of family relationships, jealousy, and manipulation. It also shows how people may resort to deceit and sacrifice others for their own gain, even when they perceive themselves as acting in a positive light.
orig: قالوا يا أيها العزيز إن له أبا شيخا كبيرا فخذ أحدنا مكانه إنا نراك من المحسنين

translation: Musa (Moses) said, 'May my Lord be pleased with us! He is our Lord and we will surely return to Him.'
interpretation: This verse reflects Prophet Moses' humble and devout submission to Allah, expressing his reliance on Allah's mercy and guidance. It serves as a reminder for believers to trust in Allah, seek His forgiveness, and acknowledge that all will eventually return to Him for accountability.
orig: قال معاذ الله أن نأخذ إلا من وجدنا متاعنا عنده إنا إذا لظالمون

translation: Then when they despaired of him, they secluded themselves in private consultation. The eldest among them said, 'Do you not know that your father has taken upon you an oath from Allah and [that] before you failed in [your duty to] Joseph? So I will never leave [this] land until my father permits me or Allah decides for me, and He is the best of judges.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of fulfilling oaths and responsibilities towards one's family. The eldest brother reminds the others of the oath their father had taken from them in the past and draws parallels to their previous actions in failing Joseph. He asserts his commitment to not leaving until he receives permission from their father or a decree from Allah, emphasizing the role of divine guidance and acknowledging Allah as the ultimate and best decision-maker.
orig: فلما استيأسوا منه خلصوا نجيا قال كبيرهم ألم تعلموا أن أباكم قد أخذ عليكم موثقا من الله ومن قبل ما فرطتم في يوسف فلن أبرح الأرض حتى يأذن لي أبي أو يحكم الله لي وهو خير الحاكمين

translation: Go back to your father and say, 'O our father, indeed your son has stolen, and we did not testify except to what we knew. And we were not witnesses of the unseen.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) and his brothers. In this part of the story, the brothers of Prophet Joseph admit to their father that their brother had committed theft. The verse emphasizes the importance of speaking the truth based on what is known and not making claims about things that are unseen or unknown.
orig: ارجعوا إلى أبيكم فقولوا يا أبانا إن ابنك سرق وما شهدنا إلا بما علمنا وما كنا للغيب حافظين

translation: And ask the city where We were and [the tribe of] the caravan in which We approached, and indeed, We are truthful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the credibility of the message being delivered by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). The instruction to ask the people of the city and the travelers who passed through to verify the truthfulness of the message serves as a challenge to the disbelievers. The verse highlights the Prophet's honest and sincere delivery of the divine message, indicating that he is indeed a truthful messenger of Allah.
orig: واسأل القرية التي كنا فيها والعير التي أقبلنا فيها وإنا لصادقون

translation: He said, 'Rather, your souls have enticed you to something, so patience is most fitting. Perhaps Allah will bring them to me all together. Indeed, it is He who is the Knowing, the Wise.'
interpretation: This verse reminds us that our own souls can sometimes lead us astray or tempt us into making decisions that may not be the best for us. In times of such challenges and temptations, patience is advised as it is the most appropriate course of action. Through patience and trust in Allah, we may find a resolution and guidance. The verse emphasizes the importance of relying on Allah's wisdom and knowledge in all matters.
orig: قال بل سولت لكم أنفسكم أمرا فصبر جميل عسى الله أن يأتيني بهم جميعا إنه هو العليم الحكيم

translation: And he turned away from them and said, "Oh, how great is my grief for Joseph!" And his eyes became white with sorrow, and he suppressed his grief.
interpretation: This verse describes the despair and sorrow felt by Prophet Jacob upon losing his beloved son, Joseph. It shows the deep emotional pain and grief that Jacob experienced, to the point where his eyes turned white with sorrow. It reminds us of the human aspect of Prophets and their capacity to feel intense emotions such as grief and sadness.
orig: وتولى عنهم وقال يا أسفى على يوسف وابيضت عيناه من الحزن فهو كظيم

translation: They said, 'By Allah, you will not cease remembering Joseph until you become fatally ill or become of those who perish.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the deep impact that the story of Prophet Joseph had on the brothers of Joseph. It shows how they were so affected by his memory and how it consumed their thoughts to the point where they believed it would lead to their demise. It serves as a reminder of the power of remembrance and the consequences of one's actions towards others.
orig: قالوا تالله تفتأ تذكر يوسف حتى تكون حرضا أو تكون من الهالكين

translation: He said, "I only complain of my suffering and my grief to Allah, and I know from Allah that which you do not know."
interpretation: This verse reflects the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) when he was faced with difficulties and challenges. Here, Prophet Yusuf expresses his reliance on Allah by confiding his sorrows and hardships to Him alone. The verse reminds us that turning to Allah in times of distress and seeking solace in Him is a powerful source of strength and comfort. It also emphasizes the knowledge and wisdom that Allah possesses, which surpasses human understanding, highlighting the importance of trust and submission to the divine will.
orig: قال إنما أشكو بثي وحزني إلى الله وأعلم من الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: O my sons, go and find out about Joseph and his brother and do not despair of relief from Allah. Indeed, no one despairs of relief from Allah except the disbelieving people.
interpretation: This verse addresses the sons of Prophet Ya'qub (Jacob), instructing them to go and search for their brother Joseph. It emphasizes the importance of not losing hope in the mercy and help of Allah. It reminds the believers that no matter how difficult the situation may seem, they should always have faith in Allah's ability to provide relief and support. Only those who reject faith and deny the power of Allah are the ones who despair.
orig: يا بني اذهبوا فتحسسوا من يوسف وأخيه ولا تيأسوا من روح الله إنه لا ييأس من روح الله إلا القوم الكافرون

translation: So when they entered upon Joseph, they said, 'O Aziz, adversity has touched us and our family, and we have come with goods poor in quality, so give us full measure and be charitable to us. Indeed, Allah rewards those who give charity.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the plea made by Joseph's brothers when they faced hardship and approached him in a time of need. It portrays a sense of humility and repentance, as they acknowledge their past wrongdoings and ask for help. The verse also emphasizes the importance of being charitable and doing good deeds, as Allah rewards those who help others in difficult times.
orig: فلما دخلوا عليه قالوا يا أيها العزيز مسنا وأهلنا الضر وجئنا ببضاعة مزجاة فأوف لنا الكيل وتصدق علينا إن الله يجزي المتصدقين

translation: He said, 'Did you know what you did with Joseph and his brother when you were ignorant?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) in the Qur'an, where his brothers conspired against him out of jealousy and threw him in a well. The verse serves as a reminder of the consequences of acting out of ignorance and jealousy, emphasizing the importance of reflection before making decisions.
orig: قال هل علمتم ما فعلتم بيوسف وأخيه إذ أنتم جاهلون

translation: They said, 'Are you indeed Joseph?' He said, 'I am Joseph, and this is my brother. Allah has certainly favored us. Indeed, whoever fears Allah and is patient, then indeed, Allah does not allow to be lost the reward of those who do good.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the themes of forgiveness, patience, and trust in Allah's divine plan. It highlights the importance of maintaining piety and perseverance in the face of challenges, reassuring believers that Allah does not overlook the efforts of those who do good and remain steadfast in their faith.
orig: قالوا أإنك لأنت يوسف قال أنا يوسف وهذا أخي قد من الله علينا إنه من يتق ويصبر فإن الله لا يضيع أجر المحسنين

translation: They said, 'By Allah, indeed has Allah preferred you over us, and indeed we have been sinners.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the reaction of the brothers of Prophet Joseph when they realized that despite their ill intentions towards him, Allah had chosen and blessed Prophet Joseph over them. It serves as a reminder that Allah's favor and blessings are not dependent on our merit or actions, but rather on His wisdom and decree.
orig: قالوا تالله لقد آثرك الله علينا وإن كنا لخاطئين

translation: He said, "There is no blame upon you today. Allah forgives you; and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful."
interpretation: This verse highlights the immense mercy and forgiveness of Allah. It reassures the believers that on that day there is no blame upon them, and forgiveness is readily available from Allah, who is the Most Merciful and Compassionate. It serves as a reminder of Allah's boundless mercy and His willingness to forgive His servants when they seek His forgiveness.
orig: قال لا تثريب عليكم اليوم يغفر الله لكم وهو أرحم الراحمين

translation: Take this, my shirt, and cast it over the face of my father; he will become seeing. And bring me your family, all together.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) in the Qur'an. It highlights the miraculous nature of the shirt of Prophet Joseph, which was used to restore the sight of his father, Prophet Jacob (Yaqub). This event demonstrates the power and mercy of God, as well as the importance of trust and faith in the divine plan.
orig: اذهبوا بقميصي هذا فألقوه على وجه أبي يأت بصيرا وأتوني بأهلكم أجمعين

translation: And when they departed, their father said, 'Indeed, I find the smell of Joseph [and would say that he is alive] if you did not think me weakened in mind.'
interpretation: This verse portrays the deep longing and love of Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him) for his son Joseph. Despite the passage of time and distance between them, Jacob's intuition picks up on signs of Joseph's existence and he expresses his belief in the survival of his beloved son. It shows the unwavering trust of a father and his unshakable hope in a reunion with his lost child.
orig: ولما فصلت العير قال أبوهم إني لأجد ريح يوسف لولا أن تفندون

translation: They said, "By Allah, you are certainly in your old error."
interpretation: In this verse, a group is accusing someone of being in a state of old error. The implication is that this person has been consistently mistaken or misguided for a substantial period of time. It serves as a reminder to reflect on our actions and beliefs to ensure that we are on the right path and not stuck in old patterns of error and ignorance.
orig: قالوا تالله إنك لفي ضلالك القديم

translation: So when he came to them with good tidings, he cast it over his face, and then suddenly he regained sight. He said, 'Did I not tell you that I know from Allah that which you do not know?'
interpretation: This verse shows the miraculous restoration of sight to a blind man and his subsequent assertion of his knowledge from Allah. It highlights the power of Allah to grant abilities beyond human comprehension and affirms the wisdom and knowledge bestowed by Allah upon specific individuals.
orig: فلما أن جاء البشير ألقاه على وجهه فارتد بصيرا قال ألم أقل لكم إني أعلم من الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: They said, 'Our father, ask forgiveness for our sins; indeed, we have been sinners.'
interpretation: This verse narrates the statement made by Prophet Ya'qub's sons who admitted their wrongdoing and sought forgiveness from their father. It reflects the humility and acknowledgment of mistakes, as well as the importance of seeking forgiveness from Allah and others when one has committed sins.
orig: قالوا يا أبانا استغفر لنا ذنوبنا إنا كنا خاطئين

translation: He said, 'I will ask forgiveness for you from my Lord. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Nuh (Noah) seeking forgiveness for his people from Allah. It emphasizes the importance of seeking forgiveness and highlights Allah's attributes of forgiveness and mercy towards His creations.
orig: قال سوف أستغفر لكم ربي إنه هو الغفور الرحيم

translation: And when they entered upon Joseph, he took his parents to himself and said, "Enter Egypt, Allah willing, safe [and secure]."
interpretation: This verse showcases the beautiful reunion of Prophet Joseph with his parents after years of separation. It highlights Joseph's compassion and filial love towards his parents by welcoming them with open arms. The phrase 'Enter Egypt, Allah willing, safe [and secure]' indicates Joseph's trust in God's plan and assurance of safety for his family in Egypt. It serves as a reminder of the importance of family bonds, trust in divine decree, and the concept of seeking refuge in God for protection.
orig: فلما دخلوا على يوسف آوى إليه أبويه وقال ادخلوا مصر إن شاء الله آمنين

translation: And he raised his parents upon the throne, and they bowed to him in prostration. And he said, "O my father, this is the explanation of my vision of before. My Lord has made it reality. And He has certainly been good to me when He took me out of prison and brought you [here] from the bedouins after Satan had caused discord between me and my brothers. Indeed, my Lord is Subtle in what He wills. Indeed, it is He who is the Knowing, the Wise."
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an is referring to Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and his recollection of a dream he had where he saw himself elevated in status above others. He interprets the dream for his father as a premonition that one day he would hold a position of power and authority. This dream does eventually come true, as Yusuf is later appointed as a high official in Egypt. The verse highlights the importance of patience, trust in God's plan, and the fact that God is All-Knowing and All-Wise in His decisions and actions.
orig: ورفع أبويه على العرش وخروا له سجدا وقال يا أبت هذا تأويل رؤياي من قبل قد جعلها ربي حقا وقد أحسن بي إذ أخرجني من السجن وجاء بكم من البدو من بعد أن نزغ الشيطان بيني وبين إخوتي إن ربي لطيف لما يشاء إنه هو العليم الحكيم

translation: My Lord, You have given me [something] of sovereignty and taught me of the interpretation of dreams. Creator of the heavens and earth, You are my protector in this world and in the Hereafter. Cause me to die a Muslim and join me with the righteous.
interpretation: This verse reflects the humility and acknowledgment of the dependence of a believer on Allah. It shows gratitude for the knowledge and blessings bestowed by God, seeking His protection, guidance, and ultimately asking for a righteous end and reunification with the pious in the afterlife.
orig: رب قد آتيتني من الملك وعلمتني من تأويل الأحاديث فاطر السماوات والأرض أنت وليي في الدنيا والآخرة توفني مسلما وألحقني بالصالحين

translation: This is of the news of the Unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. You were not aware of it, nor your people, before this. So be patient; indeed, the [best] outcome is for the righteous.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of the Unseen (Ghayb) being revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, by divine inspiration. It emphasizes the idea that the Prophet and his people did not have prior knowledge of these revelations, and therefore required patience and faith. The verse encourages believers to trust in Allah’s wisdom and promises that righteousness will lead to a positive outcome.
orig: ذلك من أنباء الغيب نوحيه إليك وما كنت لديهم إذ أجمعوا أمرهم وهم يمكرون

translation: And most of the people, even if you strive [for it], are not believers.
interpretation: This verse highlights that despite efforts to guide or persuade others towards faith, a significant portion of people will not believe. It serves as a reminder that faith is a personal choice and not everyone will respond positively to efforts to bring them closer to faith.
orig: وما أكثر الناس ولو حرصت بمؤمنين

translation: And you do not ask of them for it any payment. It is not except a reminder to the worlds.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) should not seek any payment or reward from people for delivering the message of the Qur'an. The message itself serves as a powerful reminder for all of creation, and its significance and value should not be measured in material terms but rather in the spiritual guidance it provides to all humanity.
orig: وما تسألهم عليه من أجر إن هو إلا ذكر للعالمين

translation: And how many signs within the heavens and earth do they pass over while they, therefrom, are turning away.
interpretation: This verse reflects on the heedlessness and indifference of some people towards the signs of Allah evident in the universe. Despite being surrounded by numerous signs pointing towards the existence and greatness of the Creator, many choose to ignore or turn away from these signs. The verse underscores the importance of reflecting on the natural world as a means to increase one's faith and deepen their connection with Allah.
orig: وكأين من آية في السماوات والأرض يمرون عليها وهم عنها معرضون

translation: And most of them do not believe in Allah except while they associate others with Him.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of shirk, or associating partners with Allah, which is considered the biggest sin in Islam. It points out that many people claim to believe in Allah, but their faith is tainted by associating partners with Him. The verse serves as a reminder to avoid shirk and to have pure belief in the oneness of Allah.
orig: وما يؤمن أكثرهم بالله إلا وهم مشركون

translation: So do they feel secure from Allah's plan? And coming upon them unexpectedly or the Hour they will not perceive?
interpretation: This verse questions the false sense of security that some people may have regarding the Day of Judgment and the punishment of Allah. It emphasizes that these events can come suddenly and unexpectedly, catching people off guard when they least expect it. It serves as a reminder to remain vigilant and prepared for the Day of Judgment, as it can come at any moment.
orig: أفأمنوا أن تأتيهم غاشية من عذاب الله أو تأتيهم الساعة بغتة وهم لا يشعرون

translation: Say, "This is my way; I invite to Allah with insight, I and those who follow me. And exalted is Allah; and I am not of those who associate others with Him."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of calling people to the path of Allah with knowledge and insight. It reminds believers to stay firm in their faith, to call others to the truth with wisdom and understanding, and to strictly refrain from associating partners with Allah. It highlights the importance of staying devout and committed to monotheism.
orig: قل هذه سبيلي أدعو إلى الله على بصيرة أنا ومن اتبعني وسبحان الله وما أنا من المشركين

translation: And We sent not before you [as messengers] except men to whom We revealed from among the people of cities. So have they not traveled through the earth and observed how was the end of those before them? And the home of the Hereafter is best for those who fear Allah; then will you not reason?
interpretation: This verse reminds believers of the messengers who were sent before, stating that they were also human beings who had received revelation. It urges people to reflect on the past nations and their outcomes, emphasizing that the ultimate abode of the Hereafter is best for those who are mindful of Allah. The verse invites people to ponder and think logically about the consequences of their actions.
orig: وما أرسلنا من قبلك إلا رجالا نوحي إليهم من أهل القرى أفلم يسيروا في الأرض فينظروا كيف كان عاقبة الذين من قبلهم ولدار الآخرة خير للذين اتقوا أفلا تعقلون

translation: And when the messengers had despaired and were certain that they had been denied, Our victory came to them; and whoever We willed was saved. And Our punishment cannot be repelled from the criminal people.
interpretation: This verse reassures the messengers and their followers that despite the challenges and difficulties they face, victory and success will eventually come from Allah. It also emphasizes that Allah's punishment cannot be escaped by those who persist in their wrongdoing and sin.
orig: حتى إذا استيأس الرسل وظنوا أنهم قد كذبوا جاءهم نصرنا فنجي من نشاء ولا يرد بأسنا عن القوم المجرمين

translation: Indeed in their stories, there is a lesson for those of understanding. This is not a fabricated tale, but a confirmation of what came before it, a detailed explanation of all things, and a guidance and mercy for people who believe.
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the importance of reflecting on the stories mentioned in the Qur'an as they contain valuable lessons for those who possess understanding and insight. The Qur'an is not a fictional account but a confirmation of the divine message that preceded it and provides a detailed explanation of various matters. It serves as a guidance and source of mercy for those who have belief and faith.
orig: لقد كان في قصصهم عبرة لأولي الألباب ما كان حديثا يفترى ولكن تصديق الذي بين يديه وتفصيل كل شيء وهدى ورحمة لقوم يؤمنون

translation: That is the Book, there is no doubt about it, a guidance for those conscious of Allah, who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the certainty and truthfulness of the Quran as a guidance from Allah for those who believe in its message. It highlights the qualities of the believers who are conscious of Allah, have faith in the unseen, perform prayers, and engage in acts of charity. The verse also points out that despite the clarity of the message, many people do not believe, showing the importance of faith and conviction in accepting the guidance of the Quran.
orig: المر تلك آيات الكتاب والذي أنزل إليك من ربك الحق ولكن أكثر الناس لا يؤمنون

translation: It is Allah who raised the heavens without any pillars that you can see. Then He settled Himself on the Throne and subjected the sun and the moon, each running to an appointed term. He manages all affairs; He makes the signs clear so that you may have firm belief in the meeting with your Lord.
interpretation: This verse highlights the majesty and power of Allah, who created and sustains the universe. It emphasizes that everything in the heavens and the earth is under His control and runs according to His decree. By observing the signs of Allah's creation, one can strengthen their faith and belief in the Day of Judgment and meeting their Lord. It reminds believers to have certainty in the divine plan and submission to the will of Allah.
orig: الله الذي رفع السماوات بغير عمد ترونها ثم استوى على العرش وسخر الشمس والقمر كل يجري لأجل مسمى يدبر الأمر يفصل الآيات لعلكم بلقاء ربكم توقنون

translation: It is He who spread out the earth and placed therein firmly set mountains and rivers; and from all the fruits He made therein two mates; He causes the night to cover the day. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought.
interpretation: This verse highlights the intricate design and balance in the creation of the earth, with mountains, rivers, and pairs of fruits. It emphasizes the natural cycles and patterns in the universe, calling on people to reflect and ponder on the signs of Allah's existence and wisdom in nature.
orig: وهو الذي مد الأرض وجعل فيها رواسي وأنهارا ومن كل الثمرات جعل فيها زوجين اثنين يغشي الليل النهار إن في ذلك لآيات لقوم يتفكرون

translation: And on the earth are tracts [of land] neighboring and gardens of grapevines and crops and date-palms, [growing] several from a root or otherwise, watered with the same water, but We make some of them exceed others in [quality of] fruit. Indeed in that are signs for a people who reason.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the diversity and abundance of the provisions and blessings that Allah has bestowed upon the earth. It emphasizes the variety of fruits and crops that grow from the land, all nourished by the same water source but yielding different qualities of fruit. The verse invites people to reflect on these signs of Allah's power and wisdom, serving as a reminder for those who are reflective and wise.
orig: وفي الأرض قطع متجاورات وجنات من أعناب وزرع ونخيل صنوان وغير صنوان يسقى بماء واحد ونفضل بعضها على بعض في الأكل إن في ذلك لآيات لقوم يعقلون

translation: And if you wonder, then wondrous is their saying; when we have become dust, shall we indeed be brought forth in a new creation? It is they who disbelieve in their Lord; and they will have shackles on their necks, and they are the inhabitants of the Fire, abiding therein forever.
interpretation: This verse highlights the disbelief of certain individuals who question the concept of resurrection and recreation after death. These disbelievers will face punishment and eternal damnation in the Fire as a consequence of rejecting their Lord and denying the Day of Judgment. They will be shackled in this punishment for their defiance and denial of the truth.
orig: وإن تعجب فعجب قولهم أإذا كنا ترابا أإنا لفي خلق جديد أولئك الذين كفروا بربهم وأولئك الأغلال في أعناقهم وأولئك أصحاب النار هم فيها خالدون

translation: And they urge you to hasten the punishment before the mercy, while there have already been [many] punishments before them. And indeed, your Lord is full of forgiveness for the people despite their wrongdoing, and indeed, your Lord is severe in penalty.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes how some people are hasty in seeking punishment and retribution instead of mercy and forgiveness. It serves as a reminder that despite the wrongdoings of people, God is forgiving and merciful. However, those who persist in their wrongdoing and reject mercy will face a severe punishment. It teaches us about the balance of mercy and justice in the divine plan.
orig: ويستعجلونك بالسيئة قبل الحسنة وقد خلت من قبلهم المثلات وإن ربك لذو مغفرة للناس على ظلمهم وإن ربك لشديد العقاب

translation: And those who disbelieve say, "Why has a sign not been sent down to him from his Lord?" You are only a warner, and for every people is a guide.
interpretation: This verse highlights the complaint of the disbelievers who question why the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) did not receive a miraculous sign from God. The verse clarifies that the Prophet's role is that of a warner, delivering the message of God, and that for each community or nation, there is guidance provided by God tailored to their circumstances.
orig: ويقول الذين كفروا لولا أنزل عليه آية من ربه إنما أنت منذر ولكل قوم هاد

translation: Allah knows what every female carries and what the wombs lose [prematurely] or exceed. And everything with Him is by due measure.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that Allah has complete knowledge and control over all things, including the hidden aspects of creation such as what every female conceives, what is lost during pregnancy, and the exact measure of all things. It highlights the concept of divine wisdom, knowledge, and precision in Allah's management of the universe.
orig: الله يعلم ما تحمل كل أنثى وما تغيض الأرحام وما تزداد وكل شيء عنده بمقدار

translation: The Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
interpretation: This verse describes Allah as the Knower of all that is hidden and all that is witnessed, highlighting His immense knowledge and wisdom. It emphasizes the greatness, power, and wisdom of Allah, underscoring His authority and capability to manage and oversee all matters of the unseen and the seen world.
orig: عالم الغيب والشهادة الكبير المتعال

translation: Whether one hides his thoughts or declares them, whether he is active by night or working by day,
interpretation: This verse reminds believers that Allah is aware of every aspect of their lives. Whether they express their feelings openly or keep them hidden, and whether they are active during the day or night, Allah knows their intentions and actions. It encourages believers to always be mindful of their thoughts and actions, as they are accountable to Allah at all times.
orig: سواء منكم من أسر القول ومن جهر به ومن هو مستخف بالليل وسارب بالنهار

translation: For each one are successive [angels] before and behind him who protect him by the decree of Allah. Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves. And when Allah intends for a people ill, there is no repelling it. And there is not for them besides Him any patron.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of personal responsibility and accountability. It highlights that individuals are constantly protected by angels appointed by Allah, and that change in one's condition is tied to one's inner state and actions. It also points out that when a group of people commit wrong, there is no escape from the consequences appointed by Allah. Ultimately, the verse reminds believers to be diligent in their actions and intentions, for they are under divine protection and guidance.
orig: له معقبات من بين يديه ومن خلفه يحفظونه من أمر الله إن الله لا يغير ما بقوم حتى يغيروا ما بأنفسهم وإذا أراد الله بقوم سوءا فلا مرد له وما لهم من دونه من وال

translation: It is He who shows you the lightning, [causing] fear and hope, and generates heavy clouds.
interpretation: This verse highlights the power and creativity of Allah, who displays natural phenomena like lightning and clouds as signs of His might and mercy. The reference to fear and hope suggests the dual response of believers to such displays of nature – fear of His power and hope in His forgiveness and blessings.
orig: هو الذي يريكم البرق خوفا وطمعا وينشئ السحاب الثقال

translation: And the thunder exalts [ Allah ] with praise of Him - and the angels [as well] from fear of Him. And He sends thunderbolts and strikes therewith whom He wills while they dispute about Allah ; and He is severe in assault.
interpretation: This verse describes the awe and power of Allah as manifested in natural phenomena such as thunder. It illustrates the humility of all creations before Allah, with even the angels in awe and fear of His might. Despite this clear display of power, some people still doubt and argue about Allah, showing their ignorance and arrogance. The verse highlights how Allah's strength and punishment can be swift and severe for those who challenge His authority.
orig: ويسبح الرعد بحمده والملائكة من خيفته ويرسل الصواعق فيصيب بها من يشاء وهم يجادلون في الله وهو شديد المحال

translation: To Him [alone] is the supplication of truth. And those they call upon besides Him do not respond to them with a thing, except as one who stretches his hands toward water [from afar], so he can bring it to his mouth, but it will not reach it. And the supplication of the disbelievers is not but in error.
interpretation: This verse highlights that true supplication and prayer should be directed solely to Allah, as He is the only One who can answer them. Making du'a (supplication) to anything or anyone else is futile, like reaching for water but never getting to drink it. The prayers of the disbelievers are misguided and will not lead them to the right path.
orig: له دعوة الحق والذين يدعون من دونه لا يستجيبون لهم بشيء إلا كباسط كفيه إلى الماء ليبلغ فاه وما هو ببالغه وما دعاء الكافرين إلا في ضلال

translation: And to Allah prostrates whoever is within the heavens and the earth, willingly or by compulsion, and their shadows [as well] in the mornings and the evenings.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the absolute authority of Allah over all creation, stating that everything in the heavens and the earth, whether willingly or by force, submits and prostrates to Allah. It is a reminder of the universal submission and worship to Allah and highlights the inevitability of all creatures ultimately bowing to the will of the Creator, whether they are aware of it or not.
orig: ولله يسجد من في السماوات والأرض طوعا وكرها وظلالهم بالغدو والآصال

translation: Say, "Who is the Lord of the heavens and the earth?" Say, "Allah." Say, "Have you then taken besides Him allies not possessing [even] for themselves any benefit or any harm?" Say, "Is the blind equivalent to the seeing? Or is darkness equivalent to light? Or have they attributed to Allah partners who created like His creation so that the creation [of each] seemed similar to them?" Say, "Allah is the Creator of all things, and He is the One, the Prevailing."
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of the oneness of Allah and His absolute power. It questions the wisdom and logic behind attributing partners to Allah or believing in other deities alongside Him who have no power to benefit or harm themselves or others. It emphasizes the uniqueness of Allah’s creation and categorically states that Allah is the Creator of all things, unmatched in His power and authority.
orig: قل من رب السماوات والأرض قل الله قل أفاتخذتم من دونه أولياء لا يملكون لأنفسهم نفعا ولا ضرا قل هل يستوي الأعمى والبصير أم هل تستوي الظلمات والنور أم جعلوا لله شركاء خلقوا كخلقه فتشابه الخلق عليهم قل الله خالق كل شيء وهو الواحد القهار

translation: He sends down from the sky rain, and valleys flow according to their capacity, and the flood carries a rising foam. And from that [ore] which they heat in the fire, desiring adornments and utensils, is a foam like it. Thus Allah presents examples. For those who have responded to their Lord is the best [reward], but those who did not respond to Him - if they had all that is in the earth entirely and the like of it with it, they would [attempt to] ransom themselves thereby. Those will have a terrible account, and their refuge is Hell, and wretched is the resting place.
interpretation: This verse illustrates the contrast between the superficial and the beneficial. The foam generated by the flood and the useless waste produced in the fire represent the superficial, transient aspects of life that people may chase after seeking adornments and material objectives. However, the beneficial and valuable aspects that truly benefit humanity are like the solid, enduring materials left on the earth. Allah uses these examples to remind believers that ultimately, those who respond to their Lord and focus on what is truly valuable and enduring will be rewarded, while those who are distracted by the temporary and superficial will have a regretful outcome.
orig: أنزل من السماء ماء فسالت أودية بقدرها فاحتمل السيل زبدا رابيا ومما يوقدون عليه في النار ابتغاء حلية أو متاع زبد مثله كذلك يضرب الله الحق والباطل فأما الزبد فيذهب جفاء وأما ما ينفع الناس فيمكث في الأرض كذلك يضرب الله الأمثال

translation: For those who respond to their Lord is the best [reward], but those who do not respond to Him - if they had whatever is in the earth entirely and the like of it with it, they would [attempt to] ransom themselves thereby. Those will have a bad account, and their refuge is Hell - and wretched is the resting place.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of responding to one's Lord, showing that those who respond to Allah's call with good deeds and obedience will be rewarded greatly. Those who neglect or refuse to respond to Him will regret it immensely in the hereafter. It warns about the consequences of neglecting one's duties towards Allah and highlights the severe punishment awaiting those who consciously choose to disobey and disregard their Creator.
orig: للذين استجابوا لربهم الحسنى والذين لم يستجيبوا له لو أن لهم ما في الأرض جميعا ومثله معه لافتدوا به أولئك لهم سوء الحساب ومأواهم جهنم وبئس المهاد

translation: Is he who knows that what has been revealed to you from your Lord is the truth like one who is blind? They will only be reminded who are people of understanding.
interpretation: This verse highlights the stark contrast between those who acknowledge the truth of the revelations from the Lord and those who are blind to it. The people who possess understanding and intellect are the ones who will truly be reminded and guided by the teachings of the Qur'an, whereas those who remain ignorant and reject the truth will continue to be lost in their blindness.
orig: أفمن يعلم أنما أنزل إليك من ربك الحق كمن هو أعمى إنما يتذكر أولو الألباب

translation: Those who fulfill the covenant of Allah and do not break the contract.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of fulfilling promises and agreements made with others, as well as with Allah. It highlights the significance of maintaining trustworthiness, honesty, and integrity in all dealings and relationships, as breaking promises and agreements is seen as a violation of the sacred bond between individuals and Allah. The verse serves as a reminder for believers to uphold their commitments and obligations with sincerity and faithfulness.
orig: الذين يوفون بعهد الله ولا ينقضون الميثاق

translation: And those who join that which Allah has ordered to be joined and fear their Lord and are afraid of the evil of [their] account.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who fulfill the obligations that Allah has commanded to be fulfilled, such as maintaining family ties and connections, and they do so out of fear and reverence for their Lord, aware of the accountability they will face on the Day of Judgment. It emphasizes the importance of not severing family relationships and the significance of being mindful of one's deeds and the consequences in the Hereafter.
orig: والذين يصلون ما أمر الله به أن يوصل ويخشون ربهم ويخافون سوء الحساب

translation: And those who are patient, seeking the countenance of their Lord and establish prayer and spend from what We have provided them, secretly and publicly, and prevent evil with good - those will have the good consequence of [this] home.
interpretation: This verse describes the qualities of those who are patient in their faith, seek the pleasure of their Lord, perform their prayers, give charity openly and in secret, and respond to evil with kindness. It highlights that they will be rewarded with the ultimate good outcome in the Hereafter.
orig: والذين صبروا ابتغاء وجه ربهم وأقاموا الصلاة وأنفقوا مما رزقناهم سرا وعلانية ويدرءون بالحسنة السيئة أولئك لهم عقبى الدار

translation: Gardens of perpetual residence; they will enter them with whoever were righteous among their fathers, their spouses, and their descendants. And the angels will enter upon them from every gate,
interpretation: This verse describes the reward awaiting the righteous inhabitants of paradise. Those who are granted entry into the eternal gardens will be accompanied by their righteous ancestors, spouses, and descendants. Furthermore, the angels will greet them from every entrance, symbolizing the abundant blessings and protection that surround the dwellers of paradise.
orig: جنات عدن يدخلونها ومن صلح من آبائهم وأزواجهم وذرياتهم والملائكة يدخلون عليهم من كل باب

translation: Peace be upon you for what you patiently endured. And excellent is the final home.
interpretation: This verse praises those who have shown patience in the face of hardship or adversity. It assures them that their ultimate abode in the Hereafter will be one of peace and blessings. The verse serves as a reminder to remain steadfast in difficult times and to trust in the ultimate justice and reward of Allah.
orig: سلام عليكم بما صبرتم فنعم عقبى الدار

translation: And those who break the covenant of Allah after its confirmation and sever that which Allah has ordered to be joined and cause corruption on earth - for them is the curse, and they will have the worst home.
interpretation: This verse warns against those who break their covenant with Allah, disregard His commands, and spread corruption on Earth. Such individuals are cursed by Allah and will have a severe punishment awaiting them.
orig: والذين ينقضون عهد الله من بعد ميثاقه ويقطعون ما أمر الله به أن يوصل ويفسدون في الأرض أولئك لهم اللعنة ولهم سوء الدار

translation: Allah extends provision for whom He wills of His servants and restricts for him. Indeed Allah is, of all things, Knowing. They rejoice in the worldly life, but the worldly life is not compared to the Hereafter except [brief] enjoyment.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an emphasizes that Allah is the one who provides sustenance to His servants as He wills. It reminds us that worldly enjoyments and pleasures are temporary and fleeting compared to the eternal rewards of the Hereafter. The verse calls on believers to prioritize their actions with a focus on earning provisions and rewards in the afterlife rather than becoming overly attached to the temporary pleasures of this world.
orig: الله يبسط الرزق لمن يشاء ويقدر وفرحوا بالحياة الدنيا وما الحياة الدنيا في الآخرة إلا متاع

translation: And those who disbelieve say, "Why has a sign not been sent down to him from his Lord?" Say, [O Muhammad], "Indeed, Allah leaves astray whom He wills and guides to Himself whoever turns back [to Him]."
interpretation: This verse addresses the disbelievers who demand a miraculous sign from the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as proof of his message. The response emphasizes that Allah's guidance is not dependent on signs alone; He guides those who sincerely turn to Him and seek guidance, while allowing others to stray according to His will.
orig: ويقول الذين كفروا لولا أنزل عليه آية من ربه قل إن الله يضل من يشاء ويهدي إليه من أناب

translation: Those who have believed and whose hearts are assured by the remembrance of Allah. Unquestionably, by the remembrance of Allah hearts are assured.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of remembering Allah as a source of tranquility and assurance for the believers. It highlights that true peace and contentment of the heart can be found in the remembrance and mindfulness of Allah.
orig: الذين آمنوا وتطمئن قلوبهم بذكر الله ألا بذكر الله تطمئن القلوب

translation: Those who believe and do good deeds, for them there will be happiness and a good destination.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of faith and righteous actions in Islam. It conveys the message that those who have true faith and follow it with good deeds will be rewarded with happiness in this world and a good final destination in the Hereafter. It serves as a reminder for believers to combine their faith with good actions in order to attain success and blessings in both worlds.
orig: الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات طوبى لهم وحسن مآب

translation: Thus We have sent you to a community before which other communities have passed away, so that you may recite to them what We have revealed to you. Yet they deny the Most Compassionate. Say, 'He is my Lord, there is no god but He; I trust in Him, and to Him I turn.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the universal message of Islam brought by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to the people before whom other communities had been sent Prophets. The Prophet is directed to proclaim the Oneness of God despite the denial and rejection by the people, affirming complete trust in God alone while turning to Him in all matters.
orig: كذلك أرسلناك في أمة قد خلت من قبلها أمم لتتلو عليهم الذي أوحينا إليك وهم يكفرون بالرحمن قل هو ربي لا إله إلا هو عليه توكلت وإليه متاب

translation: And if there was a Quran with which the mountains were moved or the earth was split or the dead were spoken to, but indeed, to Allah belongs the matter entirely. Then have those who believed not accepted that if Allah had willed, He would have guided the people, all of them? And those who disbelieve do not cease to be struck, for what they have done, by calamity or it will descend near their home until there comes the promise of Allah. Indeed, Allah does not fail in His promise.
interpretation: This verse highlights the ultimate power and authority of Allah. It emphasizes that there is no limit to what Allah can do or reveal, but guidance ultimately depends on the will of Allah. It also points out the consequences for those who disbelieve and commit wrongdoings, as they will face calamities as a result of their actions. The verse serves as a reminder that Allah always fulfills His promises and that His judgment is inevitable.
orig: ولو أن قرآنا سيرت به الجبال أو قطعت به الأرض أو كلم به الموتى بل لله الأمر جميعا أفلم ييأس الذين آمنوا أن لو يشاء الله لهدى الناس جميعا ولا يزال الذين كفروا تصيبهم بما صنعوا قارعة أو تحل قريبا من دارهم حتى يأتي وعد الله إن الله لا يخلف الميعاد

translation: And certainly were messengers ridiculed before you, but I extended the time for those who disbelieved; then I seized them, and how was My penalty.
interpretation: This verse highlights a recurring pattern in history where messengers of God were mocked and ridiculed by the disbelievers. Despite Allah's patience, eventually, those who disbelieved faced His punishment. The verse serves as a reminder of the consequences of rejecting the messages brought by the messengers of God.
orig: ولقد استهزئ برسل من قبلك فأمليت للذين كفروا ثم أخذتهم فكيف كان عقاب

translation: So is He who is standing over every soul for what it has earned [like any other]? And yet, they have appointed associates besides Allah. Say, 'Name them. Or do you inform Him of that which He knows not upon the earth or of what is apparent of speech?' But rather, their plan has been made attractive to those who disbelieve, and they have been averted from the way. And whoever Allah leaves astray - for him there is no guide.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of accountability for one’s actions, emphasizing that God is fully aware of every individual's deeds. It questions the logic of associating partners with God and challenges the disbelievers to explain or justify their actions. The verse suggests that disbelievers may fall prey to deception and be misguided, warning that those led astray by God will find no guide.
orig: أفمن هو قائم على كل نفس بما كسبت وجعلوا لله شركاء قل سموهم أم تنبئونه بما لا يعلم في الأرض أم بظاهر من القول بل زين للذين كفروا مكرهم وصدوا عن السبيل ومن يضلل الله فما له من هاد

translation: For them is punishment in the life of this world, and the punishment of the Hereafter is more severe. And they will have no protectors against Allah.
interpretation: This verse serves as a warning to those who disobey Allah. It emphasizes that those who commit sins and wrongdoings will face punishment both in this worldly life and in the Hereafter. The consequences in the Hereafter are depicted as more severe, while also highlighting that ultimately, they will have no one to protect them from the judgment and punishment of Allah.
orig: لهم عذاب في الحياة الدنيا ولعذاب الآخرة أشق وما لهم من الله من واق

translation: The example of Paradise, which the righteous have been promised, is [that] beneath it rivers flow. Its fruit is lasting, and its shade. That is the consequence for the righteous, and the consequence for the disbelievers is the Fire.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an describes the image of Paradise that has been promised to the righteous believers. It portrays a beautiful and abundant garden with flowing rivers, eternal fruits, and comforting shade. This description serves as an inspiration and encouragement for the believers to strive for righteousness in order to attain the reward of Paradise. It also serves as a warning to the disbelievers about the consequence of their disbelief, which is the punishment of the Fire.
orig: مثل الجنة التي وعد المتقون تجري من تحتها الأنهار أكلها دائم وظلها تلك عقبى الذين اتقوا وعقبى الكافرين النار

translation: And those to whom We gave the Scripture rejoice at what has been revealed to you, but among the factions are those who deny part of it. Say, "I have only been commanded to worship Allah and not associate anything with Him. To Him I invite, and to Him is my return."
interpretation: This verse highlights the diversity of responses to the revelation of the Quran. Some of the People of the Book (Jews and Christians) rejoice in the message given to Prophet Muhammad, while others from different groups reject parts of it. The Prophet is instructed to remain steadfast in his monotheistic worship of Allah alone, inviting others to do the same, and acknowledging that ultimately, all will return to Allah.
orig: والذين آتيناهم الكتاب يفرحون بما أنزل إليك ومن الأحزاب من ينكر بعضه قل إنما أمرت أن أعبد الله ولا أشرك به إليه أدعو وإليه مآب

translation: And thus We have sent it down as an Arabic judgement. And if you should follow their inclinations after what has come to you of knowledge, you would not have against Allah any ally or protector.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of following the knowledge and guidance revealed by Allah, even if it goes against the inclinations or desires of people. It warns against deviating from the knowledge and succumbing to one's whims, as doing so would mean losing Allah's support and protection.
orig: وكذلك أنزلناه حكما عربيا ولئن اتبعت أهواءهم بعدما جاءك من العلم ما لك من الله من ولي ولا واق

translation: And We certainly sent messengers before you and established for them wives and descendants. And it was not for a messenger to bring a sign [or verse] except by permission of Allah. For every term is a decree.
interpretation: This verse highlights that messengers before the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) were also given families and children. It emphasizes the concept of divine decree and permission, stating that no messenger can bring a sign or verse without the permission of Allah. This verse also underscores the continuity of prophethood throughout different times and the readiness of Allah to guide humanity through appointed messengers.
orig: ولقد أرسلنا رسلا من قبلك وجعلنا لهم أزواجا وذرية وما كان لرسول أن يأتي بآية إلا بإذن الله لكل أجل كتاب

translation: Allah erases what He wills and confirms [what He wills], and with Him is the Mother of the Book.
interpretation: This verse highlights the ultimate authority and power of Allah. He has the ability to erase or nullify anything He desires and to establish and confirm whatever He wills. The 'Mother of the Book' refers to the Preserved Tablet or the Eternal Book in which all decrees and knowledge are recorded. This verse emphasizes that all power and control belong to Allah alone.
orig: يمحو الله ما يشاء ويثبت وعنده أم الكتاب

translation: And if We let you see some of what We promise them, or take you in death, to Us is their return; then, it is upon Us to take their account.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of accountability and justice. It reminds believers that whether they witness the fulfillment of God's promises to disbelievers or experience death themselves, ultimately everyone will be accountable for their deeds on the Day of Judgment, and it is God's responsibility to take account of their actions.
orig: وإن ما نرينك بعض الذي نعدهم أو نتوفينك فإنما عليك البلاغ وعلينا الحساب

translation: Do they not see that We come to the land, reducing it from its borders? And Allah decides; there is no adjuster of His decision. And He is swift in account.
interpretation: This verse highlights the power and authority of Allah in His creation. It vividly describes how Allah can bring destruction to the world, emphasizing His absolute control over everything. The verse conveys a strong message that no one can alter or challenge the decisions made by Allah, and that His judgment is swift and just. It serves as a reminder of the importance of humility and submission to Allah's will, as well as the consequences of disobeying Him.
orig: أولم يروا أنا نأتي الأرض ننقصها من أطرافها والله يحكم لا معقب لحكمه وهو سريع الحساب

translation: And those before them had already plotted, but to Allah belongs the plan entirely. He knows what every soul earns, and the disbelievers will know for whom is the final home.
interpretation: This verse highlights the ultimate plan and knowledge of Allah. It emphasizes that even though individuals may plan and scheme, it is ultimately Allah who has full control over the outcome. Allah is fully aware of the deeds and intentions of every soul, and in the end, the disbelievers will come to know the consequences of their actions and where they stand in the Hereafter.
orig: وقد مكر الذين من قبلهم فلله المكر جميعا يعلم ما تكسب كل نفس وسيعلم الكفار لمن عقبى الدار

translation: And those who disbelieve say, 'You are not a messenger.' Say, 'Sufficient is Allah as witness between me and you, and [the one who has knowledge of] the Book.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that even when faced with disbelief and rejection of their message, the messengers of God should trust in Allah as the ultimate witness to their truth and the truth of their message. It reminds believers that knowledge of the Book (scripture) is a testament to the validity of the message being conveyed. Ultimately, the messengers of God are reassured by the fact that Allah is the ultimate witness of their sincerity and the truth of their mission.
orig: ويقول الذين كفروا لست مرسلا قل كفى بالله شهيدا بيني وبينكم ومن عنده علم الكتاب

translation: Alif, Lam, Ra. [This is] a Book which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], that you might bring mankind out of darkness into the light by permission of their Lord - to the path of the Exalted in Might, the Praiseworthy.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an emphasizes the importance of the guidance provided in the Quran as a means to bring people out of ignorance and darkness and into the light of knowledge and righteousness. It highlights the role of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a guide who, by the permission of God, leads people towards the path of the All-Powerful and Praiseworthy God.
orig: الر كتاب أنزلناه إليك لتخرج الناس من الظلمات إلى النور بإذن ربهم إلى صراط العزيز الحميد

translation: It is Allah who has what is in the heavens and what is on the earth. And woe to the disbelievers from a severe punishment.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the complete ownership and control of Allah over everything in the heavens and the earth. It serves as a warning to the disbelievers of the severe punishment they will face for their rejection of faith and disobedience to Allah's commands.
orig: الله الذي له ما في السماوات وما في الأرض وويل للكافرين من عذاب شديد

translation: Those who prefer the worldly life over the Hereafter, and hinder people from the Path of Allah, seeking to make it crooked—disastrous are they for it in a far-off place.
interpretation: This verse warns against those who prioritize materialistic gains and pleasures of this life over preparing for the Hereafter. They not only deviate themselves but also try to misguide others from the straight path of God. Such individuals are described as being in a state of severe misguidance, distant from the truth and righteousness.
orig: الذين يستحبون الحياة الدنيا على الآخرة ويصدون عن سبيل الله ويبغونها عوجا أولئك في ضلال بعيد

translation: And We sent not a messenger except [speaking] in the language of his people to clarify to them, and Allah sends astray [thereby] whom He wills and guides whom He wills. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that messengers were sent by Allah speaking the language of their people in order to clearly convey the message to them. Allah has the power to guide whom He wills and to lead astray whom He wills. It highlights the divine wisdom and might of Allah in guiding His creation.
orig: وما أرسلنا من رسول إلا بلسان قومه ليبين لهم فيضل الله من يشاء ويهدي من يشاء وهو العزيز الحكيم

translation: And We certainly sent Moses with Our signs, [saying], 'Bring out your people from darknesses into the light and remind them of the days of Allah.' Indeed in that are signs for everyone patient and grateful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the mission of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) and his task to guide his people from ignorance and darkness towards guidance and enlightenment. It emphasizes the importance of patience and gratitude in recognizing the signs of Allah and following His guidance. It serves as a reminder that enduring difficulties with patience and being grateful for blessings lead towards spiritual growth and enlightenment.
orig: ولقد أرسلنا موسى بآياتنا أن أخرج قومك من الظلمات إلى النور وذكرهم بأيام الله إن في ذلك لآيات لكل صبار شكور

translation: And [mention] when Moses said to his people, 'Remember the favor of Allah upon you when He saved you from the people of Pharaoh, who were afflicting you with the worst torment, slaughtering your [newborn] sons and keeping your females alive. And in that was a great trial from your Lord.'
interpretation: Moses reminds his people of the favor of Allah in delivering them from the tyranny of Pharaoh, despite the hardships they faced. The verse emphasizes the importance of remembering Allah's blessings, even in the face of adversity, as trials and difficulties can serve as tests from Allah to strengthen faith and patience.
orig: وإذ قال موسى لقومه اذكروا نعمة الله عليكم إذ أنجاكم من آل فرعون يسومونكم سوء العذاب ويذبحون أبناءكم ويستحيون نساءكم وفي ذلكم بلاء من ربكم عظيم

translation: And [remember] when your Lord proclaimed: "If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe."
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of gratitude in the eyes of Allah. It emphasizes that expressing gratitude leads to an increase in blessings and favors from Allah. On the other hand, ingratitude and denial of Allah's blessings may result in severe punishment. It serves as a reminder for believers to always be thankful for the blessings they receive and to avoid ungratefulness.
orig: وإذ تأذن ربكم لئن شكرتم لأزيدنكم ولئن كفرتم إن عذابي لشديد

translation: And Moses said, 'If you disbelieve, you and whoever is on the earth entirely - indeed, Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy.'
interpretation: This verse from Surah Ibrahim (14:8) conveys that Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) warned the disbelievers of his time that if they choose to reject faith, then God, Allah, is completely independent and free of need from His creation and worthy of all praise regardless of their disbelief. It emphasizes that God's existence and attributes are not affected by the beliefs or actions of humanity.
orig: وقال موسى إن تكفروا أنتم ومن في الأرض جميعا فإن الله لغني حميد

translation: Has there not reached you the news of those before you - the people of Noah and 'Aad and Thamud and those after them? No one knows them but Allah. Their messengers brought them clear proofs, but they put their hands in their mouths and said, 'Indeed, we disbelieve in what you have been sent with, and indeed we are, about that to which you invite us, in disquieting doubt.'
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the pattern of rejection and disbelief shown by the nations of the past towards their messengers. Despite receiving clear signs and messages from Allah through the messengers, they stubbornly refused to believe and instead chose to reject the truth. Their response was filled with doubt and arrogance, even though the message brought to them was clear and convincing. This serves as a reminder for us to reflect on our own response to the signs of Allah and to take heed of the consequences of rejecting the truth.
orig: ألم يأتكم نبأ الذين من قبلكم قوم نوح وعاد وثمود والذين من بعدهم لا يعلمهم إلا الله جاءتهم رسلهم بالبينات فردوا أيديهم في أفواههم وقالوا إنا كفرنا بما أرسلتم به وإنا لفي شك مما تدعوننا إليه مريب

translation: Their messengers said, 'Can there be doubt about God, the Creator of the heavens and the earth? He calls you to forgive you your sins and to grant you respite for a specified term.' They said, 'You are nothing but mortals like us. You only wish to turn us away from what our forefathers used to worship. So bring us clear authority.'
interpretation: This verse depicts a dialogue between the messengers of God and those who disbelieved in them. The messengers emphasize the oneness and power of God, inviting people to seek forgiveness and mercy from Him. The response of the disbelievers highlights their skepticism and demands for clear evidence. The verse underscores the importance of recognizing and submitting to the authority and guidance of God, even when faced with doubt and opposition.
orig: قالت رسلهم أفي الله شك فاطر السماوات والأرض يدعوكم ليغفر لكم من ذنوبكم ويؤخركم إلى أجل مسمى قالوا إن أنتم إلا بشر مثلنا تريدون أن تصدونا عما كان يعبد آباؤنا فأتونا بسلطان مبين

translation: Their messengers said to them, 'We are only men like you, but Allah bestows His grace on whom He wills of His servants. It is not for us to bring you an authority except by the permission of Allah. And upon Allah let the believers rely.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the humility of the messengers of Allah, who are merely human beings like the rest of humanity. They have no power or authority except that which is granted by Allah. It also highlights the importance of relying on Allah for support and guidance, as true believers should place their trust in Him alone.
orig: قالت لهم رسلهم إن نحن إلا بشر مثلكم ولكن الله يمن على من يشاء من عباده وما كان لنا أن نأتيكم بسلطان إلا بإذن الله وعلى الله فليتوكل المؤمنون

translation: And why should we not rely upon Allah while He has guided us to our [good] ways? And we will surely be patient against whatever harm you should cause us. And upon Allah let those who would rely [indeed] rely.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of relying on Allah and trusting His guidance, especially in times of difficulty and adversity. It encourages believers to have patience and perseverance in the face of trials, knowing that Allah will protect and support those who put their trust in Him.
orig: وما لنا ألا نتوكل على الله وقد هدانا سبلنا ولنصبرن على ما آذيتمونا وعلى الله فليتوكل المتوكلون

translation: And those who disbelieved said to their messengers, 'We will surely drive you out of our land, or you must return to our religion.' So, their Lord inspired to them, 'Certainly, We will destroy the wrongdoers.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the resistance faced by the messengers of Allah from the disbelievers who threatened to expel them from their lands if they did not adhere to the disbelievers' beliefs. Here, Allah reassures the messengers that He will ultimately bring destruction upon those who oppress and commit wrong, emphasizing that justice will prevail and the wrongdoers will face the consequences of their actions.
orig: وقال الذين كفروا لرسلهم لنخرجنكم من أرضنا أو لتعودن في ملتنا فأوحى إليهم ربهم لنهلكن الظالمين

translation: And We will surely settle you in the land after them. That is for he who fears My position and fears My threat.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that those who fear and are conscious of Allah's power and warning will be granted authority and security on the earth. It highlights the importance of mindfulness and reverence towards Allah as a means of attaining success and stability in this world.
orig: ولنسكننكم الأرض من بعدهم ذلك لمن خاف مقامي وخاف وعيد

translation: And they will be defeated, every obstinate tyrant.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that no matter how powerful or stubborn a tyrant may be, they will ultimately be defeated and their oppression will not prevail. It serves as a reminder of the ultimate justice of God and the consequences for those who oppress and transgress against others.
orig: واستفتحوا وخاب كل جبار عنيد

translation: from behind him is Hell, and he will be given to drink of purulent water.
interpretation: This verse describes the punishment awaiting those who turn away from the guidance of Allah. They will be faced with the torment of Hell and will be made to drink foul, purulent water as part of their punishment.
orig: من ورائه جهنم ويسقى من ماء صديد

translation: He will sip it (boiling water) but will hardly swallow it. And death will come to him from every place, yet he will not die; and in front of him will be a harsh punishment.
interpretation: This verse describes a scene of punishment where the disbelievers will be made to drink boiling water that will cause excruciating pain. Despite the unbearable agony, they will not find relief in death, as they are doomed to face a severe and continuous punishment.
orig: يتجرعه ولا يكاد يسيغه ويأتيه الموت من كل مكان وما هو بميت ومن ورائه عذاب غليظ

translation: The example of those who disbelieve in their Lord: their deeds are like ashes that the wind blows forcefully on a stormy day, they are unable to keep any of what they have earned. That is the farthest [from the truth],
interpretation: This verse describes the disbelievers as those whose deeds are ultimately worthless and insubstantial, akin to ashes scattered by the wind on a stormy day. Just as the wind disperses ashes, these disbelievers will be unable to benefit from any of their worldly actions on the Day of Judgment. This image conveys the idea that disbelief in God leads to a life devoid of true purpose and meaning, resulting in a state of ultimate loss and misguidance.
orig: مثل الذين كفروا بربهم أعمالهم كرماد اشتدت به الريح في يوم عاصف لا يقدرون مما كسبوا على شيء ذلك هو الضلال البعيد

translation: Do you not see that Allah has created the heavens and the earth in truth? If He wills, He can do away with you and bring forth a new creation.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the absolute power and authority of Allah in creating and recreating the heavens and the earth. It serves as a reminder of Allah's ability to resurrect and recreate all of creation, which highlights the concept of accountability and the Day of Judgment. It also indicates that the power to create and recreate lies solely in the hands of Allah, demonstrating His ultimate control and sovereignty over all aspects of existence.
orig: ألم تر أن الله خلق السماوات والأرض بالحق إن يشأ يذهبكم ويأت بخلق جديد

translation: And that is not difficult for Allah.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the belief that nothing is too difficult or impossible for Allah. It is a reminder that Allah's power and abilities are limitless, and that He is capable of managing and controlling all affairs, no matter how challenging they may seem to human beings.
orig: وما ذلك على الله بعزيز

translation: And they will all be presented before Allah, then the weak will say to those who were arrogant, 'Indeed, we were your followers; so can you avail us anything against the punishment of Allah?' They will say, 'If Allah had guided us, we would have guided you. It is all the same for us whether we show intolerance or are patient: there is no place of escape for us.'
interpretation: This verse highlights a dialogue on the Day of Judgment between the weak followers and their arrogant leaders. The weak followers disassociate themselves from the actions of the arrogant leaders and question if the leaders can protect them from the punishment of Allah. However, the leaders admit their own misguidance and make it clear that had they been guided by Allah, they would have guided the followers as well. Ultimately, it emphasizes that each individual is responsible for their own actions, and there is no escape from accountability before Allah.
orig: وبرزوا لله جميعا فقال الضعفاء للذين استكبروا إنا كنا لكم تبعا فهل أنتم مغنون عنا من عذاب الله من شيء قالوا لو هدانا الله لهديناكم سواء علينا أجزعنا أم صبرنا ما لنا من محيص

translation: And Satan will say when the matter has been concluded, 'Indeed, Allah had promised you the promise of truth. And I promised you, but I betrayed you. But I had no authority over you except that I invited you, and you responded to me. So do not blame me; but blame yourselves. Neither I can be your helper, nor can you be my helper. Indeed, I deny your association of me with Allah before. Indeed, for the wrongdoers is a painful punishment.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the deceitful nature of Satan, who acknowledges that he only has the power to invite and tempt humans but not force them into wrongdoing. Satan acknowledges that he misled people, but ultimately it was the individuals who made the choice to follow him. The verse serves as a reminder that individuals are responsible for their own actions and decisions, and should not place blame on external influences for their wrongdoings. It emphasizes the concept of personal accountability and the consequences of associating partners with Allah, warning of a severe punishment for those who engage in wrongdoing.
orig: وقال الشيطان لما قضي الأمر إن الله وعدكم وعد الحق ووعدتكم فأخلفتكم وما كان لي عليكم من سلطان إلا أن دعوتكم فاستجبتم لي فلا تلوموني ولوموا أنفسكم ما أنا بمصرخكم وما أنتم بمصرخي إني كفرت بما أشركتمون من قبل إن الظالمين لهم عذاب أليم

translation: And admit those who believe and do righteous deeds to gardens beneath which rivers flow, abiding therein eternally by the permission of their Lord; their greeting therein is, Peace.
interpretation: This verse speaks about the rewards for the believers who have faith and perform good deeds. They are promised entry into gardens with rivers flowing beneath them, where they will dwell forever by the permission of their Lord. The verse emphasizes that their greeting in these gardens will be peace, indicating the tranquility and harmony that the believers will experience in the afterlife.
orig: وأدخل الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات جنات تجري من تحتها الأنهار خالدين فيها بإذن ربهم تحيتهم فيها سلام

translation: Have you not considered how Allah presents an example, [making] a good word like a good tree, whose root is firmly fixed and its branches [high] in the sky?
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance and impact of speaking good words, comparing them to a flourishing tree with deep roots and lofty branches. Just as a good tree provides sustenance and benefits to those around it, good words nourish the soul, uplift the spirit, and positively influence others. The verse encourages believers to speak words of kindness, truth, and wisdom that are firmly rooted in the teachings of Islam and reach high, spreading goodness and light to the world.
orig: ألم تر كيف ضرب الله مثلا كلمة طيبة كشجرة طيبة أصلها ثابت وفرعها في السماء

translation: She brings forth her fruit at every time by the leave of her Lord. So Allah sets forth parables for mankind in order that they may remember.
interpretation: This verse illustrates the concept of consistent growth and abundance in creation, highlighting how all living beings receive sustenance and bear fruit with the permission and will of their Creator. By mentioning this process, Allah intends for people to reflect upon the signs in the natural world and be reminded of His power and wisdom, encouraging them to be grateful and mindful of His blessings.
orig: تؤتي أكلها كل حين بإذن ربها ويضرب الله الأمثال للناس لعلهم يتذكرون

translation: And the example of a bad word is like a bad tree, uprooted from the surface of the earth, not having any stability.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an illustrates the analogy of a bad word to a bad tree that has been completely uprooted, indicating that such words have no lasting impact or stability. Just as a tree torn from the ground wilts and withers, harmful and unjust words will eventually lose their power and significance.
orig: ومثل كلمة خبيثة كشجرة خبيثة اجتثت من فوق الأرض ما لها من قرار

translation: Allah keeps firm those who believe, with the firm word, in worldly life and in the Hereafter; and Allah sends astray the wrongdoers. And Allah does what He wills.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of steadfastness and belief in Allah as a means of guidance and support for believers in this life and the hereafter. It also emphasizes that Allah will lead astray those who persist in wrongdoing, while also asserting His complete authority to do as He pleases.
orig: يثبت الله الذين آمنوا بالقول الثابت في الحياة الدنيا وفي الآخرة ويضل الله الظالمين ويفعل الله ما يشاء

translation: Have you not considered those who have changed the favor of Allah to disbelief and settled their people in the house of ruin?
interpretation: This verse is reminding us to reflect on the consequences of those who knowingly reject the blessings and favors of Allah, ultimately leading to their own destruction and the ruin of their community. It serves as a warning against ingratitude and the dangers of turning away from the guidance and blessings of God.
orig: ألم تر إلى الذين بدلوا نعمت الله كفرا وأحلوا قومهم دار البوار

translation: Hell, they will [enter to] burn, and wretched is the resting place.
interpretation: This verse is a reminder of the severe punishment that awaits those who disobey Allah and commit wrongdoings. It highlights the terrifying reality of Hell and serves as a warning to individuals to be conscious of their actions and strive towards righteousness to avoid the dreadful consequences in the afterlife.
orig: جهنم يصلونها وبئس القرار

translation: And they have attributed to Allah equals to mislead [people] from His way. Say, 'Enjoy yourselves, for indeed, your destination is the Fire.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the grave sin of associating partners with Allah, which leads people astray from the path of righteousness. It serves as a warning to those who engage in polytheism and clearly states that their ultimate destination will be the Fire (Hell). It emphasizes the severity and consequences of ascribing partners to Allah.
orig: وجعلوا لله أندادا ليضلوا عن سبيله قل تمتعوا فإن مصيركم إلى النار

translation: Say to My servants who have believed, they should establish prayer and spend from what We have provided them, secretly and publicly, before a day comes in which there will be no trade, nor any friendships.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of prayer and charity in the life of a believer. It encourages believers to not only perform their religious duties but also to contribute from their wealth to help others, both in private and in public. The verse serves as a reminder that earthly possessions are temporary and should be used for the benefit of others before a day comes when material wealth will hold no value.
orig: قل لعبادي الذين آمنوا يقيموا الصلاة وينفقوا مما رزقناهم سرا وعلانية من قبل أن يأتي يوم لا بيع فيه ولا خلال

translation: It is Allah who created the heavens and the earth and sent down rain from the sky, bringing forth thereby fruits as provision for you; and He subjected to you the ships to sail through the sea by His command, and subjected to you the rivers.
interpretation: This verse highlights the power and greatness of Allah by showcasing some of the ways He provides for His creation, such as through creating the heavens and the earth, sending down rain for cultivation, and making ships and rivers accessible for transportation and sustenance. It emphasizes the signs of Allah's mercy and wisdom in the natural world and how He has made resources available for the benefit of humanity.
orig: الله الذي خلق السماوات والأرض وأنزل من السماء ماء فأخرج به من الثمرات رزقا لكم وسخر لكم الفلك لتجري في البحر بأمره وسخر لكم الأنهار

translation: He has subjected for you the sun and the moon, continuously in orbit, and has subjected for you the night and the day.
interpretation: This verse highlights the power and control of Allah over the universe by mentioning His subjection of the sun, the moon, the night, and the day for the benefit of humankind. It serves as a reminder of the order and balance in the natural world created by Allah for human beings to appreciate and benefit from.
orig: وسخر لكم الشمس والقمر دائبين وسخر لكم الليل والنهار

translation: And He gave you from all you asked of Him. And if you should count the favor of Allah, you could not enumerate them. Indeed, mankind is [generally] most unjust and ungrateful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the abundant blessings and favors that Allah bestows upon human beings, fulfilling their needs and desires even when they ask for them. However, Allah's blessings are immeasurable and countless, and no one can truly count or quantify them all. Despite this, human beings often show ingratitude and commit injustices, reflecting their ungrateful and oppressive nature.
orig: وآتاكم من كل ما سألتموه وإن تعدوا نعمت الله لا تحصوها إن الإنسان لظلوم كفار

translation: And [mention] when Abraham said, 'My Lord, make this city [Makkah] secure and keep me and my sons away from worshipping idols.'
interpretation: This verse highlights Prophet Ibrahim's supplication to Allah, requesting the city of Makkah to be safe and free from harm, and asking for protection for himself and his descendants from falling into the worship of idols. It emphasizes the importance of seeking protection from idol worship and maintaining faith in the one true God.
orig: وإذ قال إبراهيم رب اجعل هذا البلد آمنا واجنبني وبني أن نعبد الأصنام

translation: My Lord, indeed they have led many among the people astray. So whoever follows me - then he is of me; and whoever disobeys me - indeed, You are [yet] Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse reflects a prayer of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) by acknowledging the existence of those who have gone astray due to their actions and choices. The verse signifies that those who follow the Prophet are considered part of his community, while those who disobey him have the ability to seek forgiveness and compassion from God, as God is described as Forgiving and Merciful.
orig: رب إنهن أضللن كثيرا من الناس فمن تبعني فإنه مني ومن عصاني فإنك غفور رحيم

translation: Our Lord, indeed I have settled some of my descendants in an uncultivated valley near Your sacred House, our Lord, that they may establish prayer. So make hearts among the people incline toward them and provide for them from the fruits that they might be grateful.
interpretation: This verse is a supplication made by Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) as mentioned in the Qur'an. In his prayer, Ibrahim is seeking Allah's guidance and provisions for his descendants who are settled near the sacred House of worship (the Kaaba). He specifically asks Allah to help them establish prayers and to create a connection between their hearts and the hearts of the people, as well as to provide for their needs so that they may be grateful. This verse reflects the importance of prayer, gratitude, community, and seeking provisions from Allah.
orig: ربنا إني أسكنت من ذريتي بواد غير ذي زرع عند بيتك المحرم ربنا ليقيموا الصلاة فاجعل أفئدة من الناس تهوي إليهم وارزقهم من الثمرات لعلهم يشكرون

translation: Our Lord, You know what we conceal and what we reveal, and nothing is hidden from Allah on the earth or in the heaven.
interpretation: This verse acknowledges the all-encompassing knowledge of Allah, recognizing that He is aware of everything that is hidden or manifest to us, whether on the earth or in the heavens. It emphasizes the concept of the omniscience of Allah, reminding us that we are always in His presence and that nothing escapes His knowledge.
orig: ربنا إنك تعلم ما نخفي وما نعلن وما يخفى على الله من شيء في الأرض ولا في السماء
