It emphasizes the omniscience and all-knowing nature of Allah, reminding the believers that nothing is hidden from Him, and that they should strive to be sincere and truthful in their actions and intentions.
orig: وإن ربك ليعلم ما تكن صدورهم وما يعلنون

translation: And there is no creature hidden in the sky and the earth but that it is in a clear Register.
interpretation: This verse affirms the all-encompassing knowledge of Allah. It emphasizes that nothing is hidden from Him, whether in the heavens or on the earth. Every creature, every action, and every event is recorded in a clear and detailed Record. This serves as a reminder of the accountability and the ultimate justice that will be served on the Day of Judgment, as nothing escapes Allah's knowledge and wisdom.
orig: وما من غائبة في السماء والأرض إلا في كتاب مبين

translation: Indeed, this Qur'an relates to the Children of Israel most of that over which they disagree.
interpretation: This verse highlights that the Qur'an addresses many of the issues that the Children of Israel have differences and disputes about. It serves as a reminder and a guidance for them, aiming to rectify their disagreements and guide them towards the truth.
orig: إن هذا القرآن يقص على بني إسرائيل أكثر الذي هم فيه يختلفون

translation: And indeed, it is guidance and mercy for the believers.
interpretation: This verse conveys that the Qur'an is a source of guidance and mercy for those who have faith. It serves as a roadmap for believers, providing them with the necessary direction and benevolence in their lives.
orig: وإنه لهدى ورحمة للمؤمنين

translation: Indeed, your Lord will judge between them by His [wise] judgment. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Knowing.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that God, being all-powerful and all-knowing, will judge and resolve matters with His perfect wisdom and fairness. It is a reminder of the believers' faith in the divine justice and wisdom of God's decrees.
orig: إن ربك يقضي بينهم بحكمه وهو العزيز العليم

translation: So rely upon Allah; indeed, you are upon the clear truth.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of relying on Allah and trusting in Him completely. It reassures believers that they are on the right path and that they should have faith in Allah's guidance and support. It is a reminder to always trust in Allah's wisdom and follow the straight path without doubt or fear.
orig: فتوكل على الله إنك على الحق المبين

translation: Indeed, you do not make the dead hear, and you do not make the deaf hear the call when they turn their backs retreating.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the limitations of human beings in terms of their abilities. It conveys that no matter how powerful or influential a person may be, they cannot make the dead hear or the deaf listen. It is a reminder of the ultimate powerlessness of mankind in certain matters, highlighting that only Allah has the authority over life and death, and only He can make the dead hear and the deaf listen.
orig: إنك لا تسمع الموتى ولا تسمع الصم الدعاء إذا ولوا مدبرين

translation: And you are not a manager over them to guide the blind ones away from their error. You cannot make hear except those who believe in Our signs, so they surrender.
interpretation: This verse highlights that guidance ultimately comes from Allah, and not from any human being. It indicates that the Prophets can only convey the message, but it is up to individuals to choose to believe and be guided. Those who truly believe in the signs of Allah will willingly submit to His guidance.
orig: وما أنت بهادي العمي عن ضلالتهم إن تسمع إلا من يؤمن بآياتنا فهم مسلمون

translation: And when the word befalls them, We will bring forth for them a creature from the earth speaking to them, 'Indeed, the people had no certainty in Our signs.'
interpretation: This verse conveys the idea that on the Day of Judgment, when the truth and the word of Allah come to pass, a miraculous creature will emerge from the earth and speak to the people, rebuking them for their lack of certainty and faith in the signs of Allah. It serves as a reminder of the importance of having firm belief and conviction in the signs and messages of Allah.
orig: وإذا وقع القول عليهم أخرجنا لهم دابة من الأرض تكلمهم أن الناس كانوا بآياتنا لا يوقنون

translation: And [mention] the Day We will gather from every nation a company of those who deny Our signs, and they will be [driven] in rows.
interpretation: This verse highlights the Day of Judgment when all people will be gathered and sorted based on their belief or disbelief in the signs and revelations of Allah. Those who rejected and denied the signs of Allah will be grouped together, illustrating the accountability and consequence of their actions in the Hereafter.
orig: ويوم نحشر من كل أمة فوجا ممن يكذب بآياتنا فهم يوزعون

translation: Until, when they came [before Allah], He will say, 'Did you deny My signs when you encompassed them not in knowledge, or what [was it] that you were doing?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the accountability and questioning that will occur on the Day of Judgment. It reveals that people will be asked about their denial of the signs of Allah, even though they did not fully understand or comprehend them. It emphasizes the importance of acknowledging and pondering over the signs of Allah in this world, as well as the consequences of turning away from them.
orig: حتى إذا جاءوا قال أكذبتم بآياتي ولم تحيطوا بها علما أماذا كنتم تعملون

translation: And the word will fall upon them for the wrong they have done, and they will not speak.
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Day of Judgment, the wrongdoers will be held accountable for their actions and the consequences of their deeds will be pronounced upon them. They will be left speechless, unable to defend or justify their wrongdoing as they face the consequences of their actions.
orig: ووقع القول عليهم بما ظلموا فهم لا ينطقون

translation: Do they not see that We have made the night for them to rest in and the day giving sight? Surely, in that are signs for people who believe.
interpretation: This verse highlights the harmony and balance in the creation of the night and day by Allah. The night is for rest and tranquility, providing humans with much-needed repose, while the day is full of light, giving clarity and vision. This balance in the alternation of day and night serves as a reminder and a sign for those who believe in the existence and wisdom of Allah.
orig: ألم يروا أنا جعلنا الليل ليسكنوا فيه والنهار مبصرا إن في ذلك لآيات لقوم يؤمنون

translation: And [mention] the Day when the trumpet will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will be terrified except whom Allah wills. And all will come to Him humbled.
interpretation: This verse describes the Day of Judgment when a trumpet will be blown, causing fear and terror among all creatures in the heavens and on earth except those whom Allah wills. It emphasizes that all beings will return to Allah, submitting and humbled. It serves as a reminder of the inevitability of the Day of Judgment and the power of Allah's will.
orig: ويوم ينفخ في الصور ففزع من في السماوات ومن في الأرض إلا من شاء الله وكل أتوه داخرين

translation: And you see the mountains, thinking them rigid, while they will pass as the passing of clouds. [It is] the work of Allah, who perfected all things. Indeed, He is Acquainted with that which you do.
interpretation: This verse speaks about the apparent strength and rigidity of mountains, which many may perceive as permanent and unchanging. However, the verse reminds us that just as clouds move and change, mountains too will pass away according to the will of Allah. It emphasizes the power and perfection of Allah's creation, highlighting His knowledge and awareness of all our actions.
orig: وترى الجبال تحسبها جامدة وهي تمر مر السحاب صنع الله الذي أتقن كل شيء إنه خبير بما تفعلون

translation: Whoever comes [on the Judgement Day] with a good deed will have better than it; and they, from the terror of that Day, will be safe.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the principle of recompense in Islam, stating that whoever brings a good deed on the Day of Judgement will be rewarded with something better than what they did. It also highlights that those who have true faith will be safe from the fright and horror of that significant Day.
orig: من جاء بالحسنة فله خير منها وهم من فزع يومئذ آمنون

translation: And whoever comes with an evil deed - their faces will be overturned into the Fire, [and it will be said], 'Are you recompensed except for what you used to do?'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of accountability in Islam, indicating that those who commit evil deeds will face the consequences of their actions in the Hereafter. It serves as a reminder that individuals will be held responsible for their deeds, and that they will only reap what they have sown in terms of their actions and intentions.
orig: ومن جاء بالسيئة فكبت وجوههم في النار هل تجزون إلا ما كنتم تعملون

translation: Indeed, I have been commanded to worship the Lord of this city, who has made it sacred, and to Him belongs all things. And I have been commanded to be of the Muslims.
interpretation: This verse reflects the essence of Islam, which is the submission and devotion to the one true God, the Creator of all things. It emphasizes the importance of worshiping God and recognizing His authority over all aspects of life. The verse also highlights the significance of obeying God's commandments and being submissive to His will, which are essential elements of being a true Muslim.
orig: إنما أمرت أن أعبد رب هذه البلدة الذي حرمها وله كل شيء وأمرت أن أكون من المسلمين

translation: And to recite the Quran. And whoever is guided is only guided for [the benefit of] himself; and whoever goes astray - say, "I am only [one] of the warners."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of reciting the Qur'an and stresses that guidance ultimately benefits the individual who follows it. If someone strays from the right path, it is the duty of the warners (prophets and messengers) to remind and guide them. Ultimately, everyone is responsible for their own choices and actions.
orig: وأن أتلو القرآن فمن اهتدى فإنما يهتدي لنفسه ومن ضل فقل إنما أنا من المنذرين

translation: And say: "Praise be to Allah, He will show you His Signs, and you will recognise them. For your Lord is not heedless of what you do."
interpretation: This verse encourages believers to praise and thank Allah, as He will reveal His signs to them, leading them to recognise His existence, power, and presence in their lives. It serves as a reminder that Allah is always aware of our actions and not inattentive to what we do, emphasizing the importance of being mindful of our deeds and intentions.
orig: وقل الحمد لله سيريكم آياته فتعرفونها وما ربك بغافل عما تعملون

translation: Tasim.
interpretation: This verse is from the beginning of Surah Al-Qalam in the Qur'an. These Arabic letters are considered as disjointed letters that appear at the beginning of certain chapters of the Qur'an. The exact meaning and interpretation of these letters are known only to Allah. Scholars have different opinions about their significance, with some suggesting they serve as a testimony to the miraculous nature and eloquence of the Qur'an, challenging people to produce something similar if they doubt its authenticity.
orig: طسم

translation: These are the verses of the clear Book.
interpretation: This verse acknowledges the clarity and guidance found in the Qur'an, establishing it as a divine scripture with clear signs and teachings for those who seek knowledge and understanding.
orig: تلك آيات الكتاب المبين

translation: We recite to you from the news of Moses and Pharaoh in truth for a people who believe.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of learning from the stories of the past, such as the struggle between Moses and Pharaoh. It serves as a reminder of the lessons to be learned from history, emphasizing the importance of faith and belief in understanding the messages being conveyed. By reflecting on these stories, believers can draw inspiration, guidance, and wisdom to strengthen their faith and commitment to God.
orig: نتلو عليك من نبإ موسى وفرعون بالحق لقوم يؤمنون

translation: Indeed, Pharaoh exalted himself in the land and made its people into factions, oppressing a faction among them, slaughtering their [newborn] sons and keeping their females alive. Indeed, he was of the corrupters.
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an describes the actions of Pharaoh who was oppressive, unjust, and corrupted. He divided the people, oppressed a group among them, and committed heinous crimes by killing their male children while sparing the females. This verse serves as a reminder of the consequences of tyranny, corruption, and injustice.
orig: إن فرعون علا في الأرض وجعل أهلها شيعا يستضعف طائفة منهم يذبح أبناءهم ويستحيي نساءهم إنه كان من المفسدين

translation: And We will surely bestow favor upon those who were oppressed in the land and make them leaders and make them inheritors.
interpretation: This verse highlights that Allah promises to bestow His favor upon the oppressed individuals in the society. They will be given leadership roles and inheritances as a form of compensation for the injustices they faced. It emphasizes the concept of justice, where those who suffered will be rewarded and elevated in status in the eyes of God.
orig: ونريد أن نمن على الذين استضعفوا في الأرض ونجعلهم أئمة ونجعلهم الوارثين

translation: And We gave them in the land that We showed Pharaoh and Haman and their soldiers through them that which they had feared.
interpretation: This verse highlights the power and authority bestowed upon the believers by Allah, as they were granted success and victory in the land over oppressive rulers like Pharaoh and his followers. It signifies that with strong faith and perseverance, believers can overcome any obstacles and adversaries, even those they fear the most, through the divine support and assistance of Allah.
orig: ونمكن لهم في الأرض ونري فرعون وهامان وجنودهما منهم ما كانوا يحذرون

translation: And We inspired to the mother of Moses, 'Suckle him; but when you fear for him, cast him into the river and do not fear and do not grieve. Indeed, We will return him to you and make him [one] of the messengers.'
interpretation: This verse tells the story of the mother of Moses receiving inspiration to place her infant son in the river in a basket when she feared for his safety. The verse conveys the message that sometimes we need to have faith, courage, and trust in Allah's plan even in the face of difficult situations or seemingly impossible odds. It emphasizes the concept of reliance on Allah and the reassurance that He will protect, guide, and bring back what is meant for us, and that difficult decisions made in faith will ultimately lead to good outcomes.
orig: وأوحينا إلى أم موسى أن أرضعيه فإذا خفت عليه فألقيه في اليم ولا تخافي ولا تحزني إنا رادوه إليك وجاعلوه من المرسلين

translation: So the family of Pharaoh picked him up [out of the river] to become an enemy and a [cause of] grief for them. Indeed, Pharaoh and Haman and their soldiers were sinners.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Moses being found by the family of Pharaoh. It emphasizes the irony of how Pharaoh, Haman, and their followers were oppressive and unjust, despite their powerful positions. It serves as a reminder that ultimately those who transgress and act unjustly will face consequences, despite their worldly power and influence.
orig: فالتقطه آل فرعون ليكون لهم عدوا وحزنا إن فرعون وهامان وجنودهما كانوا خاطئين

translation: And the wife of Pharaoh said, '[He will be] a comfort of the eye for me and for you. Do not kill him; perhaps he may benefit us, or we may adopt him as a son.' And they perceived not.
interpretation: This verse from Surah Al-Qasas tells the story of the conversation that took place between the wife of Pharaoh and her husband regarding Prophet Moses (peace be upon him). The wife of Pharaoh, who believed in Allah, sought to persuade her husband not to kill Moses but to let him live. She saw a potential benefit in sparing his life, either from his help in the future or by adopting him. This verse teaches us about the unexpected ways in which Allah’s guidance and blessings can manifest, even in situations where it may seem unlikely, and the importance of being open to His plans beyond our own perceptions.
orig: وقالت امرأت فرعون قرت عين لي ولك لا تقتلوه عسى أن ينفعنا أو نتخذه ولدا وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And the heart of Moses's mother became empty [of all else]. She was about to disclose [the matter concerning] him had We not bound fast her heart that she would be of the believers.
interpretation: This verse describes the situation of Prophet Moses's mother who was under immense pressure and fear after conceiving him and then hiding him as a baby. She was on the verge of speaking about him, which could have exposed him to danger, but her heart was divinely guided and protected. The verse emphasizes the concept of divine intervention to safeguard believers in critical situations and highlights the theme of trust and reliance on Allah's wisdom and protection.
orig: وأصبح فؤاد أم موسى فارغا إن كادت لتبدي به لولا أن ربطنا على قلبها لتكون من المؤمنين

translation: And she said to his sister, 'Follow him.' So she watched him from a distance while they perceived not.
interpretation: This verse narrates the story of Prophet Moses' (peace be upon him) sister, who was instructed to follow her brother when he was put in a basket and placed in the river. The sister followed the instructions from a distance, not revealing her identity or her relationship to Moses. This shows the cleverness, courage, and trust in Allah's plan that she had, protecting and ensuring her brother's safety without drawing attention to herself.
orig: وقالت لأخته قصيه فبصرت به عن جنب وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And We had forbidden to him [all other] wet nurses before, so she said, 'Shall I direct you to a household that will be responsible for him for you, while they are to him [for his upbringing] sincere?'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an recounts the infant Prophet Moses being rejected by all wet nurses, but ultimately being cared for and raised by his own mother under the protection and guidance of Allah. It showcases how divine intervention can turn a seemingly hopeless situation into one of nurture and care, emphasizing the importance of entrusting our loved ones to those who are sincere and caring.
orig: وحرمنا عليه المراضع من قبل فقالت هل أدلكم على أهل بيت يكفلونه لكم وهم له ناصحون

translation: And We returned him to his mother that she might be content and not grieve and that she would know that the promise of Allah is true. But most of the people do not know.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him). It highlights the mercy and wisdom of Allah in reuniting Moses with his mother to comfort her, assure her of the truth of Allah's promise, and to teach people about His power and wisdom. It serves as a reminder that Allah's promises are always true, even though many may not realize it.
orig: فرددناه إلى أمه كي تقر عينها ولا تحزن ولتعلم أن وعد الله حق ولكن أكثرهم لا يعلمون

translation: And when he reached his full strength and attained maturity, We gave him judgment and knowledge. And thus do We reward the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting how God bestows wisdom and knowledge upon His chosen servants once they reach the peak of their physical and mental capabilities. It emphasizes that the reward for those who do good deeds is not just limited to this world, but will also be granted in the Hereafter by the Most Merciful and Just.
orig: ولما بلغ أشده واستوى آتيناه حكما وعلما وكذلك نجزي المحسنين

translation: And he entered the city at a time of inattention by its people and found therein two men fighting: one from his faction and one from among his enemy. And the one from his faction called for help to him against the one from his enemy, so Moses struck him and [unintentionally] killed him. [Moses] said, 'This is from the work of Satan. Indeed, he is a manifest, misleading enemy.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an narrates a story about Prophet Moses who intervened in a fight to help a man from his own group against an enemy, but ended up unintentionally causing the death of the man from his own faction. After this incident, Moses realizes the gravity of the situation and attributes the act to the influence of Satan, emphasizing the deceptive and misleading nature of the enemy. The verse serves as a lesson about the dangers of impulsiveness, the importance of understanding the full context before taking action, and the recognition of the evil deceptions that may lead one astray.
orig: ودخل المدينة على حين غفلة من أهلها فوجد فيها رجلين يقتتلان هذا من شيعته وهذا من عدوه فاستغاثه الذي من شيعته على الذي من عدوه فوكزه موسى فقضى عليه قال هذا من عمل الشيطان إنه عدو مضل مبين

translation: He said, "My Lord, indeed I have wronged myself, so forgive me.", and He forgave him. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the repentance of Prophet Adam after he acknowledged his mistake and sought forgiveness from Allah. It emphasizes Allah's mercy and forgiveness towards those who repent sincerely, teaching us the importance of admitting our wrongdoings, seeking forgiveness, and trusting in Allah's mercy.
orig: قال رب إني ظلمت نفسي فاغفر لي فغفر له إنه هو الغفور الرحيم

translation: He said, "My Lord, because You have blessed me, I will never be a helper to the criminals."
interpretation: This verse reflects the commitment of the speaker to stand firm against wrongdoing and maintain a distance from those who engage in sinful actions. It exemplifies the importance of staying away from criminal behavior and not aiding or promoting it in any way, even if pressured or tempted to do so.
orig: قال رب بما أنعمت علي فلن أكون ظهيرا للمجرمين

translation: So he left the city, fearful and anticipating [exposure to danger]. And he said, "My Lord, save me from the wrongdoing people."
interpretation: This verse describes a moment of fear and anticipation as Moses leaves the city, seeking protection from the people who were against him. It shows the vulnerability of even the great prophets in moments of danger, and the reliance on God for protection and guidance in times of difficulty.
orig: فأصبح في المدينة خائفا يترقب فإذا الذي استنصره بالأمس يستصرخه قال له موسى إنك لغوي مبين

translation: So when he intended to strike the one who was an enemy to both of them, he said, 'O Moses, do you intend to kill me as you killed someone yesterday? You only want to be a tyrant in the land, and you do not want to be of the amenders.'
interpretation: This verse reflects a situation where Moses is reproached for his actions. It carries a message warning against the desire for tyranny and oppression over others. The verse serves as a reminder to be just and to avoid seeking power and control at the expense of others, emphasizing the importance of working towards righteousness and reform rather than causing harm.
orig: فلما أن أراد أن يبطش بالذي هو عدو لهما قال يا موسى أتريد أن تقتلني كما قتلت نفسا بالأمس إن تريد إلا أن تكون جبارا في الأرض وما تريد أن تكون من المصلحين

translation: And there came a man from the farthest end of the city, running. He said, 'O Moses, indeed the eminent ones are conferring over you, to kill you, so leave [the city]; indeed, I am to you of the sincere advisors.'
interpretation: This verse describes a moment when a man from the farthest end of the city came rushing to warn Prophet Moses of a plot against him by the leaders of the city. The man advised Moses to leave the city for his safety, emphasizing his sincerity and goodwill towards Moses. This serves as a reminder of the importance of sincere advisors and trusting in divine guidance when faced with threats or challenges.
orig: وجاء رجل من أقصى المدينة يسعى قال يا موسى إن الملأ يأتمرون بك ليقتلوك فاخرج إني لك من الناصحين

translation: So he left it, fearful and anticipating. He said, 'My Lord, save me from the wrongdoing people.'
interpretation: This verse describes Prophet Moses leaving the city of Egypt in fear and anticipation, seeking protection from the wrongdoing people. It shows his reliance on God to protect him from harm and deliver him from the oppression and injustice he faced.
orig: فخرج منها خائفا يترقب قال رب نجني من القوم الظالمين

translation: And when he directed himself toward Madyan, he said, 'Perhaps my Lord will guide me to the sound way.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the humility and reliance on Allah that Prophet Musa (Moses) displayed when he found himself lost and uncertain of his path. It teaches us the importance of turning to Allah for guidance and staying hopeful that He will lead us to the right path.
orig: ولما توجه تلقاء مدين قال عسى ربي أن يهديني سواء السبيل

translation: And when he came to the water of Madyan, he found there a crowd of people watering [their flocks], and he found aside from them two women keeping back [their flocks]. He said, 'What is your circumstance?' They said, 'We do not water until the shepherds dispatch [their flocks]; and our father is an old man.'
interpretation: This verse describes the encounter of Prophet Musa (Moses) when he reached the water of Madyan, where he found two women waiting with their flocks, unable to water them due to the presence of other shepherds. The women explain that they have to wait until the shepherds leave before they can water their flocks, revealing respect for order and courtesy. Additionally, they mention their elderly father, emphasizing their care for him and illustrating the value of family and responsibility in Islam.
orig: ولما ورد ماء مدين وجد عليه أمة من الناس يسقون ووجد من دونهم امرأتين تذودان قال ما خطبكما قالتا لا نسقي حتى يصدر الرعاء وأبونا شيخ كبير

translation: So he gave them a drink, and then turned to the shade and said, 'My Lord, indeed I am, for whatever good You would send down to me, in need.'
interpretation: This verse speaks about the Prophet Abraham's compassion and hospitality towards his guests, even though he was in need himself. It emphasizes the importance of being generous and kind to others, even when facing personal challenges or limitations.
orig: فسقى لهما ثم تولى إلى الظل فقال رب إني لما أنزلت إلي من خير فقير

translation: So one of the two women came to him walking with shyness. She said, 'Indeed, my father invites you that he may reward you for having watered for us.' And when he came to him and related the story, he said, 'Fear not. You have escaped from the wrongdoing people.'
interpretation: This verse tells the story of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) when he helped two women water their flocks and in return for his kindness, one of the women invited him on behalf of her father. When Moses met with the father and shared his story, he reassured Moses not to fear, as he had been saved from the wrongdoing people. The interpretation highlights the themes of kindness, trust in God's protection, and the recognition of help and rewards from unexpected sources.
orig: فجاءته إحداهما تمشي على استحياء قالت إن أبي يدعوك ليجزيك أجر ما سقيت لنا فلما جاءه وقص عليه القصص قال لا تخف نجوت من القوم الظالمين

translation: One of the women said, 'O my father, hire him. Indeed, the best one you can hire is the strong and the trustworthy.'
interpretation: This verse from Surah Al-Qasas (28:26) narrates the story of Prophet Musa (Moses) when he arrived at the well of Madyan and helped two women water their flocks. One of the women suggests to her father to hire Musa because of his strength and trustworthiness. The verse highlights the qualities of strength and integrity as being the most desirable when seeking someone for employment or assistance.
orig: قالت إحداهما يا أبت استأجره إن خير من استأجرت القوي الأمين

translation: He said, 'Indeed, I wish to wed [one] of these, my two daughters, to you, on [the condition] that you serve me for eight years; but if you complete ten, it will be [a favor] from you. And I do not wish to put you in difficulty. You will find me, if Allah wills, of the righteous.'
interpretation: This verse reflects a dialogue where a man offers to marry one of his daughters to another man in return for his service for a specific period of time. The verse emphasizes the importance of fulfilling promises and commitments, as well as the concept of mutual benefit and fairness in relationships. It also highlights the belief in divine will, stating that the outcome will be according to what Allah wills. Ultimately, the verse teaches about integrity, patience, and trust in Allah's plans.
orig: قال إني أريد أن أنكحك إحدى ابنتي هاتين على أن تأجرني ثماني حجج فإن أتممت عشرا فمن عندك وما أريد أن أشق عليك ستجدني إن شاء الله من الصالحين

translation: He said, 'That is [established] between me and you. Whichever of the two terms I complete - there is no injustice to me, and Allah, over what we say, is Witness.'
interpretation: This verse indicates a pact or agreement between two parties, where one party declares that whichever of the agreed upon terms is fulfilled first, there will be no wrongdoing or injustice towards the other party. It is a reminder of the importance of keeping promises and fulfilling agreements, as God is a Witness over all that is said and done.
orig: قال ذلك بيني وبينك أيما الأجلين قضيت فلا عدوان علي والله على ما نقول وكيل

translation: When Moses had completed the term and was traveling with his family, he noticed a fire on the side of the Mount. He said to his family, 'Stay here; I have perceived a fire. Perhaps I can bring you a torch from it, or find some guidance at the fire.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an describes the account of Prophet Moses encountering a fire on Mount Sinai and perceiving it as a sign from God. It depicts his curiosity and faith, as he decides to approach the fire to gain insight or guidance. It is a reminder of the importance of being open to divine signs and inspiration in our lives, and the idea of seeking knowledge and guidance from the signs that God places in our path.
orig: فلما قضى موسى الأجل وسار بأهله آنس من جانب الطور نارا قال لأهله امكثوا إني آنست نارا لعلي آتيكم منها بخبر أو جذوة من النار لعلكم تصطلون

translation: But when he came to it, he was called from the right side of the valley in a blessed spot - from the tree, 'O Moses, indeed I am Allah, Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse describes the moment when Moses is called by Allah, Most Exalted, from a blessed place by a tree. The verse highlights the divine communication and emphasizes Allah's authority as the Lord of all existence.
orig: فلما أتاها نودي من شاطئ الواد الأيمن في البقعة المباركة من الشجرة أن يا موسى إني أنا الله رب العالمين

translation: And [He said], 'Throw down your staff.' But when he saw it writhing as if it were a snake, he turned in flight and did not return. [Allah said], 'O Moses, approach and fear not. Indeed, you are of the secure.'
interpretation: This verse describes the encounter between Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) and Allah, where Moses is instructed to throw down his staff, which then turns into a moving snake. Despite being frightened, he is reassured by Allah not to fear, as he is among the secure and protected. This incident highlights the importance of trust and faith in Allah's plan, even in the face of the unexpected and intimidating.
orig: وأن ألق عصاك فلما رآها تهتز كأنها جان ولى مدبرا ولم يعقب يا موسى أقبل ولا تخف إنك من الآمنين

translation: Proceed to Pharaoh and his people for they are indeed transgressors. But speak to him gently; perhaps he may heed the advice or fear God.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of delivering the message of God even to those who are known to be oppressors and wrongdoers. It highlights the significance of using wisdom and gentle persuasion when conveying the truth, as it may lead to positive outcomes and a change of heart in those who are in the wrong. It serves as a reminder to approach even the most difficult individuals with kindness and patience in the hope that they may be guided towards the right path.
orig: اسلك يدك في جيبك تخرج بيضاء من غير سوء واضمم إليك جناحك من الرهب فذانك برهانان من ربك إلى فرعون وملئه إنهم كانوا قوما فاسقين

translation: He said, "My Lord, indeed I have killed one of them, so I fear they will kill me."
interpretation: This verse illustrates the story of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) when he unintentionally killed an Egyptian man who was fighting with an Israelite. Moses immediately turned to Allah seeking forgiveness and protection, showing his fear and remorse for his action. The verse reflects the human vulnerability and fear that even prophets can experience in challenging situations, and the importance of seeking guidance and protection from Allah in times of distress and difficulty.
orig: قال رب إني قتلت منهم نفسا فأخاف أن يقتلون

translation: And my brother Aaron is more eloquent than me in speech, so send him with me as support, verifying me. Indeed, I fear that they will deny me.
interpretation: In this verse, Prophet Musa (Moses) is asking for his brother Aaron to accompany him as a support because he feels that Aaron is more eloquent in speech. Musa is concerned that the people may not believe him or may reject his message, so he seeks Aaron's help in delivering Allah's message effectively.
orig: وأخي هارون هو أفصح مني لسانا فأرسله معي ردءا يصدقني إني أخاف أن يكذبون

translation: He (Moses) said, "We will strengthen your arm with your brother and give you both such authority that they will not be able to touch you. With Our signs, both of you and those who follow you will be victorious."
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an depicts the dialogue between Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) and Pharaoh. It shows how Allah strengthened Moses' resolve by appointing his brother Aaron as his helper and granting them both authority and protection. The verse highlights that when one has faith in Allah and relies on Him, no opposition or challenge can harm them, and victory will eventually be granted to the faithful believers.
orig: قال سنشد عضدك بأخيك ونجعل لكما سلطانا فلا يصلون إليكما بآياتنا أنتما ومن اتبعكما الغالبون

translation: So when Moses brought them Our clear proofs, they said, 'This is nothing but invented magic, and we have not heard of this among our forefathers.'
interpretation: This verse highlights how some people responded to the miracles and signs of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) with disbelief and denial, attributing his miracles to magic or falsehood instead of acknowledging them as signs from God. It emphasizes the resistance of the disbelievers to accept the truth despite clear evidence being presented to them.
orig: فلما جاءهم موسى بآياتنا بينات قالوا ما هذا إلا سحر مفترى وما سمعنا بهذا في آبائنا الأولين

translation: And Musa said, 'My Lord knows best who came with guidance from Him and who will have the best end. Indeed, the wrongdoers will not succeed.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of guidance from Allah and highlights that true success lies in following His guidance. It reminds believers that Allah knows best the intentions and deeds of individuals, and that ultimately, those who engage in wrongdoing will not achieve true success.
orig: وقال موسى ربي أعلم بمن جاء بالهدى من عنده ومن تكون له عاقبة الدار إنه لا يفلح الظالمون

translation: And Pharaoh said, 'O eminent ones, I have not known you to have a god other than me. Then ignite for me, O Hāmān, [a fire] upon the clay and make for me a tower that I may look at the God of Moses. And indeed, I do think he is among the liars.'
interpretation: In this verse, Pharaoh, in his arrogance and disbelief, challenges the existence of any deity other than himself. He commands Hāmān to build a high tower so that he can physically see the God of Prophet Moses, implying a lack of belief in the unseen. Pharaoh's actions and words reflect a state of denial, arrogance, and defiance against the truth.
orig: وقال فرعون يا أيها الملأ ما علمت لكم من إله غيري فأوقد لي يا هامان على الطين فاجعل لي صرحا لعلي أطلع إلى إله موسى وإني لأظنه من الكاذبين

translation: And he and his soldiers were arrogant in the land without right, and they thought that they would not be returned to Us.
interpretation: This verse describes the arrogance of Pharaoh and his followers who transgressed against the truth and oppressed the people. They believed that they would not be held accountable for their actions and that they would not be resurrected to face the consequences before God. The verse serves as a reminder that arrogance and injustice will eventually lead to accountability and that no one can evade the judgment of God.
orig: واستكبر هو وجنوده في الأرض بغير الحق وظنوا أنهم إلينا لا يرجعون

translation: So We seized him and his soldiers and threw them into the sea, and see how was the end of the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse reflects a powerful reminder of the consequences that befall those who commit wrongdoing and oppress others. It serves as a warning that eventual justice will prevail and that the outcomes of the unjust actions will not be favorable. It also emphasizes the ultimate power and authority of God to hold oppressors accountable for their deeds.
orig: فأخذناه وجنوده فنبذناهم في اليم فانظر كيف كان عاقبة الظالمين

translation: And We made them leaders inviting to the Fire, and on the Day of Resurrection they will not be helped.
interpretation: This verse describes those who misguide others and lead them astray from the path of righteousness. They are depicted as leaders in calling people towards hellfire, but despite their leadership in this regard, they will find no support or help on the Day of Judgment. It emphasizes the consequences of misleading others and the ultimate accountability individuals will face for their actions.
orig: وجعلناهم أئمة يدعون إلى النار ويوم القيامة لا ينصرون

translation: And We made them a precedent and an example for the later peoples. And an evil fate awaits them on the Day of Judgment. They are indeed the ones rejected.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the consequences of those who disobeyed God's commands and turned away from the truth. They are deemed as a warning and a lesson for future generations on the Day of Judgment. The individuals described here will face a severe punishment and will be rejected for their actions.
orig: وأتبعناهم في هذه الدنيا لعنة ويوم القيامة هم من المقبوحين

translation: And We certainly gave Moses the Scripture after We had destroyed the former generations as enlightenment for the people and guidance and mercy that perhaps they would be reminded.
interpretation: This verse highlights the significance of divine scriptures as a source of knowledge, guidance, and mercy for humanity. It emphasizes the role of Prophet Moses in delivering the scripture to his people after earlier generations had faced destruction due to their disobedience. The verse stresses the importance of reflecting on the teachings of the scripture as a means to remind oneself of the truth and guidance provided by Allah.
orig: ولقد آتينا موسى الكتاب من بعد ما أهلكنا القرون الأولى بصائر للناس وهدى ورحمة لعلهم يتذكرون

translation: You were not on the western side [of the mount] when We decreed [Moses'] matter, nor were you among the witnesses.
interpretation: This verse is a reminder to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) that he was not present when Allah decreed the matter to Prophet Moses. It serves as a reassurance to Prophet Muhammad that he has been chosen to deliver a new message to his people, just as the previous prophets were chosen by Allah for their respective missions. It emphasizes the fact that the messengers before Muhammad faced similar challenges and opposition, thereby strengthening his resolve in delivering the message of Islam.
orig: وما كنت بجانب الغربي إذ قضينا إلى موسى الأمر وما كنت من الشاهدين

translation: And We had certainly created generations before you, and We prolonged their ages. And you were not living among the people of Madyan, reciting to them Our verses; but it is We who have been sending [this message].
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of divine consistency throughout history in the sending of messengers and revelations to various communities over time. It emphasizes the continuous cycle of guidance being sent down to different generations, demonstrating the mercy and wisdom of Allah in ensuring that every community receives warnings and guidance for their spiritual well-being.
orig: ولكنا أنشأنا قرونا فتطاول عليهم العمر وما كنت ثاويا في أهل مدين تتلو عليهم آياتنا ولكنا كنا مرسلين

translation: And you were not on the side of the Mount when We called [Moses], but [you are sent] as a mercy from your Lord to warn a people to whom no warner had come before you that they might be reminded.
interpretation: This verse highlights the role and mission of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a mercy to humanity. It emphasizes that his prophethood is a blessing and a form of mercy from Allah, as he came to warn those who had not received guidance before. The verse serves as a reminder to people to reflect on the message brought by the Prophet and to take heed of his warnings, leading them towards remembrance and righteousness.
orig: وما كنت بجانب الطور إذ نادينا ولكن رحمة من ربك لتنذر قوما ما أتاهم من نذير من قبلك لعلهم يتذكرون

translation: And if not that a disaster should strike them for what their hands put forth [of sins] and they would say, 'Our Lord, why did You not send us a messenger so we could have followed Your verses and been among the believers?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the response of the disbelievers when faced with hardships and calamities, acknowledging their wrongdoings and wishing for guidance from a messenger to follow the teachings of Allah. It emphasizes the importance of taking heed of the signs and messages from Allah, and the importance of faith and belief in order to avoid such consequences.
orig: ولولا أن تصيبهم مصيبة بما قدمت أيديهم فيقولوا ربنا لولا أرسلت إلينا رسولا فنتبع آياتك ونكون من المؤمنين

translation: Then when the truth came to them from Us, they said, 'Why is he not given the like of what was given to Moses?' Did they not disbelieve in what was given to Moses before? They said, 'Two works of magic supporting each other.' And they said, 'Indeed, we are disbelievers in all.'
interpretation: This verse highlights how some people, when presented with the truth that came from God, choose to question and disbelieve instead of embracing it. They also make false accusations and claim that the miracles shown are simply acts of magic. The verse warns against stubborn disbelief and the tendency to dismiss the truth while being fully aware of it.
orig: فلما جاءهم الحق من عندنا قالوا لولا أوتي مثل ما أوتي موسى أولم يكفروا بما أوتي موسى من قبل قالوا سحران تظاهرا وقالوا إنا بكل كافرون

translation: Say, 'Then bring a scripture from Allah which is more guiding than either of them that I may follow it, if you should be truthful.'
interpretation: This verse challenges those who doubt the Quran's authenticity to produce a scripture superior in guidance. It emphasizes the Quran's unparalleled guidance and refuses to compromise on its divine origin. It underscores the truthfulness and supremacy of the Quran as a guiding light for humanity.
orig: قل فأتوا بكتاب من عند الله هو أهدى منهما أتبعه إن كنتم صادقين

translation: So if they do not respond to you, then know that they only follow their desires. And who is more astray than one who follows his desire without guidance from Allah? Indeed, Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of following divine guidance over personal desires. It emphasizes that those who choose to follow their own whims and desires without seeking guidance from Allah are in a state of misguidance. It serves as a reminder that Allah does not guide those who commit wrongdoing and injustice.
orig: فإن لم يستجيبوا لك فاعلم أنما يتبعون أهواءهم ومن أضل ممن اتبع هواه بغير هدى من الله إن الله لا يهدي القوم الظالمين

translation: And We have certainly made the Qur'an easy for remembrance, so is there any who will remember?
interpretation: This verse highlights the accessibility and clarity of the Qur'an, as it is made easy to remember and reflect upon. It calls upon the believers to engage with the Qur'an, to ponder over its verses, and to take heed of its guidance in order to be reminded and guided towards the right path.
orig: ولقد وصلنا لهم القول لعلهم يتذكرون

translation: Those to whom We gave the Scripture before it - they are believers in it.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the importance of faith and belief in the previous scriptures that were revealed by Allah. It emphasizes that those who were given these scriptures should have faith in them as they are from Allah. It underscores the continuity and unity of the message across different revelations.
orig: الذين آتيناهم الكتاب من قبله هم به يؤمنون

translation: And when it is recited to them, they say, 'We have believed in it; indeed, it is the truth from our Lord. Indeed, we were [even] before it Muslims.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of recognizing the truth when it is revealed and acknowledging one's belief. It emphasizes the continuity of faith by mentioning that they were Muslims even before the revelation, showing the consistency of submission to God's will.
orig: وإذا يتلى عليهم قالوا آمنا به إنه الحق من ربنا إنا كنا من قبله مسلمين

translation: Those will be given their reward twice for what they patiently endured and repel evil with good, and spend [in the way of Allah] out of what We have provided them.
interpretation: This verse highlights the reward for those who endure trials with patience, respond to evil with goodness, and spend from their provisions in the way of God. It emphasizes the importance of perseverance, benevolence, and charity as virtues that are rewarded by Allah.
orig: أولئك يؤتون أجرهم مرتين بما صبروا ويدرءون بالحسنة السيئة ومما رزقناهم ينفقون

translation: And when they hear ill speech, they turn away from it and say, 'For us are our deeds, and for you are your deeds. Peace be upon you; we seek not the ignorant.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of avoiding engaging in idle talk or immoral conversations. Believers are advised to distance themselves from such negativity and remain focused on their own actions and responsibilities. It also teaches the importance of maintaining peace and not seeking conflict with those who are ignorant or disrespectful.
orig: وإذا سمعوا اللغو أعرضوا عنه وقالوا لنا أعمالنا ولكم أعمالكم سلام عليكم لا نبتغي الجاهلين

translation: Verily, you do not guide whom you love, but Allah guides whom He wills, and He knows best those who are guided.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the ultimate power and control that Allah has over guidance. It reminds believers that they do not have the ability to guide others on their own, as guidance ultimately comes from Allah. It serves as a reminder to trust in Allah's wisdom and sovereignty, knowing that He has perfect knowledge of those who choose to be guided.
orig: إنك لا تهدي من أحببت ولكن الله يهدي من يشاء وهو أعلم بالمهتدين

translation: And they say, 'If we were to follow the guidance with you, we would be snatched away from our land.' Have We not established for them a safe sanctuary to which are brought the fruits of all things as provision from Us? But most of them do not know.
interpretation: This verse highlights the ignorance and ingratitude of those who reject guidance and fear losing their material possessions or status by following the truth. The verse emphasizes that Allah has provided for them abundantly and securely, yet they fail to recognize it. It serves as a reminder that true guidance and sustenance come from Allah, and those who reject it do so out of ignorance.
orig: وقالوا إن نتبع الهدى معك نتخطف من أرضنا أولم نمكن لهم حرما آمنا يجبى إليه ثمرات كل شيء رزقا من لدنا ولكن أكثرهم لا يعلمون

translation: And how many a city have We destroyed, and it was their dwelling place which was not inhabited after them except for a little. And it is We who were the inheritors.
interpretation: This verse reminds us of the past nations and cities that were destroyed as a consequence of their disobedience to God. It serves as a warning of the consequences of wrongdoing and not following the path of righteousness. The verse highlights the transient nature of worldly possessions and the ultimate control Allah has over all things, including inheritance of the earth after the destruction of those who transgressed.
orig: وكم أهلكنا من قرية بطرت معيشتها فتلك مساكنهم لم تسكن من بعدهم إلا قليلا وكنا نحن الوارثين

translation: And your Lord does not destroy the towns until He sends a messenger to their mother town reciting to them Our signs. And We would not destroy the towns unless their people are wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that God's punishment is not decreed upon a town until it has received a messenger who recites the signs of God to them. It underscores the principle of justice that underpins God's actions; destruction is not unjustly inflicted but comes as a result of the wrongdoing and transgressions committed by the people of those towns.
orig: وما كان ربك مهلك القرى حتى يبعث في أمها رسولا يتلو عليهم آياتنا وما كنا مهلكي القرى إلا وأهلها ظالمون

translation: And whatever you have been given is [only for] the enjoyment of the worldly life and its adornment. And what is with Allah is better and more lasting; then, will you not reason?
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an reminds us that the resources and pleasures of this worldly life are temporary and fleeting. True value lies in what is with Allah, which is far better and everlasting. It urges us to use our intellect and understanding to prioritize the eternal over the temporary pleasures of this world.
orig: وما أوتيتم من شيء فمتاع الحياة الدنيا وزينتها وما عند الله خير وأبقى أفلا تعقلون

translation: Is one to whom We have promised a good promise which he will meet [i.e., receive] like one whom We provided with the enjoyment of worldly life but then he is, on the Day of Resurrection, among those presented [for punishment]?
interpretation: This verse questions the validity and significance of the promises and pleasures of this worldly life in comparison to the promise of the Hereafter. It emphasizes the importance of being mindful of one's actions and dedicating oneself to meeting the good promise of Allah, instead of being distracted by temporary worldly pleasures that hold no value in the Hereafter.
orig: أفمن وعدناه وعدا حسنا فهو لاقيه كمن متعناه متاع الحياة الدنيا ثم هو يوم القيامة من المحضرين

translation: And [mention] the Day He will call them and say, "Where are My 'partners' which you used to claim?"
interpretation: This verse speaks about the Day of Judgment when people will be called to account for their beliefs and actions. On that day, the disbelievers and polytheists will be asked about the false gods they worshiped besides Allah. It highlights the falsehood of associating partners with Allah and the accountability every individual will face for their choices.
orig: ويوم يناديهم فيقول أين شركائي الذين كنتم تزعمون

translation: Those upon whom the word will have come into effect will say, 'Our Lord, these are the ones we led astray. We led them astray just as we were astray ourselves. We declare our innocence before You: it was not us that they worshipped.'
interpretation: This verse highlights a scene on the Day of Judgment where those who were misled by others will disassociate themselves from their misguided leaders. It emphasizes individual accountability and the inability of one person to bear the burden of another's sins. It serves as a reminder that each person is responsible for their own actions and choices, and will not be held accountable for the actions of others.
orig: قال الذين حق عليهم القول ربنا هؤلاء الذين أغوينا أغويناهم كما غوينا تبرأنا إليك ما كانوا إيانا يعبدون

translation: And it will be said, 'Call upon your partners,' and they will invoke them but they will not respond to them, and they will see the punishment. If only they had followed guidance!
interpretation: This verse illustrates the futility of invoking false gods or partners alongside Allah. It emphasizes that those who worship anything other than the one true God will find that their false deities will be of no help or benefit to them. The verse also points out that those who do not follow the true guidance will ultimately see the consequences of their misguided beliefs and actions.
orig: وقيل ادعوا شركاءكم فدعوهم فلم يستجيبوا لهم ورأوا العذاب لو أنهم كانوا يهتدون

translation: And [mention] the Day He will call them and say, 'What was the answer you gave to the messengers?'
interpretation: This verse depicts a scene on the Day of Judgment when people will be questioned about the responses they provided to the messengers and the messages they brought. It emphasizes the accountability of individuals for their actions and beliefs, highlighting the importance of heeding the guidance brought by the messengers of God.
orig: ويوم يناديهم فيقول ماذا أجبتم المرسلين

translation: Then the reports will be obscured to them that Day, and they will not [be able to] ask one another.
interpretation: This verse highlights the Day of Judgment, emphasizing that the disbelievers will be overwhelmed by the events of that day to the extent that they will be unable to inquire or seek answers from one another. It indicates the intense fear and confusion that will envelop them on that day.
orig: فعميت عليهم الأنباء يومئذ فهم لا يتساءلون

translation: But as for one who repents, believes, and does righteousness, it may be that he will be among the successful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of sincere repentance, belief in God, and performing righteous deeds. It encourages individuals to seek forgiveness, have faith, and engage in good actions in the hope of attaining success in the Hereafter.
orig: فأما من تاب وآمن وعمل صالحا فعسى أن يكون من المفلحين

translation: And your Lord creates whatever He wills and chooses; not for them was the choice. Exalted is Allah! And high above what they associate with Him.
interpretation: This verse highlights the ultimate power and sovereignty of Allah in creating and choosing as He pleases. It emphasizes that humans do not have the ultimate choice in these matters, and that Allah's decisions are above and beyond the false associations that people make with Him. It serves as a reminder of submitting to the divine will and recognizing Allah's unmatched authority.
orig: وربك يخلق ما يشاء ويختار ما كان لهم الخيرة سبحان الله وتعالى عما يشركون

translation: And your Lord knows what their breasts conceal and what they declare.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that Allah knows everything that is hidden in the hearts and minds of people, as well as what they reveal or speak openly. It serves as a reminder that nothing is hidden from Allah, and that He is fully aware of our innermost thoughts and intentions.
orig: وربك يعلم ما تكن صدورهم وما يعلنون

translation: And He is Allah; there is no deity except Him. To Him belongs [all] praise in the first [life] and the Hereafter. And His is the [final] decision, and to Him you will be returned.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the oneness of Allah and the fact that He alone is worthy of worship. It also highlights that all praise belongs to Allah both in this life and the Hereafter. Additionally, it mentions that Allah holds the ultimate authority and will make the final decision, and ultimately, all beings will return to Him for judgment.
orig: وهو الله لا إله إلا هو له الحمد في الأولى والآخرة وله الحكم وإليه ترجعون

translation: Say, 'Have you considered: if Allah made for you the night continuous until the Day of Resurrection, what deity other than Allah could bring you light? Then will you not hear?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the power and authority of Allah over the night and day, emphasizing that if Allah willed, He could extend the night indefinitely until the Day of Judgment without anyone else being able to bring light. It serves as a reminder of Allah's control over all aspects of creation and challenges the disbelievers to reflect on His signs and guidance.
orig: قل أرأيتم إن جعل الله عليكم الليل سرمدا إلى يوم القيامة من إله غير الله يأتيكم بضياء أفلا تسمعون

translation: Say, Have you thought, if God made the day perpetual for you till the Day of Resurrection, who is a god other than God who could bring you night in which you may rest? Will you not see?
interpretation: This verse admonishes the people to reflect on the alternation of day and night as a sign of God's power and wisdom. It highlights the importance of recognizing and appreciating the divine order and balance in the natural world. By pondering upon this alternation, people are urged to realize the greatness of God's creation and His sovereignty over all aspects of life, thereby inviting them to believe in the oneness of God and to seek guidance and wisdom in His signs.
orig: قل أرأيتم إن جعل الله عليكم النهار سرمدا إلى يوم القيامة من إله غير الله يأتيكم بليل تسكنون فيه أفلا تبصرون

translation: And out of His mercy, He made for you the night and the day that you may rest therein and seek from His bounty, and [it is expected] that you will be grateful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the mercy of Allah in providing the night and the day for humanity. The night is for rest and the day for seeking sustenance and provisions. It reminds believers to appreciate Allah's countless blessings and be grateful for all that He has bestowed upon them.
orig: ومن رحمته جعل لكم الليل والنهار لتسكنوا فيه ولتبتغوا من فضله ولعلكم تشكرون

translation: And [mention] the Day He will call them and say, 'Where are My 'partners' which you used to claim?'
interpretation: This verse refers to a day when people will be called to account for their beliefs and actions. It highlights the idea that on that day, people will be confronted with the reality of their false beliefs in associating partners with God. It serves as a reminder of the importance of pure monotheism and the consequences of associating partners with God.
orig: ويوم يناديهم فيقول أين شركائي الذين كنتم تزعمون

translation: And We will extract from every nation a witness and say, 'Produce your proof,' and they will know that the truth belongs to Allah, and lost from them is that which they used to invent.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of accountability and proof on the Day of Judgment. On that day, every nation will have a witness of their actions, and they will be asked to provide evidence for their beliefs and deeds. The verse assures that the truth ultimately belongs to Allah, and all falsehood and fabrications will be exposed and lost. It highlights the importance of sincerity and adherence to the truth in one's beliefs and actions.
orig: ونزعنا من كل أمة شهيدا فقلنا هاتوا برهانكم فعلموا أن الحق لله وضل عنهم ما كانوا يفترون

translation: Indeed, Qarun was from the people of Moses, but he tyrannized them. And We gave him of treasures whose keys would burden a band of strong men; thereupon, his people said to him, 'Do not exult; indeed, Allah does not like the exultant.'
interpretation: This verse is a reminder of the story of Qarun (Korah in the Bible) from the people of Prophet Moses, who was given immense wealth and treasures but became arrogant and oppressive towards his people. Despite his wealth and power, his people warned him against arrogance and boasting because true happiness does not come from material possessions. The verse serves as a lesson about the dangers of pride, the consequences of tyranny, and the importance of humility in the eyes of Allah.
orig: إن قارون كان من قوم موسى فبغى عليهم وآتيناه من الكنوز ما إن مفاتحه لتنوء بالعصبة أولي القوة إذ قال له قومه لا تفرح إن الله لا يحب الفرحين

translation: And seek, through that which Allah has given you, the home of the Hereafter; and [yet], do not forget your share of the world. And do good as Allah has done good to you. And do not seek corruption in the land. Indeed, Allah does not like corrupters."
interpretation: This verse advises believers to prioritize seeking rewards in the Hereafter, while also not neglecting their responsibilities in this world. It encourages them to do good deeds and avoid spreading corruption. The verse emphasizes the importance of balance between the spiritual and worldly aspects of life, as well as promoting righteousness and preventing corruption. Allah loves those who strive for goodness and dislike those who spread mischief.
orig: وابتغ فيما آتاك الله الدار الآخرة ولا تنس نصيبك من الدنيا وأحسن كما أحسن الله إليك ولا تبغ الفساد في الأرض إن الله لا يحب المفسدين

translation: He said, 'I have only been given it because of knowledge I have.' Did he not know that Allah had destroyed before him of generations those who were greater than him in power and greater in accumulation? But the criminals are not asked about their sins.
interpretation: This verse highlights the arrogance and ignorance of those who deny Allah's signs by attributing their achievements solely to their own knowledge and power. It reminds them of the fate of past generations who were stronger and wealthier, yet were destroyed by Allah for their arrogance and sins. It serves as a warning against pride and a reminder of the consequences of rejecting the truth.
orig: قال إنما أوتيته على علم عندي أولم يعلم أن الله قد أهلك من قبله من القرون من هو أشد منه قوة وأكثر جمعا ولا يسأل عن ذنوبهم المجرمون

translation: And he came out before his people in his adornment. Those who desired the worldly life said, 'Oh, would that we had like what was given to Qarun. Indeed, he has been given a great fortune.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the danger of being lured by material possessions and worldly desires. It warns against coveting the wealth and status of others, as true success is not measured by worldly possessions but by faith, character, and good deeds in the sight of Allah.
orig: فخرج على قومه في زينته قال الذين يريدون الحياة الدنيا يا ليت لنا مثل ما أوتي قارون إنه لذو حظ عظيم

translation: And those who were given knowledge said, 'Woe to you! The reward of Allah is better for those who believe and do good deeds.' But none shall attain it except the patient.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of patience in attaining the reward from Allah. It emphasizes that those who believe in Allah, perform good deeds and remain patient will ultimately receive the best reward from Him. Patience is a virtue that is necessary to navigate the challenges and tests of life in order to attain the ultimate reward promised by Allah.
orig: وقال الذين أوتوا العلم ويلكم ثواب الله خير لمن آمن وعمل صالحا ولا يلقاها إلا الصابرون

translation: So We caused the earth to swallow him and his home. And he had no group to help him besides Allah, nor was he one of those who could defend themselves.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the power and control of Allah over all things. It serves as a reminder that no one can ultimately protect or save another except through the will of Allah. It highlights the importance of relying on Allah for help and protection, as ultimately He is the only true source of strength and support.
orig: فخسفنا به وبداره الأرض فما كان له من فئة ينصرونه من دون الله وما كان من المنتصرين

translation: And those who had wished for his position the previous day began to say, 'Oh, how Allah extends provision to whom He wills of His servants and restricts it! If not that Allah had conferred favor on us, He would have caused it to swallow us. Oh, how the disbelievers do not succeed!'
interpretation: This verse highlights the tendency of some people to envy others for the blessings or positions they have, attributing it solely to themselves or their own efforts. It reminds us that all provision and blessings are ultimately in the control of Allah, who grants them as He wills. The verse also points out the ingratitude exhibited by unbelievers who fail to recognize the source of their blessings and subsequently do not prosper.
orig: وأصبح الذين تمنوا مكانه بالأمس يقولون ويكأن الله يبسط الرزق لمن يشاء من عباده ويقدر لولا أن من الله علينا لخسف بنا ويكأنه لا يفلح الكافرون

translation: That home of the Hereafter We shall give to those who desire not exaltedness upon the earth, nor corruption. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the ultimate reward and destination in the Hereafter is for those who do not seek power and corruption in this world. It highlights that the righteous individuals are the ones who will attain the best outcome in the Hereafter.
orig: تلك الدار الآخرة نجعلها للذين لا يريدون علوا في الأرض ولا فسادا والعاقبة للمتقين

translation: Whoever comes with good will have better than it, and whoever comes with evil - then those who do evil will not be recompensed except [as much as] what they used to do.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of divine justice in Islam. It states that those who do good deeds will receive a better reward than their deeds, while those who do evil deeds will only be recompensed for the evil they have committed. It serves as a reminder that each person will be judged based on their actions, and that ultimately, good deeds will be rewarded and evil deeds will be accounted for.
orig: من جاء بالحسنة فله خير منها ومن جاء بالسيئة فلا يجزى الذين عملوا السيئات إلا ما كانوا يعملون

translation: Indeed, it is the One who imposed the Qur'an upon you will bring you back to a place of return. Say, 'My Lord is most knowing of who brings guidance and who is in clear error.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the idea that it is Allah who has set the rules and guidance through the Qur'an for believers. It underscores the ultimate authority and knowledge of Allah, who will guide those who seek guidance and reveal the truth to them. It also serves as a reminder that it is Allah who determines who is guided and who is led astray, ultimately highlighting the importance of seeking guidance from Allah.
orig: إن الذي فرض عليك القرآن لرادك إلى معاد قل ربي أعلم من جاء بالهدى ومن هو في ضلال مبين

translation: And you did not expect that the Book would be conveyed to you, but [it was] a mercy from your Lord. So do not be an assistant to the disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse is reminding the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) that the revelation of the Qur'an was a mercy from Allah. It instructs him not to support the disbelievers in their rejection of the truth, emphasizing the importance of staying firm in faith and not aiding those who consciously turn away from belief.
orig: وما كنت ترجو أن يلقى إليك الكتاب إلا رحمة من ربك فلا تكونن ظهيرا للكافرين

translation: And do not let yourself be diverted from the signs of Allah after they have been revealed to you, and invite (people) to your Lord. And never be of the polytheists.
interpretation: This verse reminds the reader not to be distracted or turned away from the signs of Allah and the guidance provided in the Qur'an. It emphasizes the importance of continuously inviting others to the worship of Allah and to avoid associating partners with Him in any form of polytheism or shirk.
orig: ولا يصدنك عن آيات الله بعد إذ أنزلت إليك وادع إلى ربك ولا تكونن من المشركين

translation: And do not invoke with Allah another deity. There is no deity [worthy of worship] except Him. Everything will be destroyed except His Face. His is the judgement, and to Him you will be returned.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of monotheism and warns against associating partners with Allah. It highlights the fact that only Allah deserves to be worshipped, as everything else is perishable except Him. The verse also serves as a reminder of the Day of Judgement when all beings will return to Allah for His judgement.
orig: ولا تدع مع الله إلها آخر لا إله إلا هو كل شيء هالك إلا وجهه له الحكم وإليه ترجعون

translation: Alif Laam Meem.
interpretation: This combination of letters, known as 'Huroof Muqatta'at', appears at the beginning of certain chapters (surahs) of the Qur'an. The exact meaning and purpose of these abbreviated letters remain a mystery, with various interpretations and theories proposed by scholars over time. Some suggest that they are divine signs, a challenge to the non-believers, or a way to emphasize the miraculous nature and complexity of the Qur'an.
orig: الم

translation: Do the people think that they will be left to say, 'We believe' and they will not be tested?
interpretation: This verse questions the belief of people that faith can be claimed without being tested. It emphasizes that true belief is proven through facing trials and challenges, requiring steadfastness and sincerity in one's faith.
orig: أحسب الناس أن يتركوا أن يقولوا آمنا وهم لا يفتنون

translation: And We have certainly tested those before them, so that Allah will make evident those who are truthful, and He will make evident the liars.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers that trials and tests are part of life, and just as those before them were tested, they are being tested as well. The purpose of these tests is to distinguish between those who are truthful and sincere in their faith, and those who are dishonest and deceitful. It emphasizes the importance of staying true to one's faith and being honest in all aspects of life, as these tests reveal one's true character and intentions.
orig: ولقد فتنا الذين من قبلهم فليعلمن الله الذين صدقوا وليعلمن الكاذبين

translation: Or do those who commit evils think We will make them like those who have believed and done righteous deeds - [make them] equal in their life and their death? Evil is that which they judge.
interpretation: This verse highlights the misconception of wrongdoers who believe that their actions will lead them to the same fate as those who have faith in God and perform good deeds. The verse emphasizes the importance of faith and righteous actions, condemning the misguided judgment of those who think otherwise.
orig: أم حسب الذين يعملون السيئات أن يسبقونا ساء ما يحكمون

translation: Whoever hopes for the meeting with Allah - indeed, the term decreed by Allah is coming. And He is the Hearing, the Knowing.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers that the meeting with Allah is inevitable, and that every soul will return to Him. It serves as a reminder of the ultimate fate of all beings, emphasizing the importance of preparing for the Hereafter and living a righteous life in anticipation of meeting Allah.
orig: من كان يرجو لقاء الله فإن أجل الله لآت وهو السميع العليم

translation: As for those who strive hard (in Us), We shall most certainly show them Our paths, and indeed Allah is with those who are of service to others.
interpretation: This verse highlights the concept that people who strive and put in effort towards God, will be guided to follow the righteous path Allah has set. It emphasizes that the efforts made by individuals are ultimately for their own benefit and growth. This verse assures that Allah is self-sufficient and does not need anything from the worlds, but He appreciates and rewards those who work diligently towards His cause.
orig: ومن جاهد فإنما يجاهد لنفسه إن الله لغني عن العالمين

translation: And those who believe and do righteous deeds - We will surely remove from them their misdeeds and will reward them according to the best of what they used to do.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of faith and good deeds. It assures believers that God will erase their sins and reward them generously for their righteous actions. It serves as a reminder of God's mercy and justice, encouraging believers to continue doing good deeds and having faith in Him.
orig: والذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات لنكفرن عنهم سيئاتهم ولنجزينهم أحسن الذي كانوا يعملون

translation: And We have enjoined upon man goodness to his parents. But if they endeavor to make you associate with Me that of which you have no knowledge, do not obey them. To Me is your return, and I will inform you about what you used to do.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of being kind and respectful towards parents. However, it also emphasizes not following them when they try to lead you to associate partners with God, something that goes against the teachings of Islam. In such cases, loyalty to God supersedes obedience to parents. Ultimately, all will return to God, and He will judge everyone based on their deeds.
orig: ووصينا الإنسان بوالديه حسنا وإن جاهداك لتشرك بي ما ليس لك به علم فلا تطعهما إلي مرجعكم فأنبئكم بما كنتم تعملون

translation: And those who believe and do righteous deeds, We will surely admit them among the righteous.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of both belief in Allah and the practice of good deeds. It indicates that true faith is demonstrated through righteous actions, and those who combine faith with good deeds will be among the righteous. It serves as a reminder that one's actions are a reflection of their beliefs and will be rewarded accordingly in the Hereafter.
orig: والذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات لندخلنهم في الصالحين

translation: And of the people is he who says, 'We have believed in Allah,' but when he is harmed for [the cause of] Allah, he considers the trial of the people as [if it were] the punishment of Allah. But if victory comes from your Lord, they say, 'Indeed, we were with you.' Is not Allah most knowing of what is within the breasts of the worlds?
interpretation: This verse highlights the hypocrisy of some people who claim to believe in Allah but when faced with hardships or persecution for their faith, they fail to remain steadfast and instead see the trials from people as punishment from Allah. However, when any success or victory comes their way, they quickly claim to have been supportive all along. The verse emphasizes that Allah is well aware of the true intentions and beliefs that reside within the hearts of all creation.
orig: ومن الناس من يقول آمنا بالله فإذا أوذي في الله جعل فتنة الناس كعذاب الله ولئن جاء نصر من ربك ليقولن إنا كنا معكم أوليس الله بأعلم بما في صدور العالمين

translation: And so that Allah will make evident those who believe and will make evident the hypocrites.
interpretation: This verse highlights that trials and tests are a means by which Allah distinguishes between those who truly believe in Him and those who are hypocritical in their claims of faith. It serves as a reminder that Allah's wisdom and knowledge encompass all things, including the true intentions of individuals, and that sincerity and faith are keys to being known and accepted by Him.
orig: وليعلمن الله الذين آمنوا وليعلمن المنافقين

translation: And those who disbelieve say to those who believe, 'Follow our way, and we will carry your sins.' But they will not carry anything of their sins. Indeed, they are liars.
interpretation: This verse highlights the arrogance and deception of the disbelievers who try to lead the believers astray by promising to bear the consequences of their sins. However, the disbelievers have no power to alleviate the burden of anyone's sins, and they are lying in their claims. It emphasizes the importance of staying firm in faith and not being swayed by the false promises of those who oppose the believers.
orig: وقال الذين كفروا للذين آمنوا اتبعوا سبيلنا ولنحمل خطاياكم وما هم بحاملين من خطاياهم من شيء إنهم لكاذبون

translation: And they will bear their own burdens, and other burdens along with their own, and they will surely be questioned on the Day of Resurrection about what they used to fabricate.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that everyone will be held accountable for their deeds on the Day of Judgment. Not only will individuals carry the weight of their actions, but they will also bear the consequences of leading others astray. In the end, all will be questioned about their lies and fabrications, showing that deceit and dishonesty will not go unnoticed by Allah.
orig: وليحملن أثقالهم وأثقالا مع أثقالهم وليسألن يوم القيامة عما كانوا يفترون

translation: And We certainly sent Noah to his people, and he stayed among them a thousand years minus fifty years, and the flood seized them while they were wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of the Prophet Noah (Nuh in Arabic) and how he called his people to the worship of one God for nearly a thousand years. Despite his efforts and persistence, his people persisted in their disobedience and wrongdoing. The verse highlights the consequences of their actions as they were ultimately punished by a flood. It serves as a reminder of the importance of guidance and the consequences of rejecting the truth.
orig: ولقد أرسلنا نوحا إلى قومه فلبث فيهم ألف سنة إلا خمسين عاما فأخذهم الطوفان وهم ظالمون

translation: So We saved him and those with him in the laden ship, making it a sign for the worlds.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) and the those who were with him in the Ark. It highlights the mercy and protection of Allah towards the believers. The Ark itself became a sign and a lesson for all people, serving as a reminder of the importance of faith and obedience to Allah.
orig: فأنجيناه وأصحاب السفينة وجعلناها آية للعالمين

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when Abraham said to his people, 'Worship Allah and fear Him. That is best for you, if you should know.'
interpretation: This verse from the Qur'an highlights the message of Prophet Abraham to his people, emphasizing the importance of worshipping Allah alone and being conscious of Him. The verse conveys the idea that true success and goodness come from obeying Allah and maintaining piety. It serves as a reminder to prioritize faith and righteousness in one's life for the ultimate benefit and well-being.
orig: وإبراهيم إذ قال لقومه اعبدوا الله واتقوه ذلكم خير لكم إن كنتم تعلمون

translation: You only worship idols besides Allah and produce falsehood. Indeed, those you worship besides Allah do not possess for you [the power of] provision. So seek from Allah provision and worship Him and be grateful to Him. To Him you will be returned.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the futility of worshipping anything other than Allah, highlighting that idols cannot provide sustenance or fulfill the needs of individuals. It encourages believers to seek provision from Allah alone, worship Him sincerely, and show gratitude, ultimately reminding them that all will return to Allah in the end.
orig: إنما تعبدون من دون الله أوثانا وتخلقون إفكا إن الذين تعبدون من دون الله لا يملكون لكم رزقا فابتغوا عند الله الرزق واعبدوه واشكروا له إليه ترجعون

translation: And if you deny [the truth] - already nations before you have denied. And the duty of the Messenger is only to clearly convey [the message].
interpretation: This verse highlights the inevitability of some people rejecting the message of the Qur'an, just as previous nations had also rejected the teachings of their respective prophets. It emphasizes that the role of the Messenger is solely to convey the message clearly, and that the ultimate acceptance or rejection of the message lies with the people themselves.
